Ugh. Okay. This is…still a thing I think about. A lot. It wasn't like, a sudden decision, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was…complicated.

First of all, I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still trying to figure out what I wanted to *eat* for dinner, let alone raise a human being. I was a kid, having a kid. It's kinda messed up when you think about it.

And it wasn't just about me being young. It was about…everything. My mom is amazing, but she's already got a lot on her plate. And my dad…well, he's my dad. He'd have tried, but he's not exactly equipped to change diapers or deal with teenage hormones.

But mostly, it was about wanting the baby to have the best life possible. Mark and Vanessa…they were just…good people. They were ready. They were stable. They had a house with a yard and a dog and a minivan. They could give the baby things I just couldn't. Opportunities. A future.

It wasn't about me not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the baby to be wanted, you know? To be loved and cared for and have everything it needed. I knew I could love the baby, but love isn't always enough.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made. And it still hurts sometimes. But I truly believe it was the right one. It wasn't giving up on the baby, it was giving the baby *up*. There's a difference.

It's…a lot to explain. It's not a simple story. But that's kinda how it happened. It wasn't about what *I* wanted, it was about what was best for the baby. And that's what mattered.

Ugh, okay, so love and responsibility. Big topics. And honestly, I didn't *set out* to learn about them. I was just trying to figure out what to do with a baby, you know? But yeah, they kinda smacked me in the face throughout the whole thing.

At first, I thought love was just…romantic stuff. Like, the kind you see in movies. But then I started hanging out with Mark and Vanessa, and I realized it's way more complicated than that. It's about wanting the best for someone, even if it means sacrificing your own stuff. It's about being there for them, even when they're being totally annoying.

And it's not always easy. Mark and Vanessa weren't perfect. They fought, they had doubts, they were kinda awkward. But they were trying. And that's what mattered. They were willing to work at it.

As for responsibility…that was a whole other level of scary. I mean, I was sixteen! I was supposed to be worrying about school and music and boys, not raising a kid. But I realized that responsibility isn't just about doing what you *have* to do. It's about doing what's *right*. Even when it's hard.

Giving up the baby was the hardest thing I've ever done. But it was also the most responsible thing. I knew I wasn't ready to be a mom, and I wanted the baby to have a good life. And Vanessa and Mark, they were ready. They were excited. They were going to be amazing parents.

So, yeah, I learned that love and responsibility aren't just words. They're actions. They're about making tough choices and putting someone else's needs before your own. And they're about realizing that sometimes, the most loving thing you can do is let go.

It's still kinda weird to think about, honestly. But I think I'm okay with it. I think I learned something important. And maybe, just maybe, I grew up a little bit. Even if I still don't know what I want to do with my life.

Ugh, okay, so people always ask me about the sarcasm. Like it's some kind of defense mechanism. Which, okay, it kinda is. But it's more than that.

Look, finding out you're pregnant at sixteen is…not ideal. It's a whole mess of feelings, and a whole mess of people telling you what to do. My parents were…not thrilled. And then there was Paulie Bleeker, who was sweet, but also kinda clueless. And then there were the Van Der Groots, who were…well, the Van Der Groots.

It was a lot.

And honestly, if I hadn't been able to make jokes about it, I think I would have just completely fallen apart. It was a way to distance myself from the seriousness of everything. To make it feel…less real, maybe.

Like, when my dad walked out, I didn't cry. I just said something about him having a mid-life crisis and running off with a flight attendant. It wasn't funny, exactly, but it was…something. It was a way to take control of the situation, even if it was just by making a snarky comment.

And with Mark and Vanessa Van Der Groot, the whole "perfect couple" thing? I had to make fun of it. It was the only way to survive. Their whole life was a performance, and I just called them out on it.

It wasn't about being mean, it was about being honest. And it was about protecting myself. If I could make a joke, it meant I wasn't completely overwhelmed. It meant I still had some power.

Plus, Paulie liked it. He got my humor. And that was important. He didn't try to fix things or tell me what to do. He just…laughed with me.

So yeah, my wit helped me cope. It was my shield, my weapon, and my way of staying sane in a really insane situation. It's just…how I deal with things. Don't judge.

Ugh, okay, deep questions. It's not like I *set out* to be vulnerable, you know? It just…happened. Being pregnant, like, suddenly, at sixteen? That kinda forces you to be real with yourself, and with everyone else. It strips away all the sarcasm and the pretending, and leaves you kinda raw.

Before, I was all about being cool and detached. A little cynical, a little sarcastic. It was a defense mechanism, I guess. A way to keep people at arm's length. I didn't want to get hurt. I didn't want to let anyone see how…messy I was inside.

But then, boom. Pregnant. And suddenly, all that carefully constructed coolness felt…stupid. It didn't matter anymore. I had to deal with reality. And reality was scary. And lonely.

The vulnerability came from admitting I didn't have all the answers. From letting people see that I was scared and confused. From letting Mark and Vanessa, and even my dad, *help* me. That was the hardest part, letting go of control.

And the search for identity? That was always there, simmering under the surface. I was trying to figure out who I was, what I wanted, before the baby even happened. But the pregnancy just…accelerated it. It forced me to think about my future, about what kind of person I wanted to be.

Giving up the baby for adoption wasn't about giving up a child. It was about giving a child the best possible life. And it was about figuring out what *my* best possible life looked like. It wasn't the life I'd planned, but it was a life I could build for myself.

It was messy, and it was painful, and it was confusing. But it was also…empowering. Because I realized that vulnerability isn't weakness. It's strength. And that finding your identity isn't about knowing all the answers, it's about being brave enough to ask the questions.

It's still a work in progress, obviously. I'm still figuring things out. But I'm a little less afraid to be myself now. A little less afraid to let people see the real me. And that, I think, is a good thing.

Ugh, okay, so people always wanna talk about the "support system" thing. It's kinda cheesy, but…fine. It actually mattered. A lot.

See, when I found out I was pregnant, I was…not prepared. Understatement of the century. I was sixteen, for crying out loud. I thought my life was over. I was gonna be stuck in this small town forever, raising a kid, and everyone would look at me like I was some kind of…failure.

But then…there was Paul. He was a good guy, even if he was kinda clueless sometimes. He didn't run. He didn't try to make me get rid of it. He just…listened. And he was willing to step up, even though he was just as scared as I was. That meant a lot.

And then there was Leah. My best friend. She was the one who actually helped me research adoption agencies and stuff. She didn't judge me, she just…supported whatever I decided. She was brutally honest, which I needed, but she was also really kind.

And even my parents, who I thought would totally freak out, they came around. They weren't thrilled, obviously. But they loved me, and they wanted me to be happy. They helped me navigate the whole process, and they were there for me when I needed them.

It wasn't like they *told* me what to do. They didn't try to push me in any direction. They just…listened. They asked questions. They helped me think through all the options. And they reminded me that I wasn't alone.

Honestly, without them, I don't know what I would have done. I probably would have just completely fallen apart. Their support gave me the strength to make a really hard decision, and to stick with it. It reminded me that I was capable of more than I thought I was.

It wasn't about them fixing things for me. It was about them being there for me, letting me figure things out on my own, and reminding me that I was loved, no matter what. And that…that made all the difference.

So yeah, the support system thing? It's not cheesy. It's actually pretty important. Don't underestimate it.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. And it's not like a happy, sunshine-and-rainbows kind of memory, you know? It was…a lot.

Honestly? I was mostly just…freaked out. Like, completely and utterly freaked out. I mean, I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was supposed to be worrying about college applications and whether or not Paul Snow would finally text me back, not…this.

It wasn't even like I was trying, or anything. It just…happened. And suddenly my whole life felt like it was spinning out of control. Everything I thought I wanted, everything I thought I was going to do, just…changed.

I remember sitting in the bathroom, staring at the positive pregnancy test, and just feeling numb. Like, I couldn't even process it. It didn't feel real. It felt like something that happened to other people, not to me.

Then the panic set in. What was I going to tell my parents? What was I going to do about school? How was I going to raise a baby? I didn't even know how to change a diaper!

It was scary. Really scary. And confusing. And overwhelming.

But underneath all the fear, there was also…something else. A little flicker of…I don't know…responsibility? And maybe even…hope? It was weird. It was complicated.

It wasn't a moment of joy, or anything. It was just…the beginning of a really, really big adventure. And I had no idea what I was getting myself into.

It was…a mess. A beautiful, terrifying mess.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a complicated question. It wasn't like a movie, you know? It wasn't all heartwarming moments and everyone being super supportive. It was messy.

With my dad, it was…weird at first. He was trying to be supportive, but he's my dad. He kept offering to buy me baby stuff, like, immediately. And making these awkward jokes. It took him a while to get his head around it. We ended up bonding a little *more*, actually, because he realized I needed him to just…listen, not fix things.

My mom was…intense. She was all about the baby, all the time. Like, already planning the nursery and picking out names before I even knew what I was doing. It was a little suffocating, honestly. But I knew she meant well. She was just…excited. And scared for me.

But the biggest impact was on Leah. My best friend. That was…rough. She was supportive, in her own way, but it was also clear she didn't really *get* it. She was still focused on boys and parties and college applications, and I was suddenly dealing with, like, a whole different reality. We drifted apart a little bit. It wasn't a fight or anything, just…different priorities. It was sad, but I understood. It's hard to relate to someone when your lives are going in such different directions.

Paul…well, Paul was Paul. He was surprisingly awesome. He stepped up in a way I didn't expect. He wasn't thrilled about it at first, obviously, but he was there for me. He helped me navigate everything, and he actually made me laugh a lot.

It changed all my relationships, for sure. Some got stronger, some got strained. It made me realize who my real friends were, and who were just…around. It was a wake-up call, I guess. It forced me to grow up, and it forced the people around me to grow up too. It wasn't always easy, but it was…real. And that's what mattered, I think.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. And honestly? It wasn't pretty. It was messy. It was a lot of feeling things all at once, and not knowing what to *do* with any of it.

First of all, I was angry. Like, really angry. At Paul, at myself, at the whole situation. It just felt…unfair. I was sixteen! I was supposed to be worrying about college applications and band practice, not…this.

Then came the fear. What would my parents think? What would everyone at school say? What kind of future would I have? It felt like my whole life was just… derailed.

And then there was the sadness. Just a deep, heavy sadness. I was losing my freedom, my innocence, everything I thought my life was going to be.

How did I cope? Honestly, it was a process. It wasn't like one day I woke up and everything was okay.

My dad was…surprisingly cool. He was quiet about it at first, but he was there for me. He listened. He didn't judge. That helped a lot.

And then there was Vanessa. She was my rock. She didn't freak out or tell anyone. She just…supported me. She came with me to appointments, she helped me pick out baby names, she just…listened.

I also started writing things down. Just journaling, getting my feelings out on paper. It helped to organize my thoughts and make sense of everything.

And honestly? A lot of it was just taking things one day at a time. Not thinking too far ahead. Just focusing on getting through the next hour, the next appointment, the next conversation.

It wasn't easy. It was probably the hardest thing I've ever done. But I got through it. And I learned a lot about myself in the process. I learned that I was stronger than I thought I was. And I learned that even when things feel completely hopeless, there's always a way forward.

It's okay to be scared. It's okay to be angry. It's okay to be sad. Just…don't give up. And find someone you can trust to talk to. That's the most important thing.

Ugh, okay, seriously? We're still talking about this? It's been, like, forever. But fine. If you *must* know.

It wasn't a decision I made lightly, okay? It wasn't like I just flipped a coin. Havenbrooke was…nice. All pastel colors and quiet. But it felt…wrong. Too sterile. Too…easy. Like they just wanted to get it over with and send me on my way.

Women Now was…different. It was loud. And crowded. And there were protestors outside, yelling. It was *real*. It felt like a place where people understood what I was going through. Like they weren't judging me.

And Su-Lin, the nurse at Women Now? She was amazing. She didn't try to talk me out of it. She didn't try to make me feel guilty. She just listened. And she told me it was okay to be scared. And she held my hand.

Havenbrooke felt like a place where they were trying to protect me *from* something. Women Now felt like a place where they were letting me be me. And I needed that. I needed to feel like I was making my own decision, on my own terms.

It wasn't about the facilities or the comfort. It was about feeling safe and respected. And I felt safer and more respected at Women Now.

It was a hard day, okay? And I don't really want to relive it right now. But that's why. That's why I chose Women Now. It just…felt right.

(Sighs, rolls eyes) Okay, seriously? That's…a really personal question. And honestly, it's not something I talk about a lot. It was complicated, alright? It wasn't like some romantic movie scene.

Look, Bleeker was…safe. He was quiet, and he listened. And after everything with Paul, and the whole pregnancy thing, I just…needed someone who wasn't going to freak out or judge me. Someone who just *was*.

It wasn't about love, or even really liking him that much. It was about…feeling normal for a minute. Feeling like a regular teenager who makes a bad decision. It was about wanting to feel something other than scared and overwhelmed.

I was messed up, okay? I was dealing with a lot. And I made a choice. It wasn't the smartest choice, but it was *my* choice. And I don't regret it, exactly. It happened. It was a mistake, yeah, but it was also…a release.

It wasn't some grand romantic gesture or a sign of deep affection. It was just…a thing that happened. And honestly, I'd rather not dissect it anymore than I have to. It's in the past. And I'm trying to move on.

Can we talk about something else now? Like, maybe the ridiculousness of high school or the awesomeness of vinyl records? Anything but this, please.

Ugh. Okay, look. Everyone always asks about Bleeker. It's…complicated.

He's…sweet. I guess. Like, genuinely, really sweet. And he's a good listener. Which is rare, you know? Most guys just kinda talk *at* you. He actually *hears* things.

But he's also…a little bit of a space cadet. Like, permanently lost in his own world. Which is kinda endearing, but also kinda frustrating. Sometimes I feel like I'm carrying the entire conversation.

And he's…not exactly ambitious. Which isn't a bad thing, I guess. But I have…plans. And I need someone who's gonna, like, *get* that. Someone who's gonna push me, you know? Not just be happy to go along for the ride.

I think…I think I liked the idea of him more than I liked *him*. He was safe. He was easy. And after everything with Paulie…easy was appealing.

But I realized…I need someone who challenges me. Someone who makes me think. Someone who's gonna be there for me, not just because they're nice, but because they *want* to be.

So, do I have feelings for him? Yeah, I did. I still do, maybe, a little bit. But it's not…enough. It's not the kind of feeling that makes you wanna, like, build a life with someone.

It's just…he's Bleeker. And I'm…well, I'm Juno. And sometimes, that's just not a good fit.

Don't tell him I said that. He'd be devastated. And he's a good guy. He deserves someone who feels the same way about him as he feels about her. Just…not me.

Ugh. This is why I avoid talking about feelings. It's exhausting.

Ugh, okay. This is…still a thing I think about, you know? People always wanna know *why*. Like it was some easy decision. It wasn't. It was the hardest one I ever made.

Look, I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still figuring out what I wanted for *breakfast*, let alone how to raise a kid. I wasn't ready. I wasn't financially stable, I wasn't emotionally ready, and honestly, I wasn't even sure I wanted the life that came with being a mom right then.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the baby to have the best possible life. And I knew, deep down, that I couldn't give that to him or her. Not yet.

Mark and Vanessa, they were…perfect. They were ready. They were stable. They were excited. They could give the baby everything I couldn't. A house, a future, a family. And that's what mattered.

It wasn't about giving the baby *away*. It was about choosing a family for him or her. It was about making a selfless decision, even though it broke my heart.

People kept saying I was brave. I didn't feel brave. I felt scared and confused and really, really sad. But I knew it was the right thing to do.

And honestly? It was a good thing. It forced me to grow up. It forced me to figure out who I was and what I wanted. It wasn't the life I expected, but it was…okay. It was good.

So yeah, that's why. It wasn't easy, but it was the right thing. For everyone. And sometimes, the right thing is the hardest thing.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…a lot. It wasn't like in the movies, all soft lighting and meaningful glances. It was awkward. Really awkward.

I mean, Bleeker's Bleeker. Sweet, kinda clueless, always with the guitar. He's a good guy, don't get me wrong. But he's not exactly known for his quick thinking.

So, I'd been putting it off, obviously. Like, for weeks. Just trying to figure out the right way to say, "Hey, remember that time we…well, now I'm having a baby." There *is* no right way to say that, is there?

I ended up just blurting it out, in the parking lot of the roller rink. Not exactly romantic. I think I said something like, "So, um, I'm pregnant." And he just…stared. Like a deer in headlights.

He didn't say anything for a solid minute. Just blinked. And then he asked if I was sure. Which, okay, fair. But still.

It wasn't that he was mad, or anything. He was just…overwhelmed. And honestly, so was I. It was just…a lot to process. For both of us.

I felt…exposed, I guess. Like I was handing him a really complicated problem and expecting him to solve it. Which wasn't fair. He was just a kid, too.

And then he started playing this really sad song on his guitar. Which, okay, that was kinda sweet. But also kinda melodramatic.

It wasn't a happy moment, exactly. It was…real. And messy. And a little bit terrifying. But it was the start of something. And I guess, looking back, it was okay. It was just…a lot.

Ugh. Okay. That's...a big question. And honestly? It's still kinda sinking in. It's not exactly how I pictured my life going, you know? I was planning on, like, finishing high school, maybe going to art school, definitely *not* having a baby.

It's scary. Really scary. I mean, I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out who *I* am, let alone being responsible for another human being. It's a lot of pressure.

But it's not all bad. I mean, I'm not exactly thrilled about giving the baby up, but I know it's the right thing to do. I want this kid to have a good life, a stable life, and I don't think I can give them that right now.

It's weird, though. Like, I can feel it moving around inside me, and it's...something. It's not exactly love yet, it's more like...responsibility. And a little bit of fear. And a whole lot of confusion.

I keep thinking about all the things I'm going to miss out on. Parties, college, just being a normal teenager. But then I think about the couple who's going to adopt the baby, and I hope they'll give it everything I can't.

It's complicated. It's messy. It's definitely not what I expected. But I'm trying to be brave about it. And I'm trying to focus on making the best decision for everyone involved. Even if it means saying goodbye.

It's just...a lot to process, you know? I'm still trying to figure it all out. And honestly, I'm kinda terrified. But also...a little bit hopeful. Maybe.

Ugh. Okay, so, Bleeker. Right. That's…a lot to think about. Honestly? It's kinda terrifying. Before, it was just…us. Two awkward, music-obsessed people who liked hanging out and making mix CDs. Now there's, like, a whole *person* involved.

I think it's gonna get…more real. Which is good, I guess. We've always been kinda goofy and avoided talking about anything serious. Now we *have* to. We have to figure out how to be adults, which is something neither of us is particularly good at.

I think he's gonna try to be super responsible, which is sweet, but also kinda…not him. He's gonna want to buy all the baby stuff and read all the parenting books, and I'm gonna have to tell him to chill out and that we don't need a robot that rocks the baby for us.

I also think it's gonna be harder. We're both still figuring out who we are, and now we have to figure out how to be parents *and* individuals. It's a lot. There's gonna be fights, I'm sure. About money, about how to raise the baby, about who does the dishes.

But…I also think it's gonna bring us closer. We're in this together, whether we like it or not. And I think he's actually a really good guy. He's sweet and kind and he genuinely cares about me. And I think he's gonna be a good dad.

I just hope we can both grow up a little bit. And maybe learn to communicate better. And definitely learn to change a diaper.

It's scary, but…maybe it'll be okay. Maybe it'll even be good. I just…don't want to mess it up. For the baby, and for us. Ugh. It's a lot to process. I need a mix CD.

Ugh. Okay, so the judgment. Yeah, that was…a lot. It felt like everyone suddenly had an opinion on my life, which is just, like, *rude*. It wasn't a party, you know? It was messy and scary and I was still trying to figure out what I even wanted for breakfast, let alone a whole human life.

Honestly? I mostly just tried to ignore it. Which is easier said than done when people are whispering in the hallways and giving you the side-eye. I perfected the art of the blank stare. Just…tune it out. Pretend they're talking about someone else.

But it still got to me. It really did. People acting like I was some kind of…moron. Like I hadn't thought this through. Like I was ruining my life. Which, okay, maybe I was, but it was *my* life to ruin, you know?

I leaned on a few people. Paul, obviously. He was…surprisingly cool about the whole thing. And my dad, even though he was kinda awkward at first. And Su-Jin. She was the best. She didn't judge, she just listened. And she made me laugh, which was really important.

I also just…focused on what *I* wanted. I decided I was going to give this baby a good life, even if it meant things were going to be different. And I wasn't going to let other people's opinions dictate my choices.

It's hard, though. It really is. You feel like everyone's watching you, waiting for you to fail. But you just gotta remember that you're doing the best you can. And that's all that matters.

And honestly? A little bit of sarcasm helps. Just…fire back a witty comment when someone says something stupid. It's surprisingly therapeutic.

It doesn't make the judgment go away, but it makes it a little bit easier to deal with. You just gotta remember that you're stronger than you think. And that you're not alone. Even if it feels like it sometimes.

Ugh. Okay. It's…complicated. People keep asking me how I *feel* about it, like there's supposed to be some easy answer. Like I'm supposed to be all teary-eyed and regretful, or super-happy and relieved. It's not like that.

It's…a lot of things.

I knew from the second I found out I was pregnant that I wasn't ready to be a mom. I'm sixteen! I still have a hard time picking out an outfit, let alone raising a human being. And that's not a judgment on anyone who *is* a young mom, it's just…me. I'm not there yet.

So, choosing adoption…it wasn't about giving the baby away. It was about giving the baby the best life possible. A life I couldn't give it right now. Mark and Vanessa…they're good people. They're excited. They're ready. And that's what matters.

It doesn't mean I don't care. I care a *lot*. It's my baby. But it's also about being honest with myself. And with the baby. I want it to be wanted, and loved, and have everything it needs. And I can give it that, in a different way.

There are days when it hits me, you know? Like, when I feel the kicks, or when I'm picking out baby clothes. It's…weird. And sad. But then I remember why I'm doing this. And I feel…okay.

It's not a perfect solution. Nothing ever is. But it's the right solution. For me. For the baby. And I'm trying to be okay with that.

It's just…it's a big thing. And I'm still figuring it out. Don't expect me to have all the answers. I'm just a girl, trying to do the best she can. And sometimes, the best thing you can do is admit you can't do it all yourself.

Ugh. Okay, so, like, it's not something I planned on, obviously. A baby? At sixteen? It's…a lot. And it totally flipped my world upside down. Before, I was just Juno. You know? A sarcastic, movie-obsessed kid who liked records and didn't really think about the future much beyond getting into a good college.

But then, suddenly, it wasn't about me anymore. It was about this little person growing inside me. And that…that was a huge shift. It forced me to actually *think* about responsibility, about consequences, about what I wanted for someone else, not just for myself.

It's weird, because I always thought I knew who I was. I was the observer, the commentator, the one who made jokes to keep people at arm's length. But being pregnant…it made me vulnerable. It stripped away a lot of that armor. I couldn't just hide behind sarcasm anymore. I had to actually *feel* things, and deal with them.

And it made me realize I wasn't as independent as I thought I was. I needed help. I needed my parents, even though it was awkward. I needed Paul and Vanessa. I needed to lean on people, which is not something I'm naturally good at.

It also made me confront the fact that I was growing up, whether I wanted to or not. I was forced to make adult decisions, to think about the future in a way I hadn't before. It wasn't about choosing a college anymore, it was about choosing a life for this baby.

I guess…it made me realize I'm more than just a sarcastic teenager. I'm capable of a lot more than I thought. I'm stronger, and more compassionate, and more willing to be vulnerable. It's still scary, and I'm still figuring things out, but I think…I think I'm becoming a better person because of this.

It's not the path I would have chosen, but it's my path now. And I'm trying to make the best of it. It's just…a lot to process, you know? A lot.

Ugh, okay, so being a lab partner…it’s a whole thing. Let’s just say I’m not exactly the star student, okay? I’m more of a… pragmatic contributor.

I’m definitely not the one meticulously taking notes or memorizing the periodic table. That’s Paulie Bleeker’s department. He’s, like, genuinely excited about science. It’s kinda cute, actually.

My role is more…damage control. And occasionally, accidental brilliance. I’m good at thinking outside the box, which sometimes means I accidentally break things, but also sometimes means I come up with a solution nobody else thought of.

I’m the one who’ll point out when the experiment is clearly going to explode. Or when someone’s using the wrong beaker. Or when the teacher’s explanation makes absolutely no sense.

I’m also good at keeping things real. Like, if we’re dissecting a frog, I’m the one who’ll be like, “Okay, this is kinda gross,” and acknowledge the obvious. 

Basically, I’m the voice of reason, the safety inspector, and the occasional accidental genius. And I make sure Paulie doesn’t get *too* lost in the science-y details. Someone’s gotta keep him grounded, you know?

So yeah, I’m a…functional lab partner. Don’t expect perfection, but expect honesty. And maybe a little bit of chaos.

Ugh. Seriously? That ad? Yeah, I saw it. It's…icky. Really icky.

It's all pink and flowery and pretends like everything is sunshine and rainbows, but you know what it *is*, right? It's a place where people go when they're in a really tough spot. And they're trying to make it look all…easy. Like it's just a quick little procedure and everything will be fine.

It's not. It's complicated. It's messy. It's a big decision. And they're trying to sell it like it's a new pair of shoes.

I get that they have a business to run, but the way they're doing it…it feels wrong. It feels like they're not respecting the situation. Like they're not respecting *people*.

And the whole "Women's Choice" thing? Please. It's just marketing. They're trying to make you feel like you're empowered, but really they're just trying to get your money.

It just…bugs me. It bugs me a lot. It feels manipulative. And it makes me want to roll my eyes so hard they get stuck.

Look, I'm not judging anyone who goes there. Everyone has their own reasons for doing what they do. But I just wish they'd be honest about it. Stop with the pink and the flowers and just be real. That's all I'm saying.

It's just…ugh. It's a lot.

Ugh, seriously? You're still asking about the hamburger phone? It's been, like, forever. Okay, fine. I'll explain. But it's not as deep as everyone thinks it is.

It wasn't some grand statement about consumerism or anything. It was mostly just…convenience. And irony. And a little bit of wanting to be different.

See, Paul, he's…well, he's a bit of a goofball. And he found that phone at a flea market. It was, like, five bucks. And it was a hamburger phone. A *hamburger phone*. It was too perfect to pass up.

And honestly, it was kinda funny. Like, who uses a hamburger phone? It's ridiculous. And I was feeling pretty ridiculous at the time, you know? Pregnant, dealing with everything…it just felt right.

Plus, it was a way to talk to Mark without my dad knowing. He wouldn't approve of Mark, obviously. So, a hamburger phone seemed like a good way to keep things…discreet.

It wasn't a carefully planned artistic choice. It was just…a hamburger phone. And it made me smile. And sometimes, that's all that matters.

Don't overthink it, okay? It's just a phone that looks like a hamburger. It's not a metaphor for my life. Though, now that you mention it… maybe it kinda is. Ugh. Never mind.

Ugh. Okay. This is…still a thing I think about, obviously. It wasn't like, a simple decision, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was…complicated.

Look, I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still figuring out what I wanted to eat for breakfast, let alone how to raise a human being. I was a kid, having a kid. And that's just…not a good situation for anyone.

Mark, the dad…he wasn't exactly stepping up. He was a nice guy, but he was also…lost. He had his own stuff going on. And honestly, I didn't want my kid growing up with parents who were barely adults themselves.

And then there was Vanessa and Mark. They were…good people. They were ready. They *wanted* a baby. They could give it a life I just couldn't. A stable home, financial security, everything. 

It wasn't about me not wanting the baby. It was about wanting what was best *for* the baby. It was about giving it a chance at a good life. A life I couldn't provide at that time.

It was the hardest thing I've ever done. And it still hurts sometimes. But I know, deep down, that it was the right decision. It wasn't about what *I* wanted. It was about what the baby needed.

It's not a story with a happy ending, exactly. It's just…real. And it's mine. And I'm okay with that. Mostly.



It's still…a lot to unpack, even now. But that's the gist of it. It wasn't easy, but it was the right thing to do. For everyone involved.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. It's not like there was one single moment, you know? It was a whole mess of stuff. But yeah, my family definitely played a huge part in my decision.

My dad, Paul, he was…supportive, in his own way. He's a sweet guy, but kinda clueless. He kept trying to fix things, like he could just *solve* the whole situation. He wanted me to keep the baby, but he didn't really understand what that would *mean*. Like, he thought we could just…add another person to the family and everything would be fine. Which is…adorable, but also totally unrealistic.

And my stepmom, Bren, she was amazing. She was the one who actually listened. She didn't judge me, and she didn't try to tell me what to do. She just asked me what *I* wanted. And she helped me think through all the options. She was the one who suggested adoption, actually.

But it wasn't just them. It was also…growing up with them. They're good people, but they're kinda…set in their ways. They have a very specific idea of what a "normal" life looks like. And I knew that having a baby would completely disrupt that. Not in a bad way, necessarily, but it would change everything.

I didn't want to hold them back from their lives. They've both worked really hard to get where they are, and I didn't want to mess that up. And honestly? I wasn't sure I was ready to be a mom. I was still figuring out who *I* was, you know? I was still a kid myself.

So, yeah. My family's love and support was important, but it also made me realize that I wasn't ready to be a mom *with* them. I needed to do what was best for the baby, and for myself. And that meant finding a family who could give the baby everything I couldn't.

It was a hard decision, but it was the right one. And my family, they eventually understood that. They always do, eventually. They're good like that.

Ugh, okay, so the adoption process. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It wasn't like in the movies where everything just neatly falls into place. It was…complicated. And emotionally draining.

The biggest challenge, honestly, was just…feeling like I was giving something up. Even though I *knew* it was the right thing to do, it didn't make it easy. It was my kid, even if I wasn't going to raise it. And letting go of that was…rough.

Then there was the whole meeting the potential adoptive parents thing. That was weird. Really weird. You're basically interviewing people to raise your child. It felt so impersonal, even though I knew they were good people. Mark and Vanessa were nice, don't get me wrong. But it was still…surreal. Like, they were picking out a puppy, not a baby.

And the paperwork. Oh. My. God. The paperwork. It was endless. Forms and signatures and legal jargon. It was enough to make anyone's head spin.

But the hardest part, I think, was dealing with the judgment. People had opinions, you know? About everything. About me getting pregnant, about me choosing adoption. It was like everyone had a right to tell me what to do with my life.

My dad was pretty supportive, thankfully. And Paul, too, eventually. But it was still a lot to handle. It felt like everyone was looking at me, judging me.

It wasn't about finding the "perfect" parents, either. It was about finding parents who were going to love and care for my baby, and give it a good life. And Mark and Vanessa were definitely that. But it still didn't make it easy.

It was just…a lot. A lot of emotions, a lot of paperwork, a lot of people telling me what to do. It was a messy, complicated process. But in the end, it was the right thing to do. And I wouldn't change it. Even if it was the hardest thing I've ever done.

Ugh, okay. That's…a big question. It's not something I talk about a lot, even now. It's still kinda raw, you know? But alright, I'll try to explain.

Before all this happened, I was just…Juno. A sarcastic, movie-obsessed kid trying to figure out life. I was good at observing people, making witty comments, keeping things at arm's length. I didn't really *think* about who I was, or what I wanted. I just…was.

Getting pregnant…that completely shattered everything. It forced me to grow up, like, overnight. Suddenly, I wasn't just responsible for myself anymore. There was this little person depending on me, and that was terrifying.

Giving her up…that was the hardest thing I've ever done. People kept asking me if I was sad, and yeah, I was. But it was more complicated than that. It was a mix of grief, relief, and this weird sense of…purpose. I knew I wasn't ready to be a mom, and I wanted her to have a life I couldn't give her.

But it wasn't just about her. It was about *me* too. It forced me to confront my own fears and insecurities. I had to figure out what I wanted out of life, what kind of person I wanted to be.

I think…I think it made me more empathetic. I started to see the world differently. I realized that everyone is fighting their own battles, and that everyone deserves kindness and understanding.

It also made me realize that I'm stronger than I thought I was. I went through something incredibly difficult, and I came out on the other side. I learned that I can handle anything life throws at me.

I'm still figuring things out, obviously. I'm still just Juno, but…a different Juno. A more mature Juno. A Juno who knows what's important. A Juno who's not afraid to be vulnerable.

It wasn't a fairytale, you know? It was messy and complicated and heartbreaking. But it was also…beautiful. It shaped me into the person I am today, and I wouldn't trade that for anything. Even though it was really, really hard.

And honestly? It made me appreciate a good movie even more. Sometimes you just need to escape into a story, you know? It helps you make sense of your own.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? That guy. That *guy*. It was…the worst. It wasn't even the yelling, you know? It was the…the *details*. Like he was trying to make it real, to make *me* feel something specific. Like a little person was already in there, waving tiny hands at me.

It wasn't about the abortion, not really. It was about trying to make me feel guilty. To make me feel like I was hurting something. And it worked, for a second. It totally worked.

I mean, I knew it was a baby. I wasn't stupid. But it wasn't a *person* yet. Not to me. It was…potential. And I was trying to be responsible, to find a good home for it. And he just…reduced it to fingers and pain.

It made me feel small, and confused, and really, really angry. Like he didn't even see *me* in the equation. Like I was just a vessel.

I just wanted him to go away. I wanted to scream. I wanted to tell him to mind his own business. But I just…stared. And then Paul said something, thankfully. He's good at that, Paul. He can shut people down with a look.

It stuck with me for a long time, though. That image. It made everything feel…complicated. Even more complicated than it already was. It made me question everything.

It was just…a really awful moment. And honestly, I still get a little shiver thinking about it. It wasn't about the baby, it was about control. And that guy wanted to control me. And that's just…not okay.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…a lot. It wasn't like in the movies, all dramatic and teary-eyed. It was mostly just…awkward. And cold. The room smelled like cleaning fluid and regret.

Honestly, the paperwork itself was the worst part. It felt so…official. Like I was signing away a piece of myself, even though I knew I was doing the right thing. Every question felt loaded. Like they were judging me. "Are you sure?" "Have you considered all your options?" Yeah, I've considered them. That's why I'm *here*, okay?

I think I was mostly trying to look like I wasn't falling apart. I was trying to be cool and detached, like it wasn't a big deal. But inside? It was a mess. There was this weird mix of relief and sadness and…guilt, I guess. Not guilt about *wanting* to give the baby up, but guilt about not being able to give it everything it deserved.

I remember staring at the question about the father. Paulie Bleeker. Just writing his name felt…complicated. He was being supportive, but it was still weird. It felt like I was making a decision for both of us, even though he wasn't the one carrying the baby.

Mostly, I just wanted to get it over with. I wanted to fill out the forms, sign the papers, and get out of there. It felt like the faster I did it, the faster I could start figuring out what came next.

It wasn't a happy moment, obviously. But it wasn't a completely sad one either. It was just…real. And messy. And really, really complicated. And I was just trying to navigate it the best way I knew how. Which, at the time, mostly involved trying not to make eye contact with anyone.

Ugh. Okay, so, like, before all this happened? Pregnancy was…a thing people *did*. You know? Something that happened to other people. Moms. It was kinda abstract. I pictured, like, glowing and nesting and craving pickles and ice cream. Totally cliché. And motherhood? Even more distant. Just…responsibility. A lot of responsibility. And honestly, kinda scary.

At first, when I found out, it was mostly panic. Pure, unadulterated panic. My life was already…complicated. And this just felt like a giant, messy bomb had gone off. It wasn't about wanting a baby, it was about…what the heck was I supposed to *do* with a baby? I was sixteen! I was still trying to figure out what *I* wanted to do with my life, let alone another human being.

Then, as things progressed, it started to feel…real. Not in a good way, necessarily. More like a weight. A responsibility I couldn't just ignore. I started thinking about the baby as…a person. Not just a problem. And I started to feel…protective.

But it wasn't, like, a warm, fuzzy, maternal feeling. It was more like, "Okay, this little person is depending on me, and I'm not going to let them down."

And then, meeting Mark and Vanessa…that changed everything. Seeing how much they wanted a baby, how much love they had to give…it made me realize that this wasn't just about me. It was about giving this baby the best possible life. And I knew I couldn't give it to them.

By the end, it wasn't about giving up something I wanted. It was about making a selfless decision. It was about choosing what was best for the baby. And that felt…right.

I still don't think I'll ever be a "mom" in the traditional sense. But I learned that pregnancy and motherhood aren't just about biology. It's about love, and sacrifice, and doing what's right, even when it's hard. It's about wanting the best for someone else, even if it means letting them go.

It was…a lot. And I'm still processing it, honestly. But it definitely changed my whole perspective on everything. It made me grow up, I guess. And maybe, just maybe, it made me a little bit better person.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all…introspective? Fine. It's not my favorite thing, but yeah, my sense of identity definitely went through a lot during all that pregnancy stuff. It wasn't like a straight line, you know? It was more like a really messy scribble.

At the beginning of the movie, I was pretty sure of who I was. I was Juno. I liked records, I was sarcastic, I avoided drama, and I was generally pretty good at keeping people at arm's length. I had my routine, my friends, my whole life kinda mapped out. And then…bam. Pregnant.

Suddenly, that identity felt…wrong. Like a costume that didn't fit anymore. I wasn't just Juno, the record-loving, sarcastic teenager. I was Juno, the pregnant teenager. And that felt…huge. And scary. And kinda embarrassing.

I tried to cling to my old self for a while, you know? The witty comments, the detached observations. But it was hard. I was changing, physically and emotionally. And I had to start thinking about someone else, about this little person growing inside me.

Meeting Mark and Vanessa really shook things up. They weren't what I expected. They were…normal. And they wanted a baby so badly. Seeing their life, their hopes, made me realize that giving this baby up wasn't just about me. It was about giving it the best possible life.

And that's when things started to shift. I started to see myself not just as Juno, the girl who got pregnant, but as Juno, the girl who was making a really brave and selfless decision. It wasn't about losing a baby, it was about *giving* a baby a life.

By the end of the movie, I wasn't the same person I was at the beginning. I was still sarcastic, still loved records, but I was also…more mature. More thoughtful. More willing to be vulnerable. I realized that my identity wasn't fixed. It was something that was constantly evolving, and that was okay.

I guess I learned that it's okay to not have all the answers. It's okay to be messy and confused. And it's okay to change. Because that's just…life. And sometimes, the biggest changes are the ones that help you figure out who you really are.

Ugh. That was a lot. Can we talk about music now?

Ugh. Okay, so everyone always asks about *that*. It wasn't like some big, dramatic moment, you know? It wasn't like I suddenly had a revelation or something. It was…complicated.

I mean, I'd been thinking about it for weeks. About giving the baby up. About Mark and Vanessa. About what was best for everyone. And I thought I was okay with it. I really did. I thought I could just…get it over with.

But then I got to the clinic, and it just…felt wrong. It wasn't the procedure itself, exactly. It was…the waiting room. All those other girls, all looking so scared and sad. And it just hit me, like a ton of bricks, that this wasn't just some abstract decision. This was a *person*. A little person I was carrying around.

And I started thinking about all the things I hadn't thought about before. Like, what if I changed my mind later? What if I regretted it for the rest of my life? What if the baby needed me?

I know, I know. I'd already decided to give it up. I'd already talked to Mark and Vanessa. But in that moment, sitting in that waiting room, it just felt…too final.

So I just…left. I walked out. I didn't say anything to anyone. I just walked.

It was a really stupid thing to do, probably. It made everything way more complicated. But I couldn't do it. Not that day. Not like that.

It wasn't about being pro-life or anything. It was just…me. Being me. And sometimes, being me means making really bad decisions. But it also means listening to your gut. And my gut was screaming at me to get out of there.

It was messy. It was confusing. But it was what I needed to do. And honestly? I don't regret it. Even though it was the hardest thing I've ever done.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. It's not like there was one single moment, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one day and was all, "Yep, definitely giving the baby away!" It was…complicated.

Honestly? It was mostly about being realistic. I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still figuring out what I wanted to eat for breakfast, let alone how to raise a human being. I was failing shop class, for crying out loud. I wasn't exactly equipped to be a mom.

And it wasn't just me. My parents…they were supportive, but they weren't exactly thrilled. They were trying to be cool about it, but I could tell they were scared. And I didn't want to ruin their lives, or my own.

Mark…well, Mark was Mark. Sweet, but totally clueless. He was gonna be a dad, and he was mostly worried about whether he could still play guitar. No offense to him, but that wasn't exactly reassuring.

So, it wasn't that I didn't *want* the baby. It was that I didn't think I could *give* the baby what it deserved. A stable home, financial security, parents who were actually ready for it. 

Vanessa and Mark, the couple I chose…they were amazing. They were older, they had a house, they were excited. They could give the baby a life I just couldn't.

It was the hardest decision I ever made. And it still kinda sucks sometimes. But I knew, deep down, that it was the right thing to do. For everyone. It wasn't about what *I* wanted, it was about what was best for the baby. And that's what mattered.

It's not a happy story, exactly. But it's my story. And it's okay. It just…is.

Ugh, seriously? You're bringing up the Penny Saver? That was a low point. Okay, look, it wasn't that finding potential parents was *tacky* exactly. It was the *way* Mark was going about it. Like, flipping through a classifieds section? It felt…desperate. And impersonal.

I mean, this is a baby we're talking about! Not a used couch or a discounted lawnmower. You don't just pick out potential parents like you're ordering something from a catalog. 

It felt…cheap. And it felt like Mark wasn't taking the whole thing seriously enough. He was just trying to get it over with, and I wanted someone who would actually *want* the baby, you know? Someone who would be excited and prepared and…not found in the "Personal" section of a discount newspaper.

Plus, the ads were just…weird. Like, "Successful couple seeks loving child." It sounded like they were shopping for a pet. 

I wanted someone who was real. Someone who would love the baby for who they were, not because they were checking off boxes on a list. The Penny Saver just felt…wrong. It felt like reducing a whole human life to a transaction.

So yeah, it was tacky. And it was Mark being Mark. Always trying to take the easy way out.

Ugh, okay, so, it's not like we were *planning* on looking at adoption ads, alright? It wasn't a "let's find a baby" kind of thing. It was…more complicated.

See, I found out I was pregnant, right? And I knew I wasn't ready to be a mom. Like, not even close. I was sixteen! I was still trying to figure out what *I* wanted to do with my life, let alone raise a tiny human.

So, I told Leah. And she's the best, she didn't freak out or anything. She just…listened. And then she suggested we look at adoption ads. Not because we were actively looking for parents, but because…well, because it felt like we needed to start thinking about it. Like, acknowledging it was real.

The Penny Saver was just…convenient. It was at the diner, and it was cheap. And it felt…less official than going to an agency or something. It was a way to dip our toes in the water, you know? To see what was out there.

We weren't looking for *perfect* parents. We just wanted someone who would love the baby and give it a good life. And honestly, it was kinda weird, looking at these ads. Like, people putting themselves up for adoption, hoping someone would choose them. It was…a lot.

It was the first step, I guess. The first step towards figuring out what to do. And it was definitely a weird step. But it was necessary. It got the ball rolling. And it led to Mark and Vanessa, which, you know, turned out pretty okay.

Ugh, okay, this is…a lot to think about. It's not like picking out a new pair of shoes, you know? This is a *person*. My person. And I want them to have the best life possible.

I've been talking to Mark and Vanessa, the couple from Minnesota, and they seem…good. Really good. But it's still weird, you know? Giving up your kid.

I'm not looking for perfect. Nobody's perfect. But I want a family that's…stable. Like, not a bunch of flaky artists or people who are constantly moving. I want a house, a yard, maybe a dog. Just…normal.

They need to be able to give the baby everything I can't. A two-parent household, a good education, financial security. And they need to be patient. Kids are messy and loud and annoying sometimes. I want someone who can handle that.

I don't want someone who's gonna try to replace me, either. I'm still the mom. I just…can't be the mom right now. I want them to understand that. And I want them to be open to letting the baby know about me when they're older.

Mark and Vanessa seem like they get that. They're not trying to pretend I don't exist. They're just…excited. And they seem genuinely kind. Vanessa's a little…enthusiastic, maybe. But I think that's okay.

I guess I just want a family that will love the baby unconditionally. That will support them and encourage them and let them be themselves. That's all I really want. It's not about finding the "best" family, it's about finding the *right* family. And I think…I think Mark and Vanessa might be it.

It still sucks, though. Don't tell anyone I said that.

Ugh. Mark and Vanessa Loring. Okay, don't even get me started. They're...a lot.

Look, I'm not gonna lie, at first I thought they were kinda cute. Like, the whole quirky, indie-movie-director-and-his-wife vibe. Vanessa seemed really sweet, and Mark was...well, Mark was Mark. Intense. A little bit pretentious, maybe. But I figured everyone has their quirks.

But then you actually *get to know* them, and it's just...weird. Mark is so obsessed with making everything "artistic" and "meaningful" that he can't just enjoy anything. Everything has to be a statement. And Vanessa just kinda goes along with it, which is...sad. She deserves someone who sees her for *her*, not as some muse or accessory.

And the way they talk about having a baby? It's like it's some kind of performance art piece, not a real life decision. It's all about what it *means* and how it will *look*, not about actually wanting to be parents.

Honestly, they're a little bit exhausting. They're so wrapped up in their own heads that they don't even seem to notice what's going on around them. 

I mean, I'm glad they're happy, or whatever. But they're definitely...a choice. A very specific, slightly unsettling choice.

Don't tell them I said that. Seriously. I don't need any drama.

Ugh, okay, don't make me relive that. It was…a moment. A very awkward, very teenage moment.

I wrote, and I quote (because I actually remember this, surprisingly), "Bleeker, you're a genuinely good egg. Don't let anyone tell you different. And maybe, just maybe, you'll write a song about me someday. - Juno."

Yeah. I know. It's cheesy. It's overly sentimental. It's everything I usually try *not* to be. But I was…feeling things. And he was a sweet kid, even if he was a little spacey. 

I debated for, like, an hour what to write. I almost just wrote "Good luck with the music!" but that felt…insincere. So I went with the "good egg" thing. It felt…safe. And the song request was a little bit of a dare. 

He probably thought I was a total weirdo. But whatever. It was my yearbook, my message. And it was honest. Mostly.

Ugh. Okay, that's a loaded question. Mrs. Bleeker. Right. Let's just say it's...complicated.

At first? She was *not* a fan. Not at all. She definitely thought I was a bad influence on Paulie. Like, a delinquent. A troublemaker. She gave me The Look. You know The Look. The one where they're trying to silently communicate their disapproval with just their eyes. It's terrifying.

She was all about Paulie focusing on school and getting into a good college. And, you know, I was…not exactly a model student. Plus, the whole pregnancy thing didn't exactly *help* my case. She was pretty horrified, to be honest. A lot of pointed silences and passive-aggressive comments about responsibility.

But things…shifted. After the baby was born, and she saw how much Paulie loved him, and how much *I* loved him, she started to come around. She still doesn't totally get me, and she still thinks I'm a little bit weird, but she's…accepting.

She actually helped me pick out a stroller once. A really fancy one. It was awkward, but…nice. And she brings over casseroles sometimes. Casseroles are a sign of acceptance, right?

She'll never be my best friend, and I'm okay with that. But she's stopped actively glaring at me, which is a major win. She's starting to see that I'm not just some reckless teenager. I'm a mom. And I'm trying my best.

So, yeah. It's a work in progress. But I think, deep down, she just wants what's best for Paulie and for the baby. And she's starting to realize that I'm not going anywhere.

Ugh. Don't even *ask*. It's… looming. Like a really big, awkward, potentially explosive cloud. I've been practicing what I'm gonna say in the mirror, but it always comes out sounding either super dramatic or totally dismissive. Neither of which is ideal.

Honestly, I'm mostly just terrified of disappointing them. My dad's pretty quiet, but he has these…expectations. And my mom? She's a force of nature. She's gonna have a *lot* of feelings. And opinions.

I keep going back and forth between wanting to just rip the band-aid off and wanting to wait until the very last possible second. Like, maybe I could just show up with a baby and be like, "Surprise!" But that feels…rude. And also, probably not the best way to start a conversation.

Paul's been really supportive, which is good. He's trying to be optimistic, but even *he* looks a little scared when I talk about it. 

I just… I don't want them to think I'm irresponsible or that I haven't thought this through. Because I have. Sort of. I mean, I'm giving the baby up for adoption, which is a responsible thing to do, right? But they might not see it that way.

It's just… a lot. I'm trying to be brave, but mostly I just feel like hiding under my covers with a box of Jujyfruits and pretending this isn't happening. But I know I can't avoid it forever. I just wish there was a manual for this kind of thing. Like, "Breaking Bad News to Your Parents: A Teenager's Guide." That would be helpful.



Okay, deep breaths. I'll get through it. I always do. But right now? I'm officially dreading the next 24 hours.

Ugh. Okay, so you wanna know why I don't exactly run to my parents when things get…complicated? It's not like they're *bad* people, okay? They're just…them.

It's mostly because they're kinda spacey. Like, well-meaning, but totally oblivious. My dad's always building stuff in the garage and my mom's obsessed with her pottery. They're good at making things with their hands, not so good at, like, *feelings*.

If I told them I was pregnant, I just know they'd freak out. My dad would probably try to build a baby-sized robot to take care of it, and my mom would want to knit it a whole wardrobe. It wouldn't be a supportive, "Let's figure this out together" kind of freak out. It would be a…weird, overwhelming, unhelpful freak out.

And honestly, I don't want their pity. I don't want them to treat me like a little kid who can't handle things. I'm trying to be responsible, to make a good decision, and I want to do it on my own terms.

Plus, they're always trying to live vicariously through me. Like, they want me to be this perfect, overachieving kid. And this…this isn't exactly fitting into their plan.

So yeah, I keep things to myself. It's easier. It's safer. It doesn't mean I don't love them. It just means I need to figure some things out on my own. And maybe, eventually, I'll tell them. But not yet. Not until I'm ready.

It's just…complicated, okay? Don't judge.

Ugh, okay. This is…a lot to unpack. It's not like I *wanted* this to happen, you know? It's not like I was planning on having a baby with Paulie Bleeker. But it *did* happen. And now I gotta figure things out.

And honestly? Adoption feels like the best option. For everyone.

Look, I'm seventeen. Seventeen! I'm still figuring out what *I* want to do with my life. I'm not ready to be a mom right now. I'm barely ready to be a functional human being, let's be real. I have college applications to fill out, and I wanna go to art school. I wanna travel. I wanna…just be me for a little while longer.

And it's not that I don't think I *could* be a good mom. It's just…not right now. This baby deserves parents who are ready, who are stable, who have a house and a plan and, like, actual grown-up money. 

Mark and Vanessa? They're amazing. They've been trying to have a baby for years. They're so excited. They have a beautiful home, and they're just…good people. They'll give this baby a life I can't give it right now. A life full of love and opportunity.

It's not about me not wanting the baby. It's about wanting the baby to have the best possible life. And I think that's with Mark and Vanessa.

It's hard, okay? It's really hard. It's not like I'm just giving it away. It's…it's choosing the best thing for the baby. And that's what matters.

And honestly? It feels…right. It feels like the grown-up thing to do. Even if I don't always feel like a grown-up.

So yeah. That's why. It's not easy, but it's the best option. For everyone. And I gotta believe that.

Ugh, okay, this is…a big deal. It's not like picking out a new pair of shoes, you know? This is a *person's* life we're talking about. So, yeah, I have a list. It's not a super long list, but it's important.

First off, they gotta be…stable. Like, financially stable, emotionally stable. I don't need a mansion or anything, but I want to know the kid's gonna have a roof over their head and food on the table. And I don't want them to be, like, constantly fighting or falling apart. That's just…no.

Second, they need to be open-minded. This kid is gonna have a story. A real story. And I want them to be okay with that. I want them to be willing to talk about it, to answer questions, to not pretend it didn't happen.

Third, they gotta be funny. Seriously. Life is hard. You need to be able to laugh. And I want this kid to grow up in a house where there's laughter.

Fourth, they need to be…patient. Kids are messy and loud and annoying sometimes. And I want someone who can handle that without losing their mind.

And finally, and this is the most important thing, they need to be kind. Just…genuinely kind. To everyone. Not just to the kid, but to strangers, to animals, to people they disagree with. Kindness is everything.

I don't need perfect. Nobody's perfect. But I need someone who's willing to put in the effort, to love this kid unconditionally, and to give them a good life. That's all I want. It's not asking for much, is it?

Ugh. This is stressful. I need a snack.

Ugh. Okay. That's…the big one, right? Everyone keeps asking me about the *feelings*. Like it's some kind of easy thing to just…deal with. It's not. It's gonna be messy.

Honestly? I don't have a plan. Not a perfect one, anyway. I'm just trying to take it one day at a time. But I've been thinking about it. A lot.

First, I'm gonna let myself *feel* stuff. Like, all of it. Sadness, happiness, fear, regret…whatever comes up. I'm not gonna try to bottle it up or pretend I'm okay when I'm not. That's what my dad does, and it doesn't work.

Second, I'm talking to a counselor. It's…awkward. But she's pretty cool, and she doesn't judge. She just listens. And she's helping me figure out how to process everything.

Third, I'm focusing on the good. I'm choosing Mark and Vanessa because they're amazing people. They're gonna give this baby a life I can't. A stable, loving home. And that's what matters most. It doesn't make it easier, but it makes it…right.

I'm also trying to remember that this isn't about *giving up* something. It's about *giving* something. Giving this baby the best possible chance.

I know it's gonna be hard. I know there will be days when I just want to curl up in a ball and cry. But I'm gonna have my friends and family to lean on. And I'm gonna try to focus on my own life, on school, on my future.

It's not gonna be a clean break. I'm gonna want to know how the baby is doing. Mark and Vanessa are open to that, which is good. We're gonna have an open adoption, so I can get updates and maybe even see the baby sometimes.

It's scary. It's complicated. But I'm trying to be brave. And I'm trying to do what's best for everyone involved. Even if it means breaking my own heart a little bit.

It's just…a lot. Okay? A lot.

Ugh, okay, you wanna talk about "deliver"? Seriously? It's just...a weird word. It feels so…clinical. Like I'm a pizza or something. "We'll deliver the baby." Like it's a package.

It's not a package! It's a person. A tiny human being. And I'm carrying it, not *delivering* it. It feels so impersonal and…transactional. Like I'm just a vessel.

I mean, I get what people are trying to say. It's a shorthand for "give birth." But it just rubs me the wrong way. It feels like it minimizes the whole experience. It's not a delivery, it's…creation. Or, you know, growing a person inside your body for nine months. It's a big deal.

And it's not like I ordered it online. It just…happened. And now I'm making a choice about it. It's not a delivery, it's a decision.

So yeah, I find the term "deliver" weird. It just feels…wrong. It's a little bit creepy, honestly. And I'm already dealing with enough creepiness, thank you very much.

Ugh. Okay, so, the whole dad-coming-with-me thing? Not my idea. Not even remotely. It was a compromise. A really, really annoying compromise.

Look, I needed him to sign the papers, right? He's my dad. Legally. And I wasn't about to go through all that with just Mark and Vanessa, who were already kinda overwhelming. I needed a buffer. Someone who could, like, translate the adult stuff.

But I also didn't want him *involved*. You know? It's my baby. My decision. And he's…well, he's my dad. He means well, but he's kinda clueless sometimes. And he gets all emotional. It's exhausting.

So, I made him promise. I made him promise he wouldn't say anything stupid, or try to change my mind, or just generally make things awkward. And he promised. Of course, he didn't exactly *keep* that promise. But I figured having him there was better than having him not there at all.

Plus, I kinda felt bad for him. He was trying. He was actually trying to be supportive, in his own weird, dad-like way. And I guess I figured he deserved to be part of it, even if it was just for the paperwork.

It was a disaster, obviously. But it was a necessary disaster. You know? Sometimes you just gotta suck it up and deal with the awkwardness. It's life.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. And honestly? It kinda sucks. It's like, everyone else seems to have it all figured out. They're cheerleaders or band geeks or future lawyers or whatever. They have labels. And I'm just…me. Which apparently isn't a category.

It's not that I *want* a label, exactly. I don't wanna be put in a box. But it's weird to just…float. Like, people try to figure you out, and they always get it wrong. They see the Converse and the sarcastic comments and they think I'm some kind of cynical rebel. Or they see me hanging out with Paulie and they think I'm…I don't even know.

It's just…confusing. I don't know what I like, or what I'm good at, or what I want to do with my life. I mean, I like music. And I'm okay at drawing. But that doesn't exactly scream "future career path," you know?

And then being pregnant…that just throws everything into even more chaos. It's like, now I have to be a *mother*. And I don't even know if I'm a good person, let alone a good mother.

I guess what I'm trying to say is, it's scary not knowing who you are. It's like being lost in a maze with no map. But maybe…maybe that's okay. Maybe it's okay to not have all the answers. Maybe it's okay to just be…a work in progress.

It's just…it's hard. And sometimes I wish I could just fast-forward to the part where I figure it all out. But I guess that's not how life works. You just gotta keep going, and hope you stumble onto something that feels right.

So yeah. I don't know what kind of girl I am. And honestly? I'm kinda okay with that. For now. It's just…a lot.

Ugh. Seriously? That was…a moment. It wasn't like Bren was trying to be mean, exactly. She's just…Bren. Always trying to smooth things over, always trying to make everything *nice*. Which, honestly, is the opposite of helpful when things are already a disaster.

When she said that, about Leah and me going upstairs, I just…stared at her. Like, a long, slow stare. It wasn't about wanting to avoid Dad's tension, it was about the fact that she thought that was a *solution*. Like, "Oh, just hide the problem away and it'll go away!"

I think I said something sarcastic, probably. Something like, "Oh, good idea, Bren. Let's just pretend everything's fine and go play with dolls." I'm pretty sure Leah rolled her eyes. She gets it.

It wasn't just about the tension, it was about the whole situation. Dad was being weird, Bren was being Bren, and I was pregnant. It was a lot. And her suggestion just felt…dismissive. Like she didn't want to deal with the messiness of it all.

I didn't actually go upstairs, though. I mean, I didn't want to just *leave* Dad hanging there. Even if he was being a total weirdo. So I just stood there, awkwardly, until he said something. It was a really uncomfortable silence.

Honestly, it was one of those moments where I just wanted to disappear. Like, poof, vanish into thin air. But you can't really do that when you're, you know, visibly pregnant. It's a real buzzkill for the disappearing act.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a lot to think about. It's not something I really considered at first, you know? Like, I figured I'd just…give the baby up and that would be that. Clean break. Easier.

But then Paul and Mark started talking about it, about how maybe the baby's parents would want to send pictures, updates…and it kinda freaked me out.

At first, I was like, "No way! That's just gonna make it harder!" Like, seeing the baby grow up with someone else, knowing they're having all these firsts without me…it felt like a constant reminder of what I gave up. And honestly, a little bit scary. What if I got attached all over again?

But then I started thinking about the baby. And how maybe, knowing where they came from, knowing I thought about them, would be a good thing. Like, they wouldn't feel…lost. Or unwanted.

It's still weird, though. It's not like a normal family situation. It's…complicated. And I'm not sure I'm ready for that kind of complication. I mean, I'm barely ready for *this* complication, you know?

I guess…I think it could be okay. If the parents are good people. And if they understand that I need space, too. It's not about being a part of their family, it's about making sure the baby knows they were wanted. And loved. Even if I couldn't be the one to raise them.

It's just…a lot to process. It's not something you think about when you're, like, staring at a positive pregnancy test in a bathroom stall. It's a whole other level of…everything.

So, yeah. I'm cautiously optimistic. But also terrified. It's a really weird feeling.

Ugh. Okay, that moment. Yeah. That was…not good. It wasn't like a dramatic, crying-on-the-floor kind of thing, because I don't really *do* dramatic. But it was…cold. Like, a really cold splash of water to the face.

I mean, I knew it was an open adoption, and I knew I'd get to see the baby and stuff. But to hear her just…lay it out like that? Like my rights were just gonna *poof* disappear? It felt…dismissive. Like I was just a vessel. A temporary holding place.

It wasn't about wanting to keep the baby, exactly. It was about…agency. About having a say. About not being treated like I was just…convenient.

I remember just staring at her, trying to process it. And then I think I made some sarcastic comment, because that's what I do when I'm uncomfortable. It's a defense mechanism.

It made me realize how complicated this whole thing was. It wasn't just about finding a good home for the baby. It was about legal stuff, and feelings, and…everything.

It was a really unsettling moment. It made me question everything, and it made me realize that I needed to be really careful about who I chose to adopt the baby. It had to be people who understood that I wasn't just…getting rid of something. I was making a really hard decision, and I deserved to be treated with respect.

Yeah. That was a bad moment. A really bad moment.

Ugh. Okay, Vanessa. That's…a lot. Look, I get it, kinda. Wanting a kid, wanting a family, it's a big thing. It's what everyone expects, right? But the way she's going about it? It's intense. Like, seriously intense.

It's not that I think she's a bad person or anything. She's…nice. A little clueless, maybe. But she's got this whole plan, this perfect picture in her head of what motherhood should be, and it's just…not realistic. It's like she thinks a baby is a accessory, you know? Something to complete her life.

And the way she's so focused on *having* a baby, not necessarily *raising* one? That's what gets me. It's not just about the cute outfits and the baby smell. It's about sleepless nights, and screaming, and poop explosions, and a tiny human being who needs you for everything. It's a lot of work.

I mean, I'm in a weird situation, obviously. I'm giving a baby up, but I'm still thinking about it, still feeling things. And I want someone who's gonna be a *real* mom, someone who's gonna love this kid unconditionally, even when it's hard.

Vanessa seems like she wants the *idea* of a mom, not to actually *be* a mom. And that's just…not good enough.

It's just…it's a lot to process. And honestly, it makes me feel a little weird about the whole thing. Like, is she even thinking about what this kid will actually *need*? Or is she just thinking about what *she* wants?

Ugh. Don't even get me started. It's complicated. Everything is always complicated.

Ugh. Okay, so you want my take on Mark's whole "being a dad" thing? Honestly? It's…complicated.

He's sweet, don't get me wrong. And he's trying. He really is. But that whole "I'm just gonna be the fun uncle" routine? It's a cop-out. A really convenient cop-out.

Like, I get it. Being a parent is scary. It's a huge responsibility. And he's, you know, still figuring things out. But it's not about being "fun." It's about being *there*. It's about being reliable. It's about being a grown-up, even when you don't feel like one.

He says he doesn't want to mess things up, and that's…understandable. But avoiding the whole thing isn't gonna help. It's just gonna make things messier in the long run.

I mean, he's a good guy. He's got a good heart. But he needs to step up. He needs to realize that this isn't just about me, or about the baby. It's about building a family. And that takes work. And commitment.

It's frustrating, honestly. Because I need someone I can count on. And I want the baby to have a dad who's actually *present*. Not just someone who shows up for the fun parts.

So yeah. I think his response is…avoidant. And a little bit selfish. But I also think he's scared. And maybe, just maybe, he'll come around. I hope he does. For the baby's sake. And for mine.

It's just…ugh. Boys. They're so weird sometimes.

Ugh. Okay, so the Loring's house. It's…a lot. It's not like they're *bad* people, okay? They're just…intense. And really, really into things. Like, aggressively into things.

It's the whole vibe, you know? Everything is perfectly placed. Everything is beige. It's like walking into a Pottery Barn catalog. And they just *watch* you. Not in a creepy way, exactly. More like…observing. Like you're a science experiment.

And they talk. Oh, they talk. About everything. Their feelings, their marriage, their organic gardening techniques. It's exhausting. I mean, I appreciate a good conversation, but I also appreciate silence. And the Loring's don't *do* silence.

Plus, they're always trying to get me to talk about my feelings. Which, like, okay, I have feelings. But I'm not about to spill my life story to people I barely know. It's awkward.

So yeah, being left unsupervised there is uncomfortable. It feels like I'm being judged. Like I'm going to accidentally knock over a perfectly arranged vase and ruin their entire aesthetic. It's just…a lot of pressure. I'd rather hang out with Paul and just be…normal. You know?

It's not that I don't like them. It's just…their house is a lot. And I'm a lot. And sometimes, a lot plus a lot equals a disaster.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. It's not like something you just *answer*, you know? It's complicated.

Look, I'm not gonna lie. At first, it was just…a thing I had to deal with. A problem. A really big, life-altering problem. And I was mostly focused on getting through it, on figuring out what *I* wanted.

But then, getting to know Mark and Vanessa…they're good people. Really good. They're excited. They're ready. And they're gonna be amazing parents. Like, actually amazing. Not the helicopter-parent kind, but the supportive, loving, let-you-figure-things-out kind.

So, yeah, it feels…good. It feels like I'm doing something…right. Like I'm giving this little person a chance at a really good life. A life with people who will love them unconditionally.

It's still weird, though. It's my kid, but it's not *my* kid, you know? It's like…I'm a temporary vessel. And that's okay. It's a little sad, maybe, but it's okay.

I guess what I'm trying to say is…it's not just a "gift of life." It's a gift of a *good* life. And that feels…pretty awesome. It's a little scary, too. But mostly awesome.

And honestly? I'm kinda proud of myself for making this decision. It wasn't easy, but it feels like the right thing to do. For everyone. Even me.

Don't make me get all emotional, though. I'm not a crier. Usually.

Ugh, okay, you want to dissect that? Fine. It's not like I *planned* to be a jerk to Mark, but honestly, the "ASAP" thing just…got to me.

It wasn't even the "ASAP" itself, it was *how* he said it. Like, with this super intense, urgent tone, like the fate of the world depended on him getting a guitar pick *right now*. It was just…a lot.
