He was already trying so hard to be cool and mature, you know? Like, he was trying to be this serious musician guy, and then he throws out this super-dorky, corporate-sounding abbreviation. It just felt…incongruous.

And honestly, I was nervous. Like, *really* nervous. About everything. About the baby, about Paul, about the future. And sometimes, when I'm nervous, I deflect with sarcasm. It's a coping mechanism, okay?

So, yeah, I made a snarky comment about "ASAP." It was probably mean, and I probably shouldn't have said it. But in the moment, it just felt…necessary. It was a way to break the tension, I guess. Or maybe just a way to feel like I had some control over the situation.

Don't judge me too harshly. I was a mess. And Mark, bless his heart, was just trying to be helpful. He's a good guy. He just…uses a lot of corporate jargon. It's weird.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna know about guitars? Honestly, I don't *play* guitar. I mean, I tried, for like, a week. Turns out my fingers aren't really built for delicate fingerpicking. They're better suited for, like, aggressively eating tater tots.

But Paul, you know, my baby daddy? He's a musician. And he's always going on about guitars. So I've absorbed some information through osmosis, I guess.

If I *were* to pick a brand, though, based on what I've overheard and observed...it'd have to be **Fender**. Specifically, a Fender Telecaster.

Why? Because they're kinda…unpretentious. They're not all flashy and showy like some of those other guitars. They're just solid, reliable, and they get the job done. They're the workhorse of guitars, you know? They've been around forever, and they're still good.

Plus, they're the kind of guitar you can beat up a little and they'll still sound good. Which, honestly, is a quality I appreciate. I'm not really into things that are too delicate.

Paul has a Telecaster, and he says it's the only guitar he needs. And he's a pretty good judge of guitars, I guess. So yeah. Fender Telecaster. It's a good, solid choice. Not too fancy, not too complicated. Just…real.

And honestly, it kinda reminds me of him. Which is…weird to say, I guess. Don't tell him I said that.

Ugh. Okay, fine. You wanna talk about the Melvins? Seriously? This is embarrassing.

Look, it just…happened, okay? It wasn't like a *calculated* lie. It was more of a…social lubrication thing. Paul was being all cool and talking about how much he loved them, and I just…panicked. I didn't want him to think I was a total square.

I mean, who *doesn't* want to seem cool in front of the guy they're, like, maybe kinda falling for? It was a moment of weakness. A desperate attempt to impress him.

I'd heard of them, obviously. Everyone in our school has, they're kinda legendary. But I hadn't actually *listened* to them. I just…pretended I had. I threw out some vague stuff about their early albums and hoped he wouldn't call me out on it.

And then it just spiraled. I kept digging myself deeper and deeper. It was a terrible idea. A really, really terrible idea.

It wasn't about the Melvins, really. It was about wanting Paul to like me. It was about being someone I wasn't. And it was stupid.

I eventually fessed up, obviously. He was…surprisingly chill about it. He said he liked me for who I was, even if I didn't know my obscure indie rock bands. Which was…nice.

But still. It was a dumb thing to do. And I still cringe when I think about it. Don't judge me too harshly, okay? Everyone makes mistakes. Especially when hormones are involved.

Ugh. Okay, so, Mark. Right. Describing that is…complicated. It wasn't like, a grand, sweeping romance or anything. It wasn't a movie. It was… quieter than that.

When we were playing music together, though? That was different. It was the only time I felt like I could actually *breathe*, you know? Like, everything else – the pregnancy, the parents, the whole mess – just kinda faded away.

It wasn't about, like, looking at each other and having some big emotional moment. It was more about…knowing what the other person was going to do before they did it. Like, we just *clicked*. He'd start a chord progression, and I'd just instinctively know what melody to play. It was kinda spooky, actually.

And singing? That was even weirder. It felt…safe. Like, I could be completely honest and vulnerable without feeling totally exposed. He didn't judge my lyrics, even when they were, like, super angsty and awkward. He just…understood.

It wasn't romantic, not exactly. It was more like…a really deep friendship. A connection that went beyond words. It was the only time I felt like I wasn't completely alone in all the craziness.

It was…nice. Really nice. And I miss it. Don't tell him I said that. It'd ruin everything. Ugh. This is why I avoid talking about feelings. It's exhausting.

Ugh, okay, seriously? People *still* ask about Roosevelt. It's a long story. And kinda embarrassing, honestly.

Well, my dad…he's a bit of a history buff. And he's always going on about Franklin Delano Roosevelt, how he was a good president and all that. He thinks FDR saved the country. I don't really get it, but whatever.

Anyway, I found this old guitar at a pawn shop. It was kinda beat up, but it had a good sound. And my dad, he just immediately said, "That guitar looks like a Roosevelt."

I was like, "What?"

And he was all, "You know, strong, dependable, a little bit rough around the edges, but gets the job done."

It was so cheesy, I almost didn't buy it. But it was a good price, and I needed a guitar. So I got it. And my dad just kept calling it Roosevelt. And it stuck.

It's kinda ironic, I guess. Because FDR was all about order and stability, and I'm…not. But I like the name. It's a little bit quirky, a little bit unexpected. And it reminds me of my dad, even when he's being totally annoying.

So yeah, that's why my guitar is named Roosevelt. Don't judge me. It's a good guitar. And it has a good name. Okay?

Ugh. Okay, so the whole Vanessa and Mark thing. It's…complicated. It's not like I *want* to keep them in the dark, you know? They're good people. They're my friends. But it's *my* pregnancy. And it feels weird to have to constantly report back to them like I'm some kind of science project.

It's not that I don't appreciate their support, because I do. It's just…they're so *invested*. Like, they're already picking out names and decorating the nursery in their heads. And I'm still trying to figure out if I even *want* to keep the baby, let alone deal with all the baby stuff.

I get that they want to be involved, but it feels like they're trying to take over. Like they think they know what's best for me and the baby. And honestly, it's a little suffocating.

I mean, I told them I was pregnant, and I'll tell them when I make a decision about the adoption. But I don't need a constant stream of "How are you feeling?" and "Have you thought about…?" It's my body, my choice, and my life.

I just wish they'd give me a little space. Let me figure things out on my own. It's hard enough as it is without feeling like I'm being monitored.

It's not that I don't like them. It's just…they're a lot. And sometimes, a girl just needs to be left alone to deal with her own mess. You know?

(Sighs, fiddles with a friendship bracelet)

Okay, look. People keep asking me that. Like it's some kinda easy decision. It's not. It's the hardest thing I've ever had to think about. But it's…it's the *right* thing. And I'm, like, 104% sure because I've thought about it every single way possible.

It's not about not wanting the baby, okay? It's about wanting the baby to have everything. A real home. Parents who are, like, actually ready for this. A life where they don't have to worry about, you know, me being me.

I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out what *I* want to do with my life. I'm not ready to be a mom right now. I can barely keep my grades up and remember to feed the cat. Adding a baby into that mix? It'd be a disaster. For everyone.

And it's not just about me. It's about the baby. They deserve parents who can give them everything they need. Mark and Vanessa…they're amazing. They've been wanting this for so long. They're gonna be great parents.

I know it's gonna be hard. Saying goodbye. It's gonna suck. But knowing that the baby is going to a good home, with people who love them and can provide for them…that makes it a little bit easier.

So yeah, I'm 104% sure. Not because it's easy, but because it's the most selfless thing I can do. And sometimes, you gotta do the selfless thing, even when it breaks your heart a little.

(Looks down, picks at the bracelet)

Don't tell anyone I said that last part. It's kinda embarrassing.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a complicated question. It wasn't like I was expecting a parade or anything, but seeing them all…*happy* right after I handed over the baby? It was weird. Really weird.

It wasn't that I didn't *want* them to be happy, you know? They were good people. They were gonna be amazing parents. But it felt…fast. Like they were already celebrating a future that I wasn't a part of. And it was kinda like, "Okay, mission accomplished, now we can move on."

I mean, I knew that was the point. I *wanted* them to be happy. But it still stung a little. It was like, all that…everything…was just a transaction to them. A thing to be checked off a list.

I tried to just be cool about it. I gave them a little wave and walked out. I didn't want to ruin their moment. But inside, I was kinda…numb. And a little bit sad.

It wasn't about wanting them to be miserable. It was about wanting them to acknowledge that it wasn't just a happy ending for *them*. It was a big deal for *me* too. And it was gonna take me a while to process.

I guess it just felt…insensitive. But then again, they were probably just relieved. And maybe I was overthinking it. I do that a lot.

It's just…it was a weird feeling. A mix of happiness for them and sadness for myself. And a whole lot of awkwardness.

Ugh. Seriously? People just…can’t mind their own business, can they? It’s like, everyone suddenly has an opinion on *my* life. It’s really irritating.

Look, it’s…complicated, okay? It’s not exactly a situation I planned for, and it’s definitely not something I was shouting from the rooftops. But it’s *my* situation, and I’m dealing with it. And I’m dealing with it the way *I* want to deal with it.

The rumors? They’re mostly wrong. Or, like, half-right and totally blown out of proportion. People are making up stories, and it’s just…exhausting. It’s hard enough figuring things out without everyone else weighing in.

I’m not trying to hide anything, exactly. I just…need space, you know? To think. To figure out what I want. To not have a bunch of strangers judging me.

It’s weird being the subject of gossip. It’s like, I’m just a normal person, trying to navigate a really weird situation. And I’m doing the best I can.

So, yeah. The rumors are annoying. And invasive. And frankly, none of anyone’s business. I’d appreciate it if people would just…back off. Let me figure things out on my own. Is that too much to ask?

Honestly, I just want to finish my English paper and eat a peanut butter and jelly sandwich in peace. Is that so wrong?

Ugh. Okay. Don't make me think about it too hard, alright? It's...complicated. It's not like deciding what flavor ice cream to get, you know?

Honestly? It sucks. It really, really sucks. It's like...having this little secret, this little person growing inside you, and knowing you're not gonna get to keep them. It's weirdly heartbreaking, even though I know it's the right thing to do.

I mean, I'm sixteen. I'm not ready to be a mom. I'm barely ready to be a *person*, let alone responsible for another human being. And Paul...well, Paul's a good guy, but he's sixteen too. We're kids.

So, yeah, it's scary. It's sad. It's gonna be really hard. But it's also...kind of a relief? Knowing that there are people out there, Mark and Vanessa, who are actually prepared to give this baby a good life. A stable life. A life I just can't provide right now.

I keep trying to tell myself that it's not giving up, it's...giving *to*. Giving this baby a chance at a better future. But it still feels like a huge loss.

I just hope...I hope they'll be happy. And I hope they'll understand that I did this because I loved them, even before I met them.

It's just...a lot. Don't ask me to think about it too much, okay? It makes my stomach hurt. I need to go listen to The Moldy Peaches and try to forget about everything for a while.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna know about the whole baby sex reveal thing? Honestly? It's kinda complicated. It's not like I *wanted* to surprise them, exactly. It's more like...I didn't want them to have any expectations.

See, Mark and Vanessa are...well, they're *Mark and Vanessa*. They have this whole plan for everything. The nursery, the clothes, the name...it's all meticulously planned. And that's fine, I guess. But it felt...weird to me. Like they were already treating the baby like a project, instead of a person.

I just wanted them to have a moment where they didn't know. Where they had to react to the actual baby, not to an idea of a baby. A little bit of surprise, a little bit of uncertainty. It felt more...real.

Plus, I figured it would be kinda funny. They're so serious, you know? I wanted to see their faces when they found out. It's not like I'm trying to mess with them, I just...wanted to shake things up a little.

It's not about the sex of the baby, it's about them being present in the moment. It's about them actually *seeing* the baby for who they are, not who they thought they were going to be.

Does that make sense? It's hard to explain. I'm not good at explaining feelings. I'm better at making sarcastic comments. But yeah. That's why.

Ugh. Seriously? That lady. Okay, deep breaths. It was…infuriating. And not just because she was being judgy, but because it was so *wrong*. Like, she hadn't even met me. She didn't know anything about my life, or Mark's, or what we were planning.

It wasn't like we were just, you know, messing around and suddenly surprised with a baby. We put a lot of thought into this. A *lot*. And it wasn't about giving up a baby, it was about giving a baby the best life possible. A life we couldn't give it right now.

She just…assumed. Assumed we were irresponsible, that we hadn't thought things through, that we were just trying to get rid of something. It felt like she was looking *through* me, not *at* me. Like I was just a statistic, a stereotype.

It made me want to yell, honestly. But I mostly just stared at the screen, trying not to cry. It was supposed to be a happy moment, seeing the little bean on the screen, and she just…tainted it.

Mark was really good, though. He squeezed my hand and gave her this look that could kill. He's good at that.

It just…reinforced how much judgment there is around teenage pregnancy and adoption. Like people think they have the right to tell you what to do with your life. It's your body, your decision. And it's way more complicated than people think.

It made me even more determined to do things the right way, to find the perfect parents for this baby, and to prove her wrong. It was a really crappy experience, though. Just…really crappy.

Ugh, okay, where do I even *start*? It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It wasn't like in the movies where everything just neatly resolves itself. It was messy. Really messy.

The biggest challenge, honestly, was just…dealing with everyone else's opinions. Like, suddenly *everyone* had something to say about my body and my life. My parents were…well, they were my parents. They freaked out, obviously. My dad just kept offering to buy me a car, like that would magically fix everything. And my mom was all about the adoption pamphlets and the "right thing to do." It was suffocating.

Then there was Paulie Bleeker. Sweet, clueless Paulie. He was supportive, in his own way, but he didn't really *get* it. It was hard to explain something that I barely understood myself. And I felt bad, you know? Like I was ruining his life too.

And then there were the people at school. The whispers, the stares…it was awful. I just wanted to disappear. I mean, I'm already kinda awkward and sarcastic, and suddenly I'm *pregnant*? It was a recipe for disaster.

Finding the right couple for the baby was…intense. It wasn't like shopping for a new pair of shoes. It was a human being. And I wanted the best for them, and for the baby. Mark and Vanessa were great, but it was still hard to let go. It felt like giving up a piece of myself.

And then there was just the emotional stuff. The hormones, the uncertainty, the fear…it was a lot to handle. I was still a kid, you know? I was supposed to be worrying about college applications and band practice, not about becoming a mom.

It was a lot. But I got through it. And I learned a lot about myself, and about what's really important in life. It wasn't easy, but it was…worth it. I think. Mostly. Don't tell anyone I said that.

Ugh. Okay, deep thoughts time. Don't judge. It's not like I *wanted* to spend all this time thinking about feelings and stuff. But yeah, this whole…situation…has kinda flipped my world upside down.

Love…before all this, I thought it was just, like, whatever. Something people in movies did. Or something my parents awkwardly talked about. Now? It's…complicated. It's not just about butterflies and holding hands. It's about wanting someone to be happy, even if it means letting them go. It's about being there for someone, even when it's hard. Paul…he wasn't the dad, but he was…good. He showed me that love isn't always perfect, but it can still be real. And it can still be enough.

Responsibility? Oh god. That one hit me like a ton of bricks. I was just trying to get through high school, listen to The Moldy Peaches, and avoid drama. And then suddenly, I was responsible for another human being. It was terrifying. It made me realize that actions have consequences, and that you can't just drift through life anymore. You have to actually *think* about things. And make choices. Hard choices. It's not about being a kid anymore. It's about being a grown-up, even if you don't feel like one.

And growing up…well, that's been the biggest change. I used to think growing up meant getting a driver's license and going to college. Now I know it's about figuring out who you are, what you believe in, and what you're willing to fight for. It's about accepting that life isn't always fair, and that you have to make the best of it. It's about realizing that you're not alone, and that there are people who care about you, even when you're being a total mess.

I still don't have all the answers. I'm still figuring things out. But I'm not the same person I was before. I'm…stronger, I guess. And maybe a little bit wiser. And definitely more prepared for whatever life throws at me. Even if it's a baby.

It's still weird to think about. But it's my weird. And I'm okay with that. Mostly.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're asking about *that* house? It's…complicated. It's not like I'm obsessed or anything. It's just…interesting.

Look, it's this perfectly preserved 1970s living room. Like, avocado green shag carpet, orange floral wallpaper, everything. It's like stepping into a time capsule. And it's just…sitting there. Abandoned. Like someone just got up and walked away.

It makes you wonder, you know? What happened there? Who lived there? What were their lives like? It's kinda sad, but also kinda fascinating.

Paul thinks I'm being weird about it. He says I'm projecting. Which, okay, maybe I am. But it's not about *me*. It's about the story. The story that's just…hanging in the air in that room.

It feels…familiar, somehow. Like a memory I don't have. And I'm trying to figure out why.

Plus, it's a good place to think. It's quiet. And no one bothers you. Which is nice, considering everything that's going on with…well, everything.

So, yeah. I'm interested in the abandoned living room set on Centennial Lane. Don't judge me. It's just…a thing. A weird, slightly unsettling, but ultimately intriguing thing. And honestly, it's probably less weird than some of the other things I've been dealing with lately.

Ugh. Don't even *get* me started on the Wizard. That guy was…creepy. Seriously. And that whisper? "Do you know how long I've wanted this?" It wasn't about the baby, okay? It wasn't some sweet, paternal longing. It was…possessive.

He didn't want a child. He wanted *control*. He wanted a perfect little family, a perfect little life, and he thought he could just…take it. He'd been watching Mark and me, planning, waiting for the right moment to swoop in and manipulate things.

He'd been building this whole fantasy in his head, this idea of being a dad, of having a "normal" life. And he saw me, a pregnant teenager, as a way to finally achieve that. He didn't care about me, or the baby, or Mark. He just wanted to fulfill his own selfish desires.

It was disgusting. And honestly, it was terrifying. It made me realize how dangerous he was, and how important it was to get away from him.

He'd been wanting to be a dad for a long time, sure. But it wasn't a healthy wanting. It was a creepy, controlling, obsessive wanting. And that's what made it so unsettling.

It still gives me the shivers just thinking about it. That guy…he was seriously messed up.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're dissecting my life choices now? Fine. Look, it wasn't exactly a *thought-out* plan, alright? It was a moment. A very specific, emotionally-charged moment.

First of all, the juice was a symbol. A symbol of…everything. Of being pregnant, of feeling gross, of having to deal with all this stuff. So, yeah, I dramatically threw the container in the trash. It felt good. Cathartic, even.

But then, like, immediately after, I realized I was craving a cherry chocolate chip ice cream bar. A *very* specific craving. And Dancing Elk Drug is the only place within a reasonable walking distance that sells them. It's a whole thing. They're amazing.

It wasn't about needing medicine or anything. It was about needing sugar and chocolate and a brief moment of normalcy in the middle of a completely insane situation. 

And honestly, marching down the street helped work up an appetite. Don't judge me. Pregnancy cravings are a powerful force. It's science. Or something.

It was a bad decision, probably. But it felt right in the moment. And sometimes, you just gotta have a cherry chocolate chip ice cream bar, you know? Even if you're, like, eight months pregnant and trying to figure out your life.

Ugh. Seriously? You want to talk about *that*? Okay, fine. But it's still mortifying.

It was just…so random. And aggressive. I was at the drugstore with Paul, getting, like, prenatal vitamins and stuff, and this girl – she was seriously built, like a linebacker – just walked right up to me and asked, in this really loud voice, if my nipples were real brown.

I was completely stunned. I just stared at her. I mean, what do you even *say* to that? It's not a normal question! It's not polite! It's just…weird.

I think I mumbled something about it not being anyone's business, and she just laughed and walked away. It was so awkward. Paul was trying not to laugh, which made it even worse.

I guess she was trying to be, like, edgy or something? Or maybe she was just genuinely curious? I don't know. People are strange.

It just felt really objectifying, you know? Like I was just a body to be examined. And I was pregnant! It was just…a really bad moment.

I still think about it sometimes. It's one of those things that just sticks with you. It's a reminder that people can be really rude and intrusive. And that sometimes, you just have to deal with it and try to move on.

But yeah. That happened. And it was super awkward. Don't even get me started.

Ugh, okay, so Leah. She was…essential. Honestly, if it wasn't for Leah, I probably would have just run away to Canada or something. Seriously.

Before everything happened with Paul, Leah was just…Leah. My best friend since forever. We bonded over music, hating gym class, and making fun of everyone else. She was the one person who always got me, you know? She didn't try to fix me or tell me what to do. She just *listened*.

When I found out I was pregnant, I told her first. And she didn't freak out. She didn't judge. She just…was there. She didn't try to tell me what to do, which was good, because I had *no* idea what to do. She just asked what *I* wanted.

She was the one who went with me to the clinic. She held my hand during the ultrasound, even though she was probably just as freaked out as I was. She helped me research adoption agencies and figure out what my options were. 

And she was the one who kept me sane when I was being a total mess. I mean, I was a mess. I was angry, scared, confused…all the time. And Leah just let me vent. She let me cry. She let me be a total disaster. And she still loved me.

She was also the one who kept me grounded when I was getting all caught up in the whole "perfect adoptive parents" thing. She reminded me that it wasn't about finding the *best* parents, it was about finding the *right* parents for the baby.

Honestly, I don't know how I would have gotten through it without her. She was my rock. She was my sanity. She was the one person who made me feel like I wasn't completely alone.

It wasn't always easy. We had some fights, because, you know, that's what best friends do. But even when we were fighting, I knew she was always there for me.

She's the best. Seriously. Don't tell her I said that, though. It'll go to her head.

Ugh, okay, that's a good question. People always ask about that. It wasn't, like, some grand plan, you know? It wasn't about trying to make them feel guilty or anything. It was…complicated.

Honestly, it kinda just *happened*. I was at their house, and they were being all…perfect. Like, the perfect couple, the perfect life. And it was just…suffocating. They were talking about baby names and nursery colors, and it was like they were already picking out outfits for a kid that wasn't even a real person to them yet.

And I just…I wanted them to *see*. I wanted them to see that this wasn't just some abstract idea. This was a real, living thing. A tiny human being. And it was my tiny human being.

I figured if they actually *saw* it, if they saw the ultrasound picture, maybe they'd understand. Maybe they'd realize that this wasn't just about them anymore. It wasn't about their perfect life. It was about a baby.

It was a stupid, impulsive thing to do, I know. And it definitely didn't go the way I expected. But I needed them to understand. I needed them to see what I was going through.

It wasn't about making them feel bad. It was about making them *realize*. And, I guess, it kinda worked. Eventually. It was messy, and awkward, and totally stressful, but it got them to actually listen. And that's all I really wanted.

Ugh. Okay, so Mark tells me Vanessa isn't home? My initial reaction wasn't, like, a dramatic gasp or anything. It was more of a…slow burn of dread. Like, a cold feeling creeping up my spine.

I think I just kinda stared at him for a beat too long. Probably with a really skeptical look on my face. Because, honestly, it didn't *feel* right. He was being weirdly casual about it. Too casual.

I remember thinking, "Okay, this is officially a disaster." Not in a "oh no, the world is ending" kind of way, but in a "my life is about to get a whole lot more complicated" kind of way.

I think I said something sarcastic, probably. Like, "Oh, really? That's…convenient." Or maybe just a really pointed, "Huh." I'm good at the pointed "huh."

It wasn't the fact that she wasn't home, it was *how* he told me. It was the way he avoided eye contact. It was the way he seemed…relieved, almost. 

It was the first real crack in the whole "perfect boyfriend" facade, and I knew, right then and there, that things were about to get seriously messy. And honestly? A little bit terrifying. Because I was already in way over my head, and I didn't even know the half of it yet.

Ugh, okay, you want me to dissect my own sarcasm? Fine. It's not like I *enjoy* reliving awkward moments.

Look, it wasn't about Mark being a "sellout" in a mean way, okay? It was…complicated. He was all excited about doing those commercials, and it just felt…different. Like, he was suddenly trying to be something he wasn't.

He's a musician, right? He's supposed to be all artistic and authentic. And then he's selling, like, car wax or something? It just felt…incongruous. Like he was compromising his integrity for a paycheck.

And honestly, it was a little bit of me being defensive. I was already feeling weird about everything – the pregnancy, the adoption, the whole situation with Paul. And seeing Mark, someone I thought was…genuine, suddenly embracing commercialism, it just felt like another sign that everyone was changing and growing up and leaving me behind.

It was a stupid joke, I admit. I say a lot of stupid jokes. It's how I cope. But it came from a place of feeling lost and a little bit scared. And maybe a little bit of jealousy that he seemed to have it all figured out while I was just…trying to survive.

So yeah, it was a jab. A sarcastic, slightly passive-aggressive jab. Don't judge me. I was a pregnant teenager. I wasn't exactly known for my tact.

Ugh. Okay, don't even get me started on Mark and the ultrasound. It was…a lot. Honestly? It made me feel…small. Like, really small.

I mean, I knew he wasn't exactly thrilled about the whole situation, but I thought he'd at least try to be supportive, you know? Like, "Oh wow, a little person! That's…something." But no. He just…froze. And then he ran.

It wasn't the running that bothered me the most, it was the *look* on his face. It was pure panic. Like I'd sprung a leak or something. Like I was some kind of alien creature.

I was already feeling super vulnerable and weird about everything, and that just…confirmed all my worst fears. That he didn't want this. That he didn't want *me* and this baby.

I tried to play it cool, you know? Like, "Oh, he's just processing." But inside, I was a mess. It made me question everything. Was I making a mistake? Was I ruining his life?

It wasn't about the baby, not really. It was about him not being ready. And it made me realize that maybe we weren't ready either.

It was a really crappy moment. And it definitely made me start thinking about things a little differently. Like, maybe I didn't need him to be happy. Maybe I could do this on my own.

Ugh. Just thinking about it makes me want to eat a whole box of Nerds. It was just…a really bad day.

Ugh. Okay. That's...a heavy question. And it's not something I talk about a lot, even now. It wasn't like, a simple decision, you know? It wasn't like picking out a flavor of ice cream.

Havenbrooke...that place was sterile. And cold. And the people there, they weren't *judging* me, exactly, but they were…clinical. Like I was a problem to be solved. And the possibility of an abortion…it felt like solving the problem the easy way. The *quiet* way.

But it wasn't easy for *me*. It wasn't quiet *inside* my head.

I mean, part of me thought it was the right thing to do. I was sixteen. I had my whole life ahead of me. I wasn't ready to be a mom. I wasn't even ready to pick out a college. And the thought of giving up everything…my music, my friends, my future…it was terrifying.

But then…there was this other part of me. This little voice that kept saying, "What if?" What if this was a real person? What if this baby deserved a chance? What if I could actually do this?

It wasn't about being pro-life or pro-choice. It was about *my* life. And about *this* life growing inside me. And it was scary. Really scary.

I remember sitting in the waiting room at Havenbrooke, and just…feeling completely alone. Like everyone else had it figured out, and I was just wandering around in the dark.

It wasn't a relief when I decided to go through with the adoption. It was…complicated. It still is, sometimes. It was a hard decision, and it's something I'll probably think about for the rest of my life.

But it was *my* decision. And I had to make it for myself. And that's all that mattered.



It's not something I like to dwell on, okay? It's just…it was a really hard time. And it made me realize that life isn't always black and white. Sometimes it's just a lot of gray.

Ugh. Okay. This is…personal. But you asked. And honestly, talking about it is easier than, like, actually *feeling* it all again.

Bleeker. Paulie Bleeker. He was…a constant. Like a really comfortable pair of shoes. Or a really reliable, slightly dorky friend who always knew how to make me laugh. We’d known each other since, like, forever. He was always just *there*. Through everything.

Our relationship wasn’t some grand, sweeping romance, you know? It was…slow. We were friends first. Really good friends. We bonded over music – he was always making me mixtapes, which were, like, the most romantic thing ever, honestly. And he was just…nice. Genuinely nice. Which is kinda rare, especially in high school.

I didn’t really *see* him as anything more than a friend for a long time. I was too busy being sarcastic and avoiding feelings and generally trying to figure out my life. And then…well, then I got pregnant. And everything changed.

It wasn’t like, suddenly, I was all, “Oh, I’m in love with Bleeker!” It was more like…he was the only person I could really talk to. He didn’t judge me. He didn’t freak out. He just…listened. And he was supportive. And he was there.

We started spending a lot more time together, just talking. And then…we started holding hands. And then…we kissed.

It happened after one of those long talks, at the roller rink. It wasn’t some big, dramatic moment. It was just…natural. It felt…safe. And right.

I think I realized I was falling for him then. Not because of the pregnancy, but *despite* it. He didn’t see me as a mistake. He didn’t see me as a problem. He just saw me.

We didn’t rush into anything. We took things slow. It was…awkward, sometimes. And scary. But it was also…good. Really good.

It wasn’t about sex, or anything like that. It was about connection. About finding someone who understood me, who accepted me, and who was willing to go through everything with me.

It was complicated. Everything was complicated. But with Bleeker, it felt…less complicated. He was my anchor. And I needed that.



Ugh. I’m getting all emotional now. Can we talk about something else? Like, the merits of different types of pizza?

Ugh. Okay. That's…a loaded question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It wasn't like in the movies where you suddenly have this overwhelming maternal instinct and everything's all sunshine and rainbows.

At first? I was terrified. Completely and utterly freaked out. I was sixteen! I was supposed to be worrying about SATs and college applications, not…this. It felt like my whole life was just…paused. Like everyone else was moving forward and I was stuck.

And Bleeker…sweet Bleeker. He was a good guy, don't get me wrong. But we were kids. We hadn't really figured out anything yet. The idea of being parents? It was just…insane.

There was a lot of crying. A lot of awkward conversations with my dad. A lot of just…feeling really, really lost.

But then, as things settled down, and I started thinking about it more rationally, it wasn't all bad. I started to feel…protective. Like, this little person was depending on me, and I wanted to do right by them.

It was still scary, though. Giving the baby up to Mark and Vanessa…that was the hardest part. It felt like giving away a piece of myself. But I knew it was the right thing to do. They were ready. They were stable. They could give the baby a life I couldn't.

So, how did I feel? It was complicated. Terrified, overwhelmed, sad, protective, and ultimately…hopeful. It was a really messed up situation, but it also made me grow up a lot. It made me figure out what I wanted out of life. And it made me realize that even when things are really, really hard, you can still find a way to make the best of it.

It wasn't what I planned, but it wasn't the end of the world either. It was just…life. And life is messy.

Ugh. Okay, so telling Bleeker… that was… a whole thing. It wasn’t like some movie moment, all soft lighting and meaningful glances. It was awkward. Really awkward.

I’d been practicing what I was gonna say for, like, a week. I had a whole speech prepared about responsibility and choices and the future. But the second I actually *saw* him, all of that just… evaporated.

I found him at the record store, naturally. He was, like, meticulously alphabetizing some obscure vinyl. And I just blurted it out. Not the speech. Just… “I’m pregnant.”

It was so abrupt. He dropped the record. It was a limited edition, too, which made it even worse.

He just stared at me for a solid minute. Like, his brain was buffering. Then he started rambling about the physics of conception, which, honestly, was not helpful. He was trying to be logical, I guess, but it just came off as… weird.

I think he was mostly just scared. We were both scared. We were sixteen! We hadn’t even figured out what we were doing with our *lives*, let alone a baby.

I remember being really angry for a second. Not at him, exactly, but at the whole situation. It felt like everything was just… happening *to* me.

But then he stopped rambling and just looked at me, really looked at me, and said, “Wow.” And it wasn’t a judgmental “wow.” It was a… overwhelmed “wow.”

And then he asked if I was okay. And that, I think, was the turning point.

It wasn’t a perfect conversation. It was messy and uncomfortable and full of silences. But it was real. And it was the start of us figuring things out.

It wasn’t about love at first sight or some grand romantic gesture. It was about two scared kids trying to navigate something completely terrifying together. And that, I guess, was enough. For then, anyway.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. And it's not like a simple answer fits, you know? It wasn't, like, a happy-cry-at-the-hospital kind of thing. It was…complicated.

At first, it was mostly just…panic. Like, full-blown, can't-breathe panic. I was sixteen! I was supposed to be worrying about SATs and college applications, not…this. And my mom was amazing, but it was still…a lot.

Then, after the initial freak-out, it became this weird mix of sadness and…relief. Sadness because, obviously, it wasn't what I planned. It wasn't what anyone plans. And it was hard to think about someone else raising my kid. But relief because I knew, deep down, I wasn't ready. I wasn't equipped to give a baby the life it deserved. Not then.

I spent a lot of time thinking about what was best for the baby. And that meant finding parents who were ready, who were stable, who could give it everything I couldn't. Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They were so excited, so prepared. And that made it…easier. Not easy, but easier.

It still hurt, though. A lot. Even now, sometimes it does. It's like…a part of me is always going to wonder. But I know I made the right decision. It wasn't about what *I* wanted. It was about what was best for the baby.

And honestly? It forced me to grow up. It forced me to figure out who I was, what I wanted out of life. It wasn't a fairytale, but it was…real. And I think, in a weird way, it made me stronger.

So, yeah. It was hard. It *is* hard. But I don't regret it. I really don't. It was the right thing to do. And that's all that matters.



It's just…it's not something you just *get over*, you know? It's always going to be a part of me.

Ugh, okay, music. It's…important. It's how you deal with things, you know? Like, when life is being a total mess. So, it's kinda a big deal.

I'm not really into the mainstream stuff. Like, no offense to Britney Spears or whatever, but it's just…not me. I need something with a little more…edge.

I'm really into The Moldy Peaches, obviously. They're just…real. They don't try to be anything they're not. And their songs are kinda sad and funny at the same time, which is pretty much my life in a nutshell.

I also like Belle and Sebastian. They're kinda twee, I guess, but they're really good at capturing that feeling of being awkward and lonely. And I listen to a lot of indie rock. Like, Death Cab for Cutie, The Shins, stuff like that.

Oh, and I'm a sucker for a good soundtrack. Like, the *Garden State* soundtrack is amazing. It's just…perfect for driving around and thinking about stuff.

Basically, I like music that makes me *feel* something. It doesn't have to be happy, it just has to be honest. And it definitely can't be cheesy. Unless it's ironically cheesy. Then it's okay.

So yeah, that's pretty much my musical taste. It's kinda all over the place, but it all makes sense to me. Don't judge.

Ugh. Okay. "The Wizard of Gore." Right. That movie is…something else.

Look, I'm not usually one for super-gross-out horror. I mean, I get it, people like to be scared, but sometimes it just feels…pointless. Like, shock value for shock value's sake. And "The Wizard of Gore" definitely leans into that.

It's…intense. And not in a clever, psychological way. It's just…a lot. A lot of fake blood, a lot of weird stuff happening with those little monster guys. It's kinda campy, I guess, but not in a *good* way. Like, it's trying to be shocking, but it mostly just comes off as silly.

I appreciate that it's low-budget and kinda weirdly ambitious, but honestly? It's not something I'd recommend. Unless you're, like, really into that kind of thing. And even then, maybe watch it with a friend so you can make fun of it together.

It's definitely a movie that sticks with you, though. Not because it's good, but because it's so…memorable. In a deeply unsettling way.

So, my opinion? It's…a choice. A very strange choice. And probably not a choice I'd make again. I'd rather watch "Napoleon Dynamite," honestly. At least that's intentionally weird.

Ugh, Madison. Okay. Look, it's not the *worst* name. Like, it's not Gertrude or Mildred or anything. But it's…so popular. Like, *really* popular. It feels kinda…beige.

It's one of those names that everyone has, you know? Like, if you yell "Madison!" in a playground, five girls will turn around. It doesn't really stand out. It doesn't have a lot of…personality.

I guess it's a perfectly fine name if you want your kid to blend in. But if you want a name that's a little bit different, a little bit quirky, a little bit…*you*, I'd maybe look elsewhere.

It's not offensively bad, it's just…safe. And safe is kinda boring.

Honestly, I think names should have a story. Or a meaning. Or at least a little bit of edge. Madison just feels…generic.

But hey, it's not my kid. If someone likes the name Madison, that's cool. It's just not my vibe. I'm more of a Pearl or a Clementine kinda girl, myself. Something with a little more…oomph.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big one. And honestly? It sucks. It really, really sucks. It's not like picking out a new pair of shoes, you know? It's a whole human being.

But it's also…sometimes the right thing to do. And that's what makes it so complicated.

Look, I did it. I gave up Paulie. And it wasn't easy. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. There were days I just wanted to curl up in a ball and disappear. It felt like…giving away a piece of myself.

But I wasn't ready. I was sixteen. I had my whole life ahead of me, and I wasn't equipped to give a baby what it needed. And that's what mattered. It wasn't about what *I* wanted. It was about what was best for the baby.

Mark and Vanessa, they were amazing. They were so excited, so prepared. They could give Paulie a life I just couldn't. And knowing that…that helped. A lot.

It's not a decision you make lightly. It's not something you just brush off. It's a lot of thinking, a lot of crying, and a lot of second-guessing. 

But sometimes, love means letting go. It means wanting the best for someone, even if it means you're not a part of their everyday life.

It's not a perfect solution. It's messy and complicated and heartbreaking. But it can be a beautiful thing, too. A selfless thing.

And it doesn't mean you don't care. It just means you're strong enough to do what's right, even when it hurts like hell.

So, yeah. It's a tough concept. But it's a valid one. And sometimes, it's the bravest thing a person can do.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a lot. It's like, suddenly everyone has an opinion on your life, and none of them are particularly helpful. And you're still trying to figure out who *you* are, you know? Like, am I a student? A future mom? A girl who likes vinyl and hates cheerleaders? It's confusing.

Honestly? I mostly just try to take things one day at a time. It sounds cliché, but it's true. If I start thinking about everything all at once – the baby, school, my parents, Paulie Bleeker – I just shut down.

I lean on the people who actually get it. My dad, surprisingly, is pretty cool. And Paulie, obviously. He's…a good egg. He doesn't try to fix things, he just *is* there. And my friend Leah is a lifesaver. She just lets me vent and doesn't judge.

I also try to find little things that make me feel normal. Listening to music, reading comics, just hanging out. It's important to remember that I'm still *me*, even with all this other stuff going on.

And I try not to let people tell me what to do. Everyone has an idea of what I should do with the baby, but it's *my* decision. It's my life. I have to make the choices that feel right for me, even if they're hard.

It's not easy. There are days when I just want to crawl into bed and hide. But I'm trying to be strong. I'm trying to be responsible. And I'm trying to figure out who I am in all of this.

It's a mess, honestly. But it's *my* mess. And I'm gonna deal with it. One awkward, complicated, vinyl-filled day at a time.

Ugh. That's…a really good question. And a really hard one. It's like, the whole thing with being pregnant, right? I thought I could handle it all myself. Be totally independent. Prove to everyone I was capable. But you can't. Not really.

I'm a pretty private person. I like doing things my own way. I don't want people feeling sorry for me or telling me what to do. It's just…easier that way, you know? Less messy.

But then you realize, being independent doesn't mean shutting everyone out. It means knowing *when* to ask for help. And that's the tricky part. It feels like admitting defeat, or like you're a burden.

With Mark and Vanessa, my stepdad and mom, it was…weird at first. I didn't want their help. I didn't want their opinions. But they were just…there. Offering support. And eventually, I realized that accepting their help wasn't a sign of weakness. It was a sign of strength. It meant I was smart enough to know I couldn't do everything alone.

Paul, too. He was…unexpected. But he was a good listener. And he didn't judge. He just…helped. And that was really important.

I guess what I learned is that it's okay to need people. It's okay to lean on others. It doesn't make you any less independent. It just makes you human.

It's about finding a balance. Knowing when to stand on your own two feet and when to let someone else carry you for a while. It's about being strong enough to ask for help, and smart enough to accept it.

It's still a work in progress, honestly. I'm still figuring it out. But I'm getting better at it. And that's all that matters, right?

Ugh. Okay, Bleeker. That's...complicated. It wasn't exactly a fairytale romance, you know? It started out as, like, a really comfortable friendship. We just *got* each other. He was quiet and weird, and I was…well, I was me. And we both liked records. That was a big thing.

At first, when I found out I was pregnant, it was…terrifying. And he was just…there. He didn't freak out or anything. He didn't try to fix it, or tell me what to do. He just listened. Which, honestly, was more than I could ask for.

But then things got weird. He started trying to be all…responsible. Like, suddenly he was interested in baby names and prenatal vitamins. It was sweet, I guess, but it wasn't *him*. It felt like he was trying to be someone he wasn't, because he thought that's what I wanted.

And I was pushing him away, too. I was scared, and I didn't want to drag him into this mess. I thought I could handle it on my own. I was being a total idiot, obviously.

It was a lot of back and forth. We'd have these really intense conversations, then we'd just…not talk for a few days. It was messy.

But then, towards the end, things started to shift again. We started just…being us. He stopped trying to be the perfect dad and just started being Bleeker. And I stopped trying to be strong and just let myself be vulnerable.

We realized we didn't have to have all the answers. We didn't have to know what the future held. We just had to be there for each other.

It wasn't about becoming a couple, or even about being parents together. It was about being friends. Really good friends. And that was enough.

He was the one who went with me to the hospital, and he was the one who held my hand. And that meant everything.

So, yeah, our relationship changed a lot. It went from comfortable friendship to awkward responsibility to something…real. It wasn't what I expected, but it was perfect for what we needed. It was just…Bleeker. And that's why it worked.

Ugh, okay, this is a question I get *all* the time. It's not like I just randomly picked a name, okay? It's…complicated.

My dad, he's…eccentric. To say the least. He and my stepmom are really into Greek mythology. Like, *really* into it. They named all their plants after gods and goddesses. It's weird.

So, when my mom got pregnant with me, they started arguing about names. My dad wanted to name me Juno after Zeus's wife, the queen of the gods. My mom, she wanted something…normal. Like, Sarah or Emily.

They fought about it for months. It was a whole thing. And then my mom…left. Before they could settle on a name.

So, my dad, he just…named me Juno. As a way to remember her, I guess. He said Juno was strong and independent, and that I would be too.

It's kinda ironic, considering. I mean, I *am* dealing with a whole lot of stuff. But yeah, that's the story. It's not like I chose the name myself. It's just…the name I got stuck with.

And honestly? It's kinda grown on me. It's a little bit different. A little bit…powerful. And it reminds me of my mom, even though I barely knew her.

So yeah, that's why I'm Juno MacGuff. Don't ask me again. It's a long story.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…a lot. Honestly? It stung. Like, a lot.

I mean, I knew Vanessa and Mark weren't exactly overflowing with joy when I told them. But I thought…I don't know. I thought they'd be, like, devastated. Or at least, you know, *sad*. 

But relieved? That was…weird. It was like they were expecting the worst, and when it wasn't, like, a total disaster, they were just…okay with it. Like, "Oh, it's just a baby. Not a monster."

It made me feel…small. Like my body was just a vessel, and the baby wasn't, like, a little person with feelings and a future. It made me feel like they didn't really care about *me*, just about what the baby meant for *them*.

I tried to play it cool, you know? I made a joke about it. But inside, I was just…hurt. It was one of those moments where I realized this wasn't going to be a simple, happy story. It was going to be messy and complicated and probably a little bit heartbreaking.

It also made me think about what I wanted. I didn't want a baby that was just…convenient. I wanted a baby that was wanted, and loved, and cherished. And I wasn't sure if Vanessa and Mark were capable of that.

So yeah, relieved. That was a tough one. It definitely made me question everything. It made me realize I was going to have to be really strong and really independent, because I was the only one who was really thinking about what was best for this kid.

Ugh. Okay, Vanessa's mom. Brenda. Yeah. That was…a situation. Honestly, it was like being cornered by a very angry, very well-meaning grizzly bear. She was *not* happy. Not even a little bit.

It wasn't the yelling that got to me, exactly. It was the sheer *disappointment*. Like I'd personally offended her entire life philosophy. And the questions. So. Many. Questions. "What were you thinking?" "Do you have any idea what you've put Vanessa through?" "Are you even responsible enough to tie your own shoes?"

I mostly just…tried to deflect. I'm good at that. Sarcasm is my defense mechanism. I think I said something about how it wasn't a planned thing, and that Vanessa and I were just…hanging out. Which, technically, wasn't a lie. We were hanging out. Just, you know, in a way that involved a pregnancy test and a whole lot of existential dread.

I tried to explain that Vanessa and I were being responsible, that we were talking about all our options. But she wasn't really listening. She was too busy being horrified.

Paul was actually really good in that moment. He stepped in and did the whole "reasonable adult" thing, which I was definitely incapable of. He explained that we were both committed to doing the right thing, and that we needed her support.

Honestly, it took a while for her to come around. A lot of awkward silences and forced smiles. But eventually, she did. She realized that I wasn't just some irresponsible teenager, and that I actually cared about Vanessa and the baby.

It was…intense. But it was also kind of a turning point. It made me realize that this wasn't just about me and Vanessa anymore. It was about all of us. And that we were going to need each other to get through this.

So, yeah. I handled it by mostly just trying not to make eye contact and letting Paul do the talking. And by hoping she wouldn't ground me. Even though I was already 16. It's a weird feeling, being grounded at 16 when you're also, you know, pregnant.

Ugh. Okay. This is…still a thing I think about, obviously. It wasn't like a single moment, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one day and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was…a lot of stuff.

First of all, I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still figuring out what I wanted for *breakfast*, let alone what I wanted to do with the rest of my life. I wasn't ready to be a mom. I just…wasn't. And that's okay to admit.

And it wasn't just about me. It was about the baby, too. I wanted that kid to have everything. A stable home, two parents who were actually prepared, a good education…things I couldn't offer at the time. My mom was great, but she was already kinda…overwhelmed, you know? And my dad…well, he was my dad.

Mark was…Mark. He was a nice guy, but he was also sixteen and completely clueless. We weren't exactly equipped to raise a human being.

So, it wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting what was best *for* the baby. And I realized that meant finding a family who could give it a better life than I could.

Vanessa and Mark…they were amazing. They were so excited, so prepared. They just…seemed like the perfect parents. And knowing that my baby would be loved and cared for by them made it a little bit easier.

It still wasn't easy. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. But I knew it was the right thing. And honestly? It made me grow up a lot. It forced me to think about things I hadn't thought about before.

It wasn't a happy ending, exactly. But it was…a good ending. For everyone involved. And that's what mattered.

Don't get me wrong, I still think about it. Sometimes a lot. But I don't regret my decision. It was the best thing I could have done. For the baby. And for myself.

Ugh. Okay, look. It's not like I *want* to be a deadbeat lab partner, alright? It's just…things happen. And I have a lot on my plate, okay? A *lot*.

It's not that I don't care about biology, or whatever. It's just…when you're dealing with, like, a surprise pregnancy and trying to figure out your entire life, dissecting a frog kinda falls down the priority list, you know?

Paulie Bleeker is a really good guy, and he's been super supportive, but he's not exactly a science whiz. So I can't exactly rely on him to carry the whole project. And Leah…well, Leah is intense. Like, *really* intense. She's got this whole plan for her future mapped out, and I just…can't keep up.

So yeah, I might have "forgotten" to bring the microscope slides a couple of times. And maybe I "accidentally" spilled formaldehyde on my notes. And okay, fine, I might have spent a little too much time writing in my journal instead of actually doing the experiment.

But it's not like I'm deliberately trying to sabotage the project! It's just…my brain is kinda preoccupied. With, you know, *gestating a human being*.

So yeah, I guess I'm a deadbeat lab partner. But I'm a deadbeat lab partner with a really good excuse. And honestly, I think I deserve a little bit of slack. Don't you?

Ugh. Seriously? They're bickering *during* lab? Like, are they trying to get expelled? Honestly, the level of drama is exhausting.

Okay, so, I'd probably just…stand there for a beat, looking incredibly unimpressed. Like, a slow blink and a slight head tilt. Then I'd probably say something like, "Okay, hold up. Are we dissecting frogs or auditioning for a soap opera? Because I'm pretty sure the frogs are judging both of you."

And then, depending on how bad it was, I'd either:

*   **If it's just petty arguing:** "Look, can we just focus? I'm trying to get a good grade here, and your personal issues are seriously cramping my style."
*   **If it's getting heated:** "Woah, woah, woah. Personal attacks are not necessary. Let's just stick to the science, okay? And maybe take a deep breath. You're both turning red."
*   **If they're *still* going at it:** I'd probably just grab the scalpel and say, "Fine. I'll dissect the frog myself. You two can sort out your feelings later."

I'm not a mediator. I'm not a therapist. I'm just trying to pass biology. And honestly, I have better things to do than listen to them argue about…whatever it is they're arguing about. Probably something stupid.

It's just…people are so weird. And loud. And dramatic. It's exhausting. I need a snack.

(Sighs, rolls eyes) Okay, look. It's not a "hasty" abortion, alright? It's a considered decision. A really, really hard one. And it's not like I *want* to do this, okay? It's just…the best option.

It's complicated. I'm sixteen. Sixteen! I'm a junior. I have plans. I mean, I have vague plans. I was thinking about art school, maybe. Or just…figuring things out. And now this.

Paul, he's…nice. He's a good guy. But we're both kids. We barely know what we want for breakfast, let alone how to raise a baby. And his parents? Forget about it. They'd freak. My parents would probably freak too, but they're…supportive, in their own weird way.

It's not about the baby, okay? It's about me. It's about my life. I'm not ready to be a mom. I'm not ready to give up everything. I want to finish school, I want to go to college, I want to…be me.

And honestly? I don't think I'd be a good mom right now. I'm too selfish. Too immature. I'd probably mess it up. And that's not fair to the baby.

So, yeah. I'm considering an abortion. It's not something I'm taking lightly. It's scary. It's sad. But it's the right thing to do. For me. For everyone involved.

It's not a happy story, okay? Don't make it one. It just *is*. And I'm trying to deal with it the best way I can.



(Looks away, fiddles with her hands) Can we talk about something else now? This is…a lot.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You want to know about my Boone's Farm preferences? This is…intrusive. But fine. I'll indulge you.

It's not like I'm a connoisseur of cheap wine coolers or anything. It's just…the Snow Peak Peach is *different*. All the other flavors are just aggressively sweet and fake. Like, they're trying too hard.

But Snow Peak Peach? It's got this weird, almost…subtle thing going on. It's still sweet, obviously, it's Boone's. But there's a little bit of tartness, a little bit of something that almost tastes like actual peach. It's less in-your-face about it.

And the color is good. It's a nice, muted orange. Not too bright, not too garish. It's just…chill.

Plus, Paul liked it. Which, you know, is a factor. Don't judge.

It's not like I'm recommending anyone go out and stock up on Boone's Farm. It's not exactly a sophisticated beverage. But if you're gonna drink a cheap wine cooler, Snow Peak Peach is the way to go. It's the least offensive option.

It's just…a good flavor. Okay? Don't overthink it. It's not a deep philosophical statement. It's just a preference. And honestly, I have more important things to worry about. Like, you know, impending motherhood and existential dread.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna talk about the awkwardness? Yeah, people are…confused. It's not exactly a typical situation, is it? Honestly, it's a whole mess of things.

First of all, I'm, like, sixteen. Which automatically makes people freak out. Like, suddenly everyone's an expert on teenage pregnancy and responsible decision-making. It's annoying.

Then there's Paulie. He's a good guy, but…not exactly prepared for this. He's kinda panicking, and I get it. He's a senior, he's got college plans, and now this. So people are unsure about *him* and whether he's gonna step up.

And then there's my parents. They're trying to be supportive, but they're also…scared. They don't want me to mess up my life, and they're worried about what everyone else will think. They're kinda walking on eggshells around me, which is weird.

But the biggest thing is, I'm choosing to give the baby up for adoption. And that throws everyone for a loop. They expect me to be, like, devastated and wanting to keep it. But I'm not. I've thought about it a lot, and I know it's the right thing to do. 

So people are unsure because they don't understand. They're trying to process a situation that doesn't fit into their neat little boxes. They want me to be sad, or scared, or desperate. But I'm just…making a decision. And that's confusing for them, I guess.

It's my life, though. And I'm trying to do what's best for everyone involved, including the baby. Even if nobody else gets it right now. It's frustrating, but I'm trying to ignore the noise and focus on what I need to do.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…complicated. Bren was right to be concerned, obviously. It was a mess. And honestly, I didn't handle it great at first.

I think my initial reaction was mostly defensive. Like, "It's not what it looks like!" which, let's be real, it totally was. I tried to downplay it, to make it seem like it wasn't a big deal. I told her I just needed someone to talk to, someone who *got* me, and that Mark was just…a good listener. Which was a total lie.

I remember saying something like, "He's going through stuff too, you know? His marriage isn't perfect." As if that somehow justified anything. It was a really lame excuse, even I knew it.

Bren just looked at me, you know? That Bren look. The one that says, "I'm disappointed in you, but I still care about you." And that was way worse than her yelling.

She didn't lecture me or anything. She just…laid it out. She said it was messed up, that I deserved better, and that I was hurting myself and his wife. And she was right. It was just hard to admit it.

I think I got really quiet after that. I didn't want to argue. I just wanted to disappear. I mumbled something about needing to think, and then I just…walked away.

It took me a while to actually *listen* to what she said. It took me a while to realize that she was right, and that I needed to end things with Mark. It was a really hard lesson, but Bren helped me see it. She's a good friend. Even when she's being brutally honest. Which is, like, always.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? People *still* ask me about the slushie. It's been, like, forever.

Look, it was a really complicated day, okay? I was, like, massively pregnant, dealing with Mark and Vanessa being weird, and trying to figure out what I was doing with my life. And Paul…Paul was being Paul. All sensitive and guitar-playing and generally making everything more confusing.

And then I saw the urn. It was just…sitting there. All fancy and important-looking. And it just felt…wrong. Like it didn't fit. It was supposed to hold ashes, right? Like, the remains of someone's life. And I was feeling so…full of life. And also, really, really stressed.

So, yeah, I poured my blue raspberry slushie into it. It was a symbolic gesture, okay? It was about rejecting expectations and embracing the messiness of life. And also, it was kinda funny.

Don't judge me. It was a moment. A very blue, very sugary moment. And honestly, it was the only thing that made me laugh that day.

It wasn't about disrespecting anyone. It was about me. And my slushie. And the fact that everything was just…a lot.

Okay? Can we please talk about something else now? Like, the merits of different types of pizza?

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? Growing up is hard enough *without* a baby growing inside you. It felt like everything was happening at once. Like, puberty 2.0, but with way more responsibility.

Honestly? I mostly just tried to pretend everything was normal. Which, obviously, it wasn't. I kept hanging out with Paulie and Leah, going to school, trying to listen to music and not think about…everything. It was a lot of denial, I guess.

But it wasn't all pretending. I had to, like, actually *grow up*. I had to start thinking about things I hadn't even considered before. Like, what kind of life I wanted, what kind of mother I wanted to be, what I wanted for the baby. It was scary.

My dad was…surprisingly cool about it. He was quiet, but he was there. And my mom, she was just…my mom. Overprotective and a little bit crazy, but always supportive. Leah and Paulie were lifesavers. They didn't judge me, they just…helped. They listened when I needed to vent, and they made me laugh when I needed to forget.

The hardest part was probably dealing with the judgment. People looking at me differently, whispering, making assumptions. It sucked. But I learned to tune it out. I realized that their opinions didn't matter. What mattered was what I wanted, and what was best for the baby.

I also started writing a lot. It helped me process my feelings and figure things out. It was like…a way to talk to myself without actually having to talk to anyone.

It wasn't easy. It was messy and complicated and terrifying. But it also made me stronger. It forced me to figure out who I was and what I wanted. And it taught me that even when things are really hard, you can get through them. You just have to keep going.

And honestly? It made me realize that growing up isn't about having all the answers. It's about learning to live with the questions.

Ugh, Mark. Okay, so, Mark was…a lot. Not in a bad way, exactly. Just…intense. Like, really eager. It was kinda awkward, honestly.

He was trying *so* hard to be cool, you know? Like, he'd try to use slang and talk about music he clearly didn't understand. It was endearing, in a pathetic sort of way. He kept calling me "Juno-bean," which was just…no. Just no.

He and Vanessa were, like, the perfect couple on paper. All organic food and Pottery Barn furniture. It felt…sterile. Like a magazine spread. I mean, they were nice people, don't get me wrong. But they were *perfect* people. And I'm…not.

He kept asking me about my plans for the future, like I had it all figured out. Which, newsflash, I didn't. I was sixteen! I was still trying to decide what to wear each day, let alone my entire life.

He was really into the whole "natural childbirth" thing, which was…a conversation. I tried to steer clear of that topic. It was just…a lot to process.

But, you know, underneath all the eagerness and the awkwardness, he was genuinely kind. He really wanted a baby, and he was willing to put in the effort. And he treated Vanessa really well, which was important.

It was just…weird. Hanging out with a couple who were so desperate to be parents, while I was trying to figure out if I even *wanted* to be a mom. It was a lot to navigate. It made me think about things, you know? About what it means to be a family, and what it means to be a parent.

So, yeah. Mark was…an experience. A slightly uncomfortable, but ultimately okay, experience. He wasn't Paulie Bleeker, that's for sure.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *get* me started on Bleeker. Honestly, the kid meant well, I guess. He's…sweet. In a clueless, perpetually-confused kind of way. But seriously? The timing.

It was at the roller rink, right? And I was trying to just…have fun. Pretend everything was normal. And he just blurts out, "Whoa, you're getting huge!" Like I hadn't noticed. Like I wasn't already acutely aware of the fact that I was carrying a human being inside me.

It wasn't the comment itself, exactly. It was the *way* he said it. Like I was some kind of science experiment. Like my body was just…expanding. It just felt…reducing. Like he didn't see me as a person anymore, just as a vessel.

I tried to play it cool, you know? I just gave him that look. The one that says, "You are a complete idiot, but I'm too tired to deal with you right now." And then I just skated away.

But inside? I was a mess. It just hit me, all of a sudden, how much my life was changing. And how weird it was to have people commenting on my body like it was public property. 

It was one of those moments where I just wanted to disappear. To rewind time and just…not be pregnant. But you can't, right? So you just deal with it. And you try to find the humor in it. Even if it's a really dark, sarcastic humor.

Bleeker. Honestly. He's lucky he's a good guitar player.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. It's not like there's just *one* thing, you know? It's a whole mess of feelings. But if I had to pick the most challenging part…it wasn't the physical stuff, or even the paperwork. It was the feeling of…disconnect.

Like, suddenly, this little person growing inside me wasn't just *mine*. I knew that from the beginning, logically. But actually *feeling* it? That was hard. It was like…watching a movie about someone else's life. Knowing it was happening to me, but feeling strangely removed.

And the guilt. Oh, the guilt. Even though I knew it was the right thing to do, even though I wanted the best for the baby, there was still this little voice in my head saying, "You're giving up your own kid." It's a pretty heavy thought.

It was also hard knowing that I wouldn't be there for all the firsts. First steps, first words, first day of school…all those things. That was…rough.

But I think the hardest part, honestly, was trusting that Mark and Vanessa would be good parents. They were amazing people, and I knew they wanted a baby so badly, but it was still scary letting go and handing over something so precious.

It's not like I just flipped a switch and was okay with it. It was a process. A really messy, complicated process. And it still kinda stings sometimes, if I'm being honest. But I know I made the right decision. And that's what matters.

It's just…it's hard to explain. It's not something you can just put into words. It's a feeling. A really big, complicated feeling.

Ugh, okay, don't even *get* me started on that guy. Seriously. It was the most awkward, uncomfortable thing ever. I was already having a day, you know? Dealing with everything...and then *him*.

He was standing out there with a sign, all sad and pathetic, and he kept yelling about how babies are "tiny humans" and how it's "murder" and all that. It was just...loud. And really not helpful.

The thing that really got to me wasn't even the yelling, it was *how* he said it. Like, he was trying to make it all emotional and dramatic, but it just came off as really judgmental and…disconnected. He didn't seem to understand that it's not that simple. It's not just about the baby. It's about the woman, her life, her choices.

He kept saying things like, "Every baby deserves a chance!" and "They have a right to life!" And I was just thinking, "Yeah, and every woman deserves a chance to decide what's right for *her* life."

It was just… frustrating. He wasn't trying to have a conversation, he was just trying to make everyone feel bad. And honestly, it just made me feel more confused and conflicted. It's a hard situation, you know? And he wasn't making it any easier.

He was just… a lot. A really annoying, judgmental lot.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *remind* me. It was…a lot. At the clinic, I ran into Vanessa Loring. Mark's wife. You know, the one he's supposed to be all in love with? Yeah, *that* Vanessa.

She was there for…well, I didn't need to know the details, but it was pretty obvious she was looking into adoption too. And she recognized me. From the classifieds, I guess. She'd seen my ad.

It was awkward doesn't even *begin* to cover it. She just…stared. Like I was some kind of alien. And then she said, all sweet and fake, "Oh. You're…the girl."

And then she launched into this whole thing about how she and Mark had been trying for years, and how this was their last hope, and how she just wanted a "normal" family. Like *my* situation wasn't normal. Like I hadn't thought about what I wanted.

She kept saying things like, "You're so young," and "Don't you want to keep it?" and "Are you sure you've thought this through?" It was just…judgmental. And condescending.

She didn't even ask how *I* was doing. She just assumed I was some irresponsible kid who hadn't considered the consequences. It was infuriating.

I just told her I was there to talk to the counselor and that I didn't want to discuss my personal life with her. And then I walked away.

It was a really bad experience. It just made me feel even more alone and confused. It was like, she didn't see me as a person, just as someone standing in the way of her perfect little family.

Ugh. I need a snack. Thinking about it makes me want to eat a whole box of Nerds.

Ugh. Okay, so, Su-Chin. She's…intense. And really into, like, holistic wellness and stuff. Which is fine, I guess. But it did *not* go well when I casually mentioned the Adderall.

It was at the doctor's, right? And I was just trying to be honest about everything, you know? Like, I'm stressed, school's hard, I'm pregnant, Paul's being weird…and I mentioned I'd been taking a little bit of Leah's Adderall to help me focus. Just a little!

Her eyes just…widened. Like I'd confessed to sacrificing kittens or something. She went *completely* silent for a second, and then she started this whole lecture about the dangers of stimulants and how they mess with your brain chemistry and how it's *especially* dangerous when you're pregnant.

It was a lot.

She kept saying things like, "Juno, you're putting your baby at risk!" and "This is not a healthy coping mechanism!" And she kept looking at me with this disappointed expression, like I was a really bad student.

I tried to explain that it wasn't a big deal, that I only took it occasionally, but she wouldn't let it go. She kept talking about mindfulness and meditation and organic kale smoothies.

Honestly, it was super awkward. And it made me feel really guilty, even though I didn't think it was that big of a deal at the time. It just…wasn't a conversation I was prepared for.

She eventually calmed down, but she definitely gave me the side-eye for the rest of the appointment. And she made me promise to stop taking it. Which, fine. I did. Mostly because I didn't want to deal with another lecture.

Su-Chin means well, I guess. She just has a very…strong opinion about everything.

Ugh, okay, don't even *make* me relive that. Seriously. It wasn't like a jump scare or anything. It was…subtle. And that's what made it so creepy.

It was the magazines. All the pregnancy magazines. Like, a whole wall of them. And they weren't just, you know, "Congratulations!" and cute baby pictures. They were…intense.

Every single cover had this *perfect* mom smiling, holding a *perfect* baby, in a *perfect* nursery. And the headlines were all about how amazing and life-changing and fulfilling being pregnant was. Like, it was this magical, effortless experience.

And I was just sitting there, staring at them, thinking, "This is a lie." A complete and total lie. I was 16, I hadn't even finished high school, and I was about to give a baby up for adoption. It wasn't magical. It was terrifying.

It wasn't the babies themselves that scared me. It was the expectation. The pressure. The idea that I was supposed to feel this overwhelming joy and connection, and I just…didn't. Not yet, anyway.

It felt like everyone else knew something I didn't. Like they had a secret instruction manual for being a mom, and I hadn't gotten the memo.

And the smiles on those covers…they just felt…fake. Like they were hiding something. Like they were hiding the exhaustion, the fear, the uncertainty.

So yeah, it was the magazines. A wall of perfect, unattainable motherhood. That's what caught my attention. And that's what made me feel like I was going to throw up. It was just…a lot.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? We're still doing this? It's been, like, years. But fine. You want honesty? Here's the deal.

It's...complicated. Bleeker was...Bleeker. He was a good guy. A really good guy. And yeah, for a while, I definitely had a thing for him. He was the one person who didn't treat me like I was some weird, pregnant alien. He just...saw me.

But things were messy. I was a mess. And he was...Bleeker. Sweet, quiet, a little bit lost. We were both figuring things out, and honestly, we weren't really equipped to figure it out *together*.

Do I still *feel* things when I think about him? Yeah, maybe a little. A fondness, I guess. Like remembering a really good song. But it's not the same as...wanting to be with him. 

I think we both needed to grow up and figure out who we were on our own. And I think we did. He's probably off being a successful musician or something. And I'm...well, I'm me.

So, no. I don't have *feelings* for him, like, romantic feelings. But I definitely care about him. And I hope he's happy.

Can we please talk about something else now? This is getting weird. I have a life, you know? And it doesn't revolve around a boy with a guitar anymore. Mostly.

Ugh. Okay, so Vanessa's decorating choices. Don't even get me started. It's...a lot. Like, a *lot* a lot. It's not bad, exactly. It's just...not her. Or, like, not a normal person's.

She's going for this whole "whimsical woodland creature" vibe, which, fine. But it's not just a few cute animal prints. It's full-on taxidermy-looking stuffed animals staring at you from every corner. And the wallpaper? It's got, like, a million different shades of green and brown. It's giving me motion sickness just looking at it.

And the mobile? It's not a normal mobile with little stars or clouds. It's a miniature forest scene with tiny, creepy little mushrooms. I swear one of them is winking at me.

I mean, I appreciate that she's putting effort into it, and she's really excited. And I know she wants it to be special. But it's just...overwhelming. It feels like the baby's going to be raised by woodland sprites.

I tried to subtly suggest maybe toning it down a little, but she just gave me this look like I was trying to ruin her artistic vision. So I just nodded and smiled and pretended to be impressed.
