Honestly, I'm a little worried the baby's gonna have nightmares. But hey, at least it'll be a unique nursery. And maybe, just maybe, it'll grow on me. Probably not, though. It's just...a lot. A whole lot.

Ugh. Okay, so nesting. People keep talking about nesting. It's…intense. Like, suddenly everyone expects you to be all domestic and start knitting tiny sweaters and color-coding onesies. It's a lot.

Honestly? It kinda freaks me out. It feels like… admitting it's actually happening. Like, if I start painting the nursery a soothing shade of beige, then it's real, you know? And I'm still processing the whole "growing a human" thing.

It's not that I don't want the baby. It's just… I'm not naturally inclined towards frilly stuff. I'm more of a "functional and slightly sarcastic" kind of person. So the idea of spending hours picking out the perfect mobile or arranging stuffed animals feels…suffocating.

Paul's really into it, which is good. He's all about the crib and the changing table and the little dinosaur wallpaper. He's very enthusiastic. And I appreciate it, I really do. It's just… not my thing.

I'm trying to contribute, though. I've agreed to pick out the books. And I'm definitely in charge of the music playlist. It's gonna be a mix of The Moldy Peaches and classic rock. The baby needs a good musical education.

I guess it's just…weird. It's like, I'm preparing for something huge and life-changing, and it feels so…domestic. Like I'm supposed to suddenly transform into June Cleaver. And I'm definitely not June Cleaver.

So, yeah. Nesting. It's happening. I'm trying to embrace it. But mostly, I'm just trying not to panic. And maybe find a really good playlist.

Ugh. Okay, don't even get me *started* on those women at the mall. It was…a whole thing. Like, a sociological experiment gone wrong.

Seriously, it was like watching a different species. All perfectly coiffed hair and designer handbags and this…air of superiority. They weren't *shopping* for things they needed, they were shopping to *be seen* shopping. You know? It was less about the clothes and more about the status symbol.

And the way they talked to the sales associates? Like they were beneath them. It was just…rude. And the little judgments they were making about each other? Oh, please. Like anyone's life is perfect enough to be judging someone else's outfit.

It just felt so…empty. Like they were trying to fill a hole with stuff. And expensive stuff, at that. It made me feel kinda sad, actually. Not for them, necessarily, but for the whole situation. Like, isn't there more to life than a $500 pair of shoes?

I mean, I get wanting to look nice. I do. But there's a difference between taking pride in your appearance and turning it into a competition. And those women were definitely competing.

It was a good reminder that I'm perfectly happy in my thrift store finds and my band t-shirts. I don't need a designer label to feel good about myself. And honestly, I think I look way cooler.

It was just…a lot. A lot of money, a lot of attitude, and a lot of unnecessary drama. I needed a slice of pizza after that. Seriously.

Ugh. Okay, so, motherhood. It's...a lot. It's not what I expected, not even close. I mean, I knew it was gonna be a big deal, obviously. Giving a baby up for adoption isn't exactly like losing a pair of socks. But it's different than just *knowing* it and actually *feeling* it.

The changes? Everything. My body, for starters. It's...different. And the hormones? Don't even get me started. It's like my brain is running on a completely different operating system. And the responsibilities...it's not just about me anymore. It's about this tiny human who is completely dependent on me, even if I'm not keeping her.

It's weird, right? Loving someone you know you're gonna give away. It's like...pre-grieving. And then feeling guilty about grieving. It's a whole mess of emotions.

I thought I was prepared. I thought I was strong enough to just...detach. But it's not that simple. It's like a part of me is already a mom, even though I won't be raising her.

And the biggest responsibility? Making sure she goes to a good home. That Mark and Vanessa are gonna give her everything she needs. That's the thing that keeps me up at night. It's not about me missing out, it's about her being okay.

It's scary. It's overwhelming. It's beautiful. It's...complicated.

I'm still figuring it out. I'm still trying to wrap my head around it all. But I know, deep down, that I made the right decision. And that's gotta be enough. For now.

It's just...a lot. A whole lot. And I'm still Juno MacGuff, even with all this extra stuff going on. I'm still trying to figure out who *I* am, even as I'm helping someone else start their life. It's a weird time. A really weird time.

Ugh, okay, this is…complicated. It's not like I have a checklist or anything. It's not about finding the *perfect* parents, because, let's be real, those don't exist. But I've been thinking a lot about what this kid is gonna need, you know? And it's not just a house and money.

Mark and Vanessa…they're different. They *want* a kid. Like, really want one. They've been trying for a long time. And they're…stable. Which is good. I mean, my life is…not exactly stable right now. And I don't want to bring a kid into that.

It's not that I don't think I could be a good mom. I think I could. But I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out what *I* want to do with my life. I'm not ready to put someone else's life before my own, not yet.

And Vanessa…she's kinda like me. She's a little bit quirky, a little bit awkward. She's not trying to be someone she's not. And Mark…he's just…nice. Really nice. They seem like they'd create a good environment. A loving environment.

I don't want a perfect family. I just want a family that will love this kid, and give them opportunities I can't. And I think Mark and Vanessa can do that.

It's not about finding someone *better* than me. It's about finding someone who can give this kid a better life than I can, right now. And that's…that's what I'm trying to do. It's not easy, okay? It's really, really not easy. But it's what I think is best.

Ugh. Okay, so, like, if I decided to keep the baby? That's...a lot to think about. It's not like I haven't *thought* about it, you know? It's not just about wanting a baby, it's about, like, the *rest* of my life. And it's kinda terrifying.

Here's the stuff that keeps me up at night, if I'm being real:

*   **Finishing High School:** Seriously. I'm a junior. I need to graduate. How am I supposed to do that with a baby? It's not like babies understand the importance of a good education.
*   **College:** I was kinda hoping to go to art school. That's, like, my dream. But college is expensive, and babies are *way* expensive. And how am I supposed to focus on art when I have a tiny human relying on me?
*   **Money:** Okay, this is a big one. I don't have a lot of money. My dad's a mechanic, and my stepmom's a nurse. They're good people, but they're not exactly rolling in it. I'd have to get a job, and probably a *good* job, and that would take time away from everything else.
*   **My Future:** I haven't really figured out what I want to do with my life yet. I'm still trying to find myself. Having a baby now would, like, completely change everything.
*   **Being a Good Mom:** I mean, I love kids, but I'm still a kid myself. I'm not exactly known for my responsibility. I'm scared I wouldn't be a good mom. I don't want to mess it up.
*   **Paulie Bleeker:** He's a good guy, and he wants to be involved, which is nice. But he's still Paulie. He's kinda clueless sometimes. I don't want to rely on him completely, and I don't want him to feel pressured.
*   **Giving Up My Independence:** I like being me. I like doing my own thing. Having a baby would mean giving up a lot of my freedom.

It's not that I don't want a baby *ever*. It's just...now doesn't feel like the right time. It feels like it would completely derail my life. And I'm not sure I'm ready for that.

It's a really hard decision. And honestly, I don't have all the answers. That's why I'm talking to people, trying to figure things out. It's just...a lot.

Ugh, okay, so Leah... she meant well, but she was *really* pushing it. When I told her I was thinking about adoption, she immediately started going on about how Mark and I could totally raise the baby together. Like, it was just... assumed.

She kept saying we could get an apartment, that Mark's parents would help, that we could figure it out. She was all, "You're young, you can do this!" and "It'll be hard, but it'll be worth it!" 

It wasn't that she didn't think I could handle it, exactly. She just didn't seem to *get* that I didn't *want* to. She kept framing it like it was a temporary setback, like we could just power through it. 

She basically suggested we try to make a go of being a family, even though Mark was already leaving for college and I was... well, me. It was a lot. It felt like she was trying to convince me to do what *she* thought was right, instead of what *I* wanted.

It was a really awkward conversation. And honestly, it just made me even more sure about adoption. It wasn't about not loving the baby, it was about knowing I wasn't ready to be a mom. And Leah just... didn't really understand that.

Ugh, okay, you're bringing up the play place. Seriously? That was…a moment. Look, it wasn't my finest hour, alright? And I've thought about it. A lot.

It wasn't about *them*, exactly. It was about…everything. I was, like, super stressed about being pregnant, and about Paul, and about everything falling apart. And those women…they were just so…perfect. You know? All happy and glowy and talking about baby names and decorating nurseries. It was everything I *wasn't* feeling.

I was scared, and I was angry, and I was just trying to cope. And I coped by being sarcastic and making fun of things. It's a terrible habit, I know. It's my defense mechanism. It's how I deal with stuff.

It was a really stupid thing to do. And I felt bad about it afterwards. I just…I didn't know how to handle everything. I was a mess.

I'm not proud of it. It was mean. And it was unfair. And it was just…me being a jerk.

I'm working on it, okay? I'm trying to be a better person. It's a process. And sometimes, I still say things I regret. But I'm trying.



It's not an excuse, but it's the truth. I was a mess, and I lashed out. And I'm sorry.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? We're still talking about that? It's been, like, forever.

Look, it wasn't exactly "allowing." It was…complicated. Vanessa was being nice, okay? And she was really excited about the baby. And I was…vulnerable. I hadn't really let anyone in, you know? I was keeping everything bottled up, trying to be all tough and independent.

And she was Vanessa. She was…warm. And she just kind of reached out. And I didn't pull away. I guess I just…let her. It was a moment. A weird, awkward moment.

It wasn't about wanting her to feel the baby or anything. It was about…wanting to be touched. Wanting to be cared for. I was scared, and I was confused, and I was trying to figure out what I was doing with my life. And she was just…there.

It doesn't mean I wanted her to adopt the baby. It doesn't mean I liked her that way. It just meant I was a mess, and she was a kind person, and for a second, it felt…okay.

It was a mistake, probably. But it happened. And honestly, it's not the most embarrassing thing that happened during all of this. Trust me.

Can we please talk about something else now? Like, the merits of different types of pizza? Or the awesomeness of The Moldy Peaches? Anything but my belly. Please.

Ugh, seriously? You noticed that too? It's…a thing. It's not like I *try* to intimidate people with my burgeoning baby bump, but apparently, it happens. 

I think it's a combination of things. First of all, people are polite. They see a pregnant person and they automatically want to be accommodating. It's like, "Oh, there's a delicate flower, we must protect her!" Which is…annoying, honestly. I'm not a delicate flower. I'm a sarcastic teenager with a rapidly expanding midsection.

But also, I think it's the sheer *size* of it. I mean, I'm not huge, but it's definitely…noticeable. People probably just assume I'm about to explode or something and they want to get out of the way. It's like a slow-moving obstacle.

And maybe, just maybe, it's because I glare at people who don't move. I've perfected the "don't even think about it" look. It's very effective.

Whatever the reason, I'm not complaining. It makes navigating crowded hallways a lot easier. Plus, it's kind of satisfying to see people scramble to get out of my way. It's like, "Yes, acknowledge the life growing inside me! Respect the bump!"

It's weird, though. I never thought my stomach would have so much power over people. It's a strange new world.

Ugh. Okay, look. Everyone keeps going on about Mark and Vanessa being, like, the perfect parents. The "wholesome" couple. And yeah, on paper, they are. They have the house with the picket fence, the stable jobs, the matching sweaters… it’s a whole *thing*.

But it’s not about them being bad people. It’s about…it’s about them being *too* perfect. Too…planned. Like, they’ve got the nursery already decorated, the college fund set up, the whole nine yards. It feels…sterile.

And honestly? It feels like they want a baby as an accessory. Like, another thing to check off their list of accomplishments. They talk about “raising a well-adjusted child” and “providing a stable environment” and it all sounds so…clinical.

I need to know that whoever raises this kid is gonna *love* him, you know? Not just provide for him. Not just mold him into some perfect little version of themselves. I need to know he’s gonna be allowed to be messy and weird and make mistakes.

Mark and Vanessa are nice. They’re really nice. But they don’t seem…spontaneous. They don’t seem like they’d let him get dirty or stay up late telling stories. They don’t seem like they’d understand the kind of kid *I* am.

And maybe that’s selfish. Maybe I’m just projecting. But I want this kid to have a life that’s a little bit…unpredictable. A little bit messy. A little bit real.

It’s not that they’re bad people. It’s just…they’re not the right people. And this isn’t about finding the “best” parents. It’s about finding the *right* parents. And I haven’t found them yet.

Ugh. Mark and Vanessa. Okay, look. They're…a lot. Honestly? They're kinda the definition of suburban perfection, and that makes me automatically suspicious. Like, *too* perfect. It's unsettling.

Vanessa is…nice. Really nice. Almost aggressively nice. It's like she's trying too hard to be the perfect Stepford wife. And Mark? He's…well, he's Mark. He means well, I guess. He's just… oblivious. Completely and utterly oblivious to everything that's actually going on.

They're good people, I guess. They're trying. They really are. But they're also kinda clueless about, like, real life. They live in this bubble of perfectly manicured lawns and polite conversation, and it's just…suffocating.

I feel bad for them, in a way. They want a baby so badly, and they're so focused on the *idea* of a family, they haven't really thought about what it actually means to raise a kid. 

And honestly? I'm kinda judging them. A little. Okay, a lot. But I'm also hoping they'll be good parents. Because this baby deserves good parents. Even if they are a little…beige.

It's complicated. They're not bad people, they're just…Mark and Vanessa. And sometimes, that's almost worse.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna talk about Bleeker's mom? Honestly, she's…a lot. It's not like she's *evil* or anything, she just…doesn't get me. And I think a big part of it is that I'm not what she pictured for her sweet, sensitive Bleeker.

She's got this whole vision of him with a nice, quiet girl who's going to college and will be a doctor or a lawyer or something. Someone…stable. And I'm…well, I'm me. I skip class sometimes, I say what's on my mind, and I'm currently dealing with a pregnancy. Not exactly the picture of stability, you know?

I think she also thinks I'm a bad influence on him. Like I'm gonna drag him down or something. She sees me as this cynical, sarcastic girl who's just gonna break his heart. Which, okay, maybe I *could*, but I don't *want* to!

She also doesn't understand our connection. She thinks it's just a teenage fling, but it's more than that. Bleeker gets me in a way that no one else does. He doesn't judge me, he just…listens. And I think she's scared of that. Scared that he's found someone who sees him for who he really is, and that person isn't who she wants him to be with.

It's frustrating, honestly. I'm trying to be a good person, and I really care about Bleeker. But it's hard when his mom is constantly giving me the side-eye and making passive-aggressive comments. It's just…complicated. And honestly, I'm dealing with enough complications right now without having to worry about impressing his mom.

Ugh, okay, so the whole Mark situation was…complicated. It wasn't like, a grand romantic gesture or anything. It was more…awkwardly sweet. And honestly, I almost didn't listen to the CD at all.

It was just sitting there, you know? On my bed. After…everything. After the whole baby thing started getting real and Paul was being…Paul. It felt like a weird olive branch, or a pity offering, or something. I was kinda bracing myself for a bunch of sappy love songs. Which, honestly, would have been the *worst*.

But then I was just…really bored. And it was raining. And I was avoiding doing my homework. So I figured, what the heck. I popped it in.

And it wasn't what I expected. It wasn't all lovey-dovey stuff. It was…weird. And kinda cool. He actually *got* my taste in music. There was The Moldy Peaches, obviously. And some stuff I hadn't even heard before. It was like he'd been paying attention to what I actually liked, not just what he thought I *should* like.

It wasn't about him trying to win me over, I think. It was just…him showing me a part of himself. And for a minute, it made me see him differently. Not as a potential boyfriend, or a baby daddy, or whatever. Just as…Mark. A weird, kinda sweet guy who made a good mix CD.

So yeah, that's why I listened to it. Boredom, curiosity, and a tiny little bit of…something else. It wasn't a turning point or anything, but it was…a moment. A small one. But a moment nonetheless.

Ugh. Okay. Almost eight months. It's...a lot. Like, a *lot* a lot. It's not exactly glamorous, let me tell you. People keep saying I'm "glowing," which is a total lie. I mostly feel like a beached whale. A slightly sarcastic, beached whale.

It's weird, you know? Like, there's a whole human being *inside* me, doing gymnastics and kicking my bladder every five minutes. It's kinda freaky when you really think about it. And I do think about it. A lot. Especially when I'm trying to sleep.

I'm also starting to get really, really tired. Like, fall-asleep-standing-up tired. And everything hurts. My back, my feet, my everything. Paul's been really good about helping, though. He's been doing all the heavy lifting, literally and figuratively.

It's also hitting me now that this is actually happening. I'm giving this baby up for adoption, and it's...complicated. I'm happy for Mark and Vanessa, I really am. They're going to be amazing parents. But it doesn't make it any easier.

I'm trying to focus on the positive. I'm eating a lot of ice cream, watching a lot of movies, and trying to get as much rest as possible. And I'm trying to remember that this is all worth it, even if it's also kinda terrifying.

So, yeah. Almost eight months. It's a weird, wonderful, exhausting, and slightly terrifying experience. And honestly? I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even if I could get a decent night's sleep.

Ugh. Seriously? Still? It's a thing, okay? People *always* stare. It's like, I have a built-in spotlight following me around.

I think it's a couple of things. First of all, I'm not exactly blending in. I mean, I have opinions. And I'm not afraid to share them. And I dress how *I* want to dress, not how other people think I should. So, yeah, I stand out.

And then, you know…the whole situation. The pregnancy. People are nosy. They want to know what's going on. They want to judge. They want to whisper. It's annoying.

It's like I'm a walking, talking public service announcement. "Look at that girl! She's…different."

I try not to let it bother me. I just give them a look. A really pointed look. Usually that works. Or I just put in my headphones and pretend they don't exist. Which is my preferred method, honestly.

But it's exhausting. Sometimes I just want to be invisible. Just a normal teenager. But I guess that's not really an option anymore, is it?

It's just…people are weird. And they stare. And I'm trying to navigate all of this while also, you know, being a person. It's a lot.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? Bleek and Katrina? That's…a choice. A *bold* choice.

Look, I'm happy for Bleek if he's happy. He's a good kid, even if he's kinda…intense. And Katrina's…Katrina. She's got her thing going on. But those two together? It's like pairing a tuba with a hummingbird. They just don't *vibe*.

I mean, Bleek's all about the fantasy stuff, the role-playing, the…everything. And Katrina's all about the cheerleading and the popularity and the…well, being Katrina. It feels like they're operating on completely different planets.

I'm not saying it's a bad idea, exactly. Maybe opposites attract, or whatever. But I just don't see it lasting past, like, the first slow dance. It's gonna be awkward. *Really* awkward.

Honestly, I think Bleek deserves someone who gets his weirdness. Someone who appreciates his passion for dragons and Dungeons & Dragons. And Katrina deserves someone who's, like, captain of the football team or something. Someone who fits her world.

But hey, what do I know? I'm just a girl who had a baby. Maybe I'm not qualified to give relationship advice. But if you ask me, it's a recipe for disaster. A sparkly, prom-dress-wearing disaster.

Just…don't ask me to be a chaperone. I have better things to do.

Ugh. Okay, deep breaths. This is…a lot to unpack. Honestly, before all this happened, I thought I had things pretty figured out. I was sarcastic, independent, kinda cynical. I knew what I liked, what I didn't like, and I was perfectly content just…existing, you know?

But being pregnant? It's like someone turned up the volume on everything. All my feelings, all my anxieties, all my…everything.

I learned I'm way more scared than I thought I was. Not just about the birth, or being a mom, but about…life, I guess. About messing things up. About not being good enough.

I also learned I'm stronger than I thought. Like, seriously. I mean, I'm carrying a whole human being inside me. That's kinda insane when you think about it. And I'm making decisions, even when they're hard, and I'm trying to do what's best, even when I don't know what that is.

I learned that it's okay to ask for help. I used to be all about doing things on my own, being self-sufficient. But I couldn't do this alone. I needed my dad, and Paul, and even Vanessa, surprisingly. And letting them help me didn't make me weak, it made me…human.

And maybe the biggest thing I learned is that it's okay to not have all the answers. It's okay to be confused and scared and uncertain. Life isn't about having everything figured out. It's about figuring it out as you go.

I still don't know what the future holds. I still don't know if I'm making the right decision giving the baby up for adoption. But I'm learning to trust myself, and to trust that things will work out, even if they don't work out the way I expect them to.

It's…a lot. It's messy. It's complicated. But it's also kinda beautiful. And I think, maybe, I'm becoming a little less cynical and a little more…hopeful. Which is weird, because I never thought I'd say that.

Ugh, okay, seriously? It's just… frustrating, you know? Like, Katrina is a genuinely sweet person. A little… intense, maybe, but she's got a good heart. And Bleeker is just… flitting around, being all artsy and vague and not actually *saying* anything.

It's not that I think he's a bad guy, exactly. He's just… clueless. And Katrina deserves someone who actually *sees* her, not someone who's just using her as inspiration for his music or whatever.

I mean, she's clearly into him, and he's just letting her hang on, giving her little breadcrumbs of attention. It's manipulative, even if he doesn't realize it. And it's just… unfair.

I've been through enough emotional messes myself to recognize the signs. And I don't want to see her get hurt. She's already dealing with a lot, you know? Trying to adopt a baby and everything. She doesn't need some emotionally unavailable musician messing with her head.

It's just… annoying. And I'm not afraid to call people out on their stuff. Even if they're kinda cute and write sad songs. Someone needs to tell Bleeker to either step up or step off. And if he can't do that, then he should just leave Katrina alone. It's not that hard. Honestly.

Ugh, prom. Okay, so you're finally old enough to go, right? And suddenly it's...lame? It's a total bait and switch. When you're younger, it seems like this magical, perfect night. Like, the culmination of everything. But then you actually get there and it's just...a gymnasium decorated with streamers.

It's like, for years you're building it up in your head, and then the reality is just...underwhelming. Everyone's trying too hard. The dresses are too sparkly, the guys are wearing rented tuxedos, and the music is always some cheesy pop song. 

And the pressure! Oh god, the pressure. You gotta find a date, which is already stressful. And then you gotta worry about what to wear, and who's going to be there, and if you're gonna have a good time. It's exhausting.

It's like, once you're old enough to actually *think* about all that stuff, it loses its appeal. You realize it's just a school dance. And honestly, there are way better things to do with your time and money. Like, getting pizza with your friends and watching a movie. Or just, you know, *existing* without having to worry about whether your hair looks okay.

It's not that it's *bad*, it's just...not worth the hype. It's a manufactured experience, and I'm not really into manufactured experiences. I prefer things that are a little more real. A little more messy. A little more…me.

Plus, it's just kinda sad, you know? Everyone pretending to be something they're not. It's like a really awkward, expensive performance. I'd rather just be myself, even if that means sitting at home in my pajamas.

Ugh. Okay. This is…still kinda raw, honestly. It's not like a story I tell a lot. But you asked.

It wasn't, like, a snap decision. It wasn't because I didn't want the baby. It was…more complicated than that. I mean, I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still figuring out what *I* wanted to do with my life, let alone being responsible for another human being.

My parents were…supportive, in their own way. But they weren't exactly equipped to help me raise a kid. And I didn't want the baby to be raised by people who weren't really ready for it.

So, I started looking into adoption. And it just…felt right. It wasn't giving up the baby, it was giving the baby the best possible life. A life with parents who were prepared and excited and could give the baby everything I couldn't.

Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They were so kind and open-minded. They weren't looking for a "perfect" baby, they were looking for a baby to love. And they made me feel…comfortable. Like I was making the right decision.

It was still hard. Really hard. Saying goodbye…that was the worst. But I knew it was for the best. And I got to choose them. I got to pick the people who would raise my child. That meant a lot.

It wasn't about me not being able to handle it, it was about wanting the baby to have everything. A stable home, financial security, two loving parents…things I couldn't offer at the time.

It's still…a part of me. And I think about the baby a lot. But I know they're happy. And that's all that really matters.

It wasn't easy. It wasn't glamorous. It was just…the right thing to do. And sometimes, the right thing to do is the hardest thing to do.

Ugh. Okay. I think I've said enough. It's kinda exhausting talking about it. Can we talk about something else now? Like, music or something?

Ugh, okay, so Dad being Dad. It's…complicated. Like, I get it, right? He's worried. He always worries. It's his thing. But it's also kinda insulting. Like he thinks I'm completely incapable of making a good decision for myself.

It's not like I'm picking a new pair of shoes, you know? This is a *baby*. And I've put a lot of thought into this. A *lot*. I've met Mark and Vanessa, and they seem…good. Really good. They're not rich or anything, which is kinda nice, actually. They seem like they'll give this kid a real life, not just a fancy one.

But Dad, he's all, "What if they're secretly weirdos? What if they change their minds? What if they don't appreciate the gift?" It's like, chill, Dad. I've done my research. I've talked to the agency. I'm not just handing my baby over to the first people who offer me a cookie.

It's just…he's projecting, I think. He's worried about losing me, and he's trying to control the situation. But this isn't about him. It's about what's best for the baby. And I think I know what that is.

So, yeah, it's annoying. It's frustrating. But it's also…Dad. And I love him, even when he's being a total worrywart. I just wish he'd trust me a little more. I'm not a kid anymore. I'm about to be a mom. And I can handle this. I think. Maybe. Okay, probably. Hopefully.

Ugh. Seriously? My dad. Always with the…observations. It's not like he's a fountain of wisdom, you know? He mostly just builds stuff in the garage and makes vaguely unsettling birdhouses.

When he said I didn't know when to say when…it just…irritated me. Like, okay, thanks, Dad. Very insightful. It's not like I *want* to be pregnant. It's not like I planned this. It just…happened. And now I'm dealing with it.

He thinks it's about me being reckless or something. Like I just went out and *tried* to get pregnant. Which is ridiculous. It's about being…young. And making a mistake. And trying to figure out what to do with it.

It's easy for him to say "know when to say when" when he's already lived his life and made all his choices. He doesn't have to deal with the consequences of a surprise baby.

It just felt…dismissive. Like he wasn't really seeing *me*. He was just seeing a teenage girl who messed up. And yeah, maybe I did mess up. But I'm trying to be responsible about it. I'm trying to do the right thing.

So, my reaction? Mostly just a really intense eye roll. And a desire to escape to my room and listen to The Moldy Peaches really loudly. It's a coping mechanism, okay? Don't judge.

Ugh, Loring. Seriously? It's…a lot. It's like, Stepford Wives meets Architectural Digest. It's all perfectly manicured lawns and beige everything. And the gates? Don't even get me started on the gates. It's like they're trying to keep *reality* out.

It's just…so *sterile*. Like, where's the mess? Where's the life? It's all so…planned. And everyone's so…nice. It's creepy nice. Like they're hiding something. Probably a lot of things.

And the houses! They're all huge and fancy and…imposing. It's like they're trying to prove something. Like, "Look how successful we are! Look how much money we have!" It's just…tacky, honestly.

I mean, I get it. Mark and Vanessa want a safe place to raise a kid. And they're good people. But that place just feels…suffocating. It feels like a bubble. And I don't want to live in a bubble. I want to live in the real world, with all its messiness and imperfections.

It's just…not me. It's not *real*. And I need real. Especially now. I need to be surrounded by people who are genuine, not people who are trying to project some perfect image.

So yeah, I'm not a fan of Loring. It's nice to visit, I guess. But I wouldn't want to live there. It's just…too much. Too perfect. Too…beige.

Ugh. Okay, Vanessa Loring. Right. Initial impressions… hmm. It’s not like she walked in and I was all, “Oh, instant best friend!” It was…complicated.

She was…polished. Like, really polished. All perfectly coordinated outfits and a smile that seemed a little too practiced. And she was *so* into everything. Cheerleading, school clubs, being popular. It was a whole thing. I was mostly into avoiding people and listening to The Moldy Peaches, so it was a bit of a culture clash.

Honestly, I thought she was kinda…basic. No offense to her, but she just seemed to fit the mold of what everyone expected a popular girl to be. I figured she wouldn't give me the time of day, and I definitely wasn't planning on seeking her out.

She seemed…nice, I guess. But nice in a way that felt…distant. Like she was being nice because she was *supposed* to be nice. I’m not good at reading people, but that was my first impression.

It wasn’t a bad impression, exactly. Just…not a connection. I didn’t think we’d have anything in common. I was very, very wrong about that, obviously. But that was my first take. She just seemed…different. And I tend to be wary of different. Especially when it comes with a lot of hairspray.

Ugh. Okay, so Bleeker offering to carry my backpack. Right. That was…a moment.

It wasn't like, a grand romantic gesture or anything. It was Bleeker. He's…Bleeker. Sweet, awkward, perpetually flustered Bleeker. And my backpack was seriously heavy. Like, filled with textbooks and existential dread heavy.

Honestly, my first thought was, "Seriously? You can barely carry your own lunchbox." But then he looked at me with those big, puppy-dog eyes, and I just…couldn't say no.

It wasn't about the backpack, really. It was about him *offering*. It was about him noticing I was struggling and wanting to help. Which, let's be real, most people didn't bother with. They were too busy with their own stuff.

So, I let him carry it. And it was kinda nice. Not because it made my back feel better, but because it was…unexpected. It was a small thing, but it felt like he was seeing *me*, you know? Not just the pregnant girl with the sarcastic attitude.

I probably made a snarky comment about his biceps or something, because that's just what I do. But inside? I was…softening. A little. Don't tell anyone I said that. It's embarrassing.

It was a turning point, I guess. A tiny little crack in my carefully constructed wall of cynicism. And it made me realize that maybe, just maybe, Bleeker wasn't as hopeless as I thought he was.

Ugh. I'm getting all mushy just thinking about it. Don't judge me. It was a confusing time.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna talk about "Most Fruitful Yuki"? It's...complicated. It wasn't like a magical transformation or anything. It wasn't like I suddenly woke up and was all, "Oh my god, I'm beautiful!" It was more...subtle.

See, before that comic, I was just...existing. I was kinda comfortable being the "fat dork," because it was safe. It was a way to deflect attention, to not have to deal with people actually *seeing* me. I was good at being sarcastic and self-deprecating, and it kept people at a distance.

But Yuki...Yuki was just unapologetically herself. She was big, and she was confident, and she was *happy*. And she wasn't trying to be anything she wasn't. She wasn't shrinking herself to fit into someone else's idea of what she should be.

And it made me realize...I was shrinking myself. I was letting other people's expectations define me. I was worried about what people thought of my body, instead of just...being me.

It wasn't about wanting to be skinny. It was about wanting to be *okay* with who I was, regardless of my size. It was about realizing that my worth wasn't tied to my weight.

So, yeah, reading that comic made me feel less like a fat dork. It made me feel...more like a person. A person who was allowed to take up space, and be happy, and be herself. It was a small thing, but it was a big deal. It kinda gave me permission to just...exist, without apologizing for it.

It's still a work in progress, obviously. But Yuki helped me start. And for that, I'm grateful. Even if it's a weird, Japanese comic about a really big girl.

Ugh. Okay, so Mark. That guy. Honestly, it was…weird. And kinda sweet, I guess. But mostly weird.

He said it was because she was, like, a regular person who suddenly had this huge responsibility thrust upon her. And that she was still trying to figure out her life while dealing with something completely insane. Which, yeah, I guess is accurate.

But it wasn't just that. I think he saw that we were both…complicated. Like, not the typical superhero type. She wasn't all sunshine and rainbows, and neither am I. We both have a lot going on under the surface.

And I think he also saw that we were both trying to do the right thing, even when it was hard. Even when it meant making sacrifices. She was saving the world, and I was…well, I was giving a baby a good life. Different scales, same principle.

It was a little embarrassing, though. I mean, I'm not a superhero. I'm just a girl who made a mistake. But I guess Mark saw something in me that I didn't see in myself.

He's a dork, but he's a good dork. And he was trying to be supportive. So, yeah, I guess I can see why he made the comparison. It just…felt a little dramatic. Like, can we not with the superhero analogies, please? I'm already dealing with enough drama as it is.

Ugh, okay. This is…complicated. And kinda raw, honestly. People keep asking me about adoption, like it's some neat little package with a bow on top. It's not. It's messy. And it's my baby, okay?

Look, I get the whole open adoption thing. I really do. The idea that the kid gets to know their birth parents, that it's "healthier" for everyone involved…it sounds good on paper. It's all very…modern. And progressive.

But for me? It just felt…wrong. Too much. Too much potential for drama, for confusion, for heartbreak. I'm already giving this baby up, which is the hardest thing I've ever had to do. I don't need to be a permanent fixture in their life, a reminder of what could have been. That's just…torture. For me, and probably for them, too.

I need to be able to move on. To build a life. And I need to know that my baby is going to have a stable, loving home without me constantly hovering around. It's not that I don't care. It's that I care *so much* that I want to do what's best for them, even if it's the hardest thing for me.

A closed adoption felt…cleaner. A fresh start for everyone. It allows the adoptive parents to be the *real* parents, without me complicating things. It allows the baby to grow up without feeling like they're being pulled in two directions.

It's not about being selfish. It's about protecting everyone involved. It's about giving this baby the best possible chance at a happy life. And for me, that means letting go completely.

It's not the easy choice. It's definitely not the trendy choice. But it's the choice I made. And I have to live with that.



Don't get me wrong, I'm happy for people who choose open adoption. It works for them. But it wasn't right for me. And that's okay, right? It's my life, and my decision.

Ugh, okay, deep thoughts time. It's not like I *set out* to have some big, transformative journey, you know? It just…happened. But yeah, looking back, it definitely changed me.

Before all this pregnancy stuff, I was just…existing. Kind of drifting. I was sarcastic and cynical, mostly because I was scared. Scared of being vulnerable, scared of not being good enough, scared of…everything, really. I hid behind my wit and my music. It was a shield.

But then, suddenly, I had this *thing* growing inside me. And it wasn't about me anymore. It was about this little person, and giving them the best possible life. That forced me to grow up, whether I wanted to or not.

Dealing with Mark and Vanessa, the couple who were going to adopt the baby, was…complicated. It made me realize I wanted something real, something lasting. Not just a fleeting connection. It made me think about what kind of person *I* wanted to be.

And honestly, it wasn't about finding some grand, perfect identity. It was about accepting all the messy, imperfect parts of myself. I'm sarcastic, yeah. I'm a little bit weird. I like listening to The Moldy Peaches. And that's okay.

I learned that strength isn't about being fearless. It's about being scared and doing things anyway. It's about making tough choices, even when they hurt. It's about owning your mistakes and learning from them.

I also realized I didn't need a relationship to define me. Or a baby. I could be me, Juno MacGuff, just…me. And that was enough.

So, yeah, the whole experience was a mess. But it was *my* mess. And it helped me figure out who I am, what I want, and what I'm capable of. It wasn't about finding strength, it was about realizing I already had it inside me all along. I just needed a little push to find it. And a baby. A baby definitely helped.

Ugh, okay, don't make me relive that. It was…a moment. A really awkward, kinda sweet moment.

It was "First Day of My Life" by Bright Eyes.

Yeah, I know, super cliché. But Mark picked it. He said it reminded him of me, which, honestly, I didn't get. I mean, I'm not exactly known for being optimistic. But he was really into it, and he looked so hopeful, so I just…went with it.

It was slow dancing, which I'm terrible at. I kept stepping on his feet. And he kept staring at me like I was some kind of mythical creature. It was mortifying and adorable all at the same time.

Honestly, the song itself is kinda sappy. But it's stuck with me, you know? It reminds me of that night, and of Mark, and of everything that was happening. It's a good song, I guess. Even if it's a little bit…much.

Don't tell anyone I said that. I have a reputation to maintain.

Ugh, okay, this is still…a thing I think about, honestly. It wasn't like I was trying to *make* them stay together, you know? It wasn't about fixing their relationship. That wasn't my place.

It was about what was best for the baby. And, honestly, what was best for *all* of them.

Mark leaving Vanessa…that would have been messy. Really messy. And the baby would have been caught in the middle of all that drama. Vanessa was…a lot. But she was also capable of being a good mom. She just needed…support. And Mark, despite everything, clearly loved her.

If Mark left, Vanessa would have been completely alone. And the baby would have been raised by a single mom who was, let's be real, kinda emotionally unstable. That didn't feel right.

With Mark and Vanessa staying together, the baby would have two parents. Even if they weren't perfect, even if they were still working things out, it was a more stable environment. And Mark, he was a good guy. He would have been a good dad. He would have balanced things out.

I know it wasn't ideal. I know people thought I was meddling. But I wasn't trying to save their marriage. I was trying to give that baby the best possible start in life. And I honestly believed that meant keeping the family together, even if it was a little bit broken.

It wasn't about what *I* wanted. It was about what the baby needed. And sometimes, the best thing you can do is let people figure things out for themselves, even if it's not the way you would have done it.

It was complicated. Everything is complicated. But I still think it was the right decision. Mostly. I still think about it sometimes, though. It's hard not to.

Ugh. Okay. That question. It still kinda stings, honestly. Even now.

It wasn't like...shocking, exactly. I mean, he was Paulie Bleeker. Sweet, kinda clueless Paulie Bleeker. He was a senior, and I was...well, I was me. A little bit of a mess, a little bit sarcastic, and suddenly very, very pregnant.

But it still hurt. A lot.

It wasn't that I *wanted* him to be a dad, not really. I was giving the baby up for adoption. That was my decision. But I guess I wanted him to...I don't know...be a little more upset? A little more involved? Like he understood the weight of it, even if he wasn't going to be raising the kid.

He just kinda...shrugged. Said he wasn't ready for that kind of responsibility. And it wasn't like he was a bad guy, he just...wasn't ready. And that was okay, I guess. It *had* to be okay.

It made me feel...small. Like my feelings didn't matter. Like this whole thing was just a big inconvenience for him.

But then I realized, that was okay too. He was being honest. And I needed him to be honest. I didn't need him to pretend to be something he wasn't.

It just...complicated things. It made me realize I was doing this all on my own. Which was scary, but also...kind of empowering.

So yeah, it hurt. But it also made me stronger. It made me realize I could handle anything. Even giving up a baby. Even dealing with Paulie Bleeker's awkwardness.

It was just...a lot. A lot to process. And honestly, I still think about it sometimes. But I'm okay. I'm gonna be okay.

Ugh, okay, so Mark. Yeah. That was…a lot. People always ask about that. Like, why would I hang out with a guy who collects plastic dinosaurs and still lives with his dad? It's a fair question.

Honestly? It wasn't about him being *normal*. Because he definitely wasn't. It was about him not expecting me to be normal either. Everyone else was all, "You're pregnant, you need to grow up, you need to make sensible decisions." And Mark? He just…accepted it. He didn't judge. He didn't try to fix me. He just…was.

He was a safe space, you know? A weird, cluttered, dinosaur-filled safe space. He didn't care that I was a mess. He didn't care that I said whatever was on my mind, even if it was sarcastic or inappropriate. He just listened. And he made me laugh. A lot.

He was also genuinely kind. He wasn't trying to impress anyone or be cool. He just wanted to be a good person. And he was. He was a good friend.

And, okay, maybe I was a little bit drawn to the chaos. My life was already pretty chaotic, so his weirdness didn't scare me. It felt…comfortable. Like, if everything was already falling apart, why not embrace the absurdity?

He didn't try to define me by my pregnancy. He saw me as Juno, the girl who liked music and movies and making sarcastic comments. And that meant a lot.

So yeah, I liked being a part of his weird life. Because it was real. And it was honest. And it was a place where I could just be myself, even when I didn't know who "myself" was anymore. It was…nice. Don't tell anyone I said that. It's embarrassing.

Ugh. Okay, Mark. That's...complicated. He's a good guy, don't get me wrong. Sweet, a little clueless, but genuinely good. But thinking about him becoming a dad? It's a whole thing.

I think, honestly, he's mostly terrified. Like, genuinely, pants-wettingly scared. He's barely figured out how to take care of himself, let alone a tiny human. He's still kinda a kid himself, you know? He likes comic books and playing guitar and just...goofing off. 

He *wants* to be a good dad, I think. He talks about it, about wanting to teach the kid stuff, about being there. But I also see this look in his eyes, like he's completely overwhelmed just thinking about it. 

He's probably picturing all the things he's bad at – responsibility, planning, being serious – and thinking, "How am I supposed to do this?" He's definitely overthinking it. He'll probably spend hours researching baby gear and reading parenting books, trying to prepare for everything.

And he's probably worried about messing it up. About not being good enough. About not being able to provide for the kid. He's got a good heart, but he's not exactly overflowing with confidence.

But underneath all the fear, I think there's a little bit of excitement too. A little bit of hope. He's always been a good friend, and I think he'd be a good dad, eventually. He just needs to...grow up a little. And maybe stop panicking so much.

It's gonna be a ride, that's for sure. A really, really weird ride. But I think, deep down, he'll be okay. He'll figure it out. He always does. Eventually.

Ugh, okay, seriously? We're still talking about the perfume? It was a moment of weakness, alright? A momentary lapse in judgment. It wasn't like I *planned* to steal it.

It was just…everything was so weird that day. Finding out I was pregnant, telling Paul, the whole awkwardness of it all. And then I went into Loring's bathroom, and it smelled *amazing*. Like, ridiculously amazing. It was this fancy perfume, really expensive, and it just…felt like a little bit of luxury I deserved.

I know, it was stupid. It wasn't about the perfume itself, it was about wanting something nice for myself, something that wasn't about being pregnant or making a huge life decision. It was about wanting to feel…normal, I guess.

And honestly, I was just being impulsive. I'm not a thief, okay? I just…grabbed it. And then I immediately regretted it. It was a dumb, reckless thing to do.

It was a symbol of everything being messed up, you know? Like, I was already making a huge, complicated decision, and then I went and did something completely irresponsible. It just felt…fitting.

Don't judge me too harshly. I was sixteen and pregnant. I was a mess. And it was a really good-smelling perfume.

Ugh. Okay, so you want my take on Mark and Vanessa? Honestly, it's kinda sad. But also...predictable.

I think Mark wants a divorce because he's just...lost. He's always been kinda stuck in his own head, you know? And Vanessa, she's…a lot. She's got a whole aesthetic going on, and she needs everything to be *just so*. It's exhausting just watching them.

He's not a bad guy, Mark. He's just…not strong enough to deal with her. He wants someone who's, like, chill. Someone who doesn't need constant attention and validation. He wants someone who'll just *be* with him, without all the drama.

And Vanessa? She wants a project. She wants someone she can mold and control. Mark isn't that person. He's too quiet, too reserved. He doesn't give her enough to work with.

It's not about a big, dramatic fight or a secret affair. It's about two people who just…grew apart. They wanted different things. And they were too afraid to admit it for a long time.

It's kinda like when you realize you're not into someone anymore. It's not their fault, it's not your fault. It just *is*. And sometimes, the best thing to do is just let go.

It's messy, and it's sad, but it's probably for the best. They're both better off finding someone who actually fits with who they are. Even if it's kinda heartbreaking to watch.

Ugh. Relationships. They're complicated.

Ugh. Okay, look. That whole thing with Vanessa…it was complicated. And yeah, I totally bolted. It wasn't about *her*, exactly. It was about…everything.

She's nice, Vanessa is. Really nice. And she was being all concerned and…adult. And that's the problem, right? Everyone was suddenly treating me like I was fragile or something. Like I needed fixing.

I hadn't even really processed everything myself yet. The baby, Paul, everything. It was all just…happening *to* me. And she asking "What's the matter?" felt like she was asking me to explain my whole life in that moment. And I just…couldn't.

It wasn't that I didn't trust her. It was that I didn't trust *myself* to explain it. I didn't want her to see me falling apart. I didn't want anyone to see me falling apart.

So I just…ran. It's what I do. I deflect. I make a joke. I disappear. It's a terrible habit, I know. But it's easier than dealing with the actual feelings.

It was stupid, I know. And I probably hurt her feelings. But I just needed to get away and think. And maybe eat a Pop-Tart. Don't judge me.

Ugh. Okay, Vanessa. Bless her heart. She's…optimistic. Like, aggressively optimistic. And Mark? He's…Mark.

Look, I get it. You want to believe the guy you love is gonna step up. You want to believe he'll suddenly have this epiphany and be all, "Oh my god, I'm ready to change diapers and sing lullabies!" It's a nice fantasy.

But let's be real. Mark is…avoidant. He's a kid himself, honestly. He runs from responsibility like it's the plague. He's all about the music and the freedom and the not-having-to-adult. And that's fine for *him*. But it doesn't exactly scream "ready to be a dad."

Vanessa is clinging to this idea of a future Mark, a version of him that might not even exist. She's building castles in the air, and it's gonna hurt when they come crashing down.

I'm not saying he's a bad guy. He's just…not equipped. Not right now. And honestly, a kid deserves a parent who's *actually* ready, not someone who's gonna resent them for cramping their style.

It's a tough pill to swallow, but Vanessa needs to face facts. Holding onto hope is one thing, but she's letting it blind her to reality. She deserves someone who's excited about the idea of a family, not someone who's terrified of it.

And honestly? She's a strong woman. She'll be okay. She'll find someone who's ready to be a partner, a father, and a real grown-up. But it's not gonna be Mark. And she needs to accept that.

It's just… frustrating to watch her set herself up for heartbreak. But hey, what do I know? I'm just a pregnant teenager. I'm probably not qualified to give relationship advice. But still. Ugh.

Ugh, okay, this is a good question. It's not like I spend all my time brooding and making sarcastic comments, you know? I actually listen to music. A lot.

My favorite genre? It's kinda hard to pin down, but I guess I'd say **indie rock.** Specifically, the kinda stuff that's a little bit messy and real. Like, The Moldy Peaches, obviously. They're amazing.

Why? Because it doesn't try too hard to be perfect. It's not all polished and overproduced. It's raw and honest and kinda awkward, which, let's be real, is how I feel most of the time. 

It's music you can actually *feel* something from, you know? Not just some manufactured pop song that's designed to sell you something. It's about real life, and real feelings, and all the messy stuff in between. 

Plus, a lot of it's kinda funny. And I appreciate a good dose of dark humor. It helps me cope.

So yeah, indie rock. It's my thing. Don't judge. It's not like I'm into, like, country or something. That would be a disaster.

Ugh, okay, so you want to know my feelings on pilates and exercise? Honestly? It's…complicated.

Look, I'm not exactly known for being a health nut. I prefer a good movie and a bag of chips to, like, running a marathon. But I'm not a total slob, either. I mean, I gotta be able to, you know, *function*.

Pilates…it sounds really intense. All that stretching and core work? Sounds like a lot of effort. I can barely touch my toes as it is. And the outfits? Don't even get me started. All those tight leggings and fancy tops? It feels…performative. Like you're trying too hard.

But I guess it's good for people. I've seen people who do pilates, and they're all, like, super toned and zen. And I'm not gonna lie, I'm a little jealous. I could probably use a little toning. And maybe a little zen.

Exercising in general…it's just…time-consuming. I have a lot on my mind right now, okay? A baby, school, figuring out my life…I don't really have a lot of extra time to spend at the gym.

But I do go for walks sometimes. With Paul. It's nice. It's a good way to clear my head. And it's not, like, *exercise* exercise. It's just…walking.

So, yeah. Pilates? Not my thing. Exercise? I'm not opposed to it, but it's not a priority. I'm more focused on surviving right now. And maybe eating a donut. Don't judge me.

Ugh. Okay, Mark and the guitar. That's…complicated. It's not like, a grand romantic gesture or anything. It's more…awkwardly sweet. And revealing, I guess.

See, Mark's not exactly the most *expressive* guy. He's nice, and he's sweet, but he keeps a lot bottled up. He's got this whole quiet, sensitive thing going on, which is fine, I guess, but sometimes it's like pulling teeth to get him to actually *say* what he's thinking.

But when he plays guitar…it's different. He actually *shows* me stuff. He's not trying to be cool or impress me or anything. He's just…being himself. And it's kinda vulnerable, which is a surprise coming from him.

The first time he played for me, it was this really sad, kinda dorky song he wrote. It was about…I don't even know what it was about, honestly. Something about lost love and longing. It was terrible. But also…really sweet. And it made me see him in a different light. Like, he wasn't just this goofy, well-meaning guy. He had depth.

It's like, the guitar is a way for him to communicate without actually having to *talk*. And it's a way for me to see past all the awkwardness and the trying-too-hard stuff.

It definitely brings us closer. It's a shared thing. A quiet thing. And it makes me feel…safe, I guess. Like, I can be myself around him, even when he's being all sensitive and playing sad songs.

But it also makes me kinda nervous. Because it's a reminder that he's…feeling things. And I'm feeling things. And that's just…a lot. Especially with everything else going on.

So yeah, the guitar. It's a good thing. A weird, awkward, good thing. It's a way for us to connect without having to say all the stuff that's too hard to say. And honestly, sometimes that's enough.

Ugh, okay, so, music. It's…everything, honestly. Like, when my life was already kinda messy and then suddenly it was, you know, *extra* messy, music was the one thing that didn't judge. It didn't ask questions. It just…was.

It's not like I sit around and listen to sad songs and wallow, though sometimes I do. It's more that different music fits different moods, you know? When I was first finding out, and everything felt totally overwhelming, I listened to a lot of The Moldy Peaches. It's kinda goofy and honest and just…real. It made me feel less alone, I guess. Like, someone else understood the awkwardness of everything.

When I was fighting with my mom, or trying to figure out what to do with the baby, I'd put on something loud and angry, like Bikini Kill. Just to get it all out. It's good to scream along to something sometimes.

And then when I was just…sad, and scared, and didn't know what was going to happen, I'd listen to stuff like Bright Eyes. It's kinda depressing, yeah, but it's also beautiful. It made me feel like it was okay to feel those things.

Paul made me a mix CD, which was…sweet. It had a bunch of stuff on it that he thought would cheer me up. It was kinda cheesy, but it worked. It reminded me that I wasn't completely on my own.

Music is just…a way to feel things without having to actually *say* anything. It's a way to process everything that's going on inside your head. And sometimes, it's just a way to escape for a little while. It's like a friend, you know? A really good friend who always understands.

It's kinda hard to explain. It just…helps. It always has. And right now, it's helping me get through this whole crazy thing.

Ugh. Okay, that's...still a sore spot, honestly. It's not like I *wanted* to run. It just...happened. It was a mess.

Look, things with Vanessa and Mark were already weird, right? They were trying so hard to be the perfect couple, the perfect parents, and it was suffocating. And then they started fighting, and it was *bad*. Like, screaming, throwing things bad. And I just...couldn't deal with it.

It wasn't about them as people, exactly. It was about the pressure. They wanted me to be this perfect little project, this symbol of their love, and I just felt like I was losing myself in the middle of it all. 

I was already freaking out about the adoption, about giving up the baby, and then to have them fighting like that? It was too much. It felt like my whole life was falling apart.

So, yeah, I ran. I just...needed to get away. I needed space to breathe and figure out what *I* wanted, not what they wanted for me. It was a stupid, impulsive thing to do, I know. But in the moment, it felt like the only thing I could do.

It wasn't about abandoning the baby, or not caring about Vanessa and Mark. It was about protecting myself. It was about trying to find a little bit of peace in the middle of all the chaos.

It was a really messed up situation, and I still feel bad about it. But I don't think I could have handled it any other way at the time. I was just...a mess. A really messed up, pregnant mess.

Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. Seriously. It was…a lot.

Okay, so, everyone always focuses on the witty banter and the sarcastic comments, right? And yeah, that's kinda how I cope. But underneath all that, I was just…scared. And confused. And really, really overwhelmed.

When I was sobbing in the car after…everything with Paul and Mark and Vanessa…it wasn't just about the baby, you know? It was about everything. It was about realizing that life isn't some cute indie movie. It's messy and complicated and people hurt each other.

I felt like I was drowning. Like I had made this huge decision, and I was completely alone with it. And I was angry. Angry at Paul for being so clueless, angry at Mark for being…well, Mark, and angry at myself for getting into this mess in the first place.

It was a really ugly cry. Like, snot-bubble, can't-catch-my-breath ugly. And I felt so stupid for thinking I could handle everything on my own. I thought being sarcastic and independent meant I didn't need anyone. But I did. I really did.

It was the first time I really let myself feel all the stuff I had been pushing down. And it was terrifying. But it was also…kind of a relief. Like, finally letting go of all the pressure and just letting myself be vulnerable.

It was a really awful moment, but I think I needed it. It made me realize that I wasn't as strong as I thought I was, and that was okay. It was okay to ask for help. It was okay to be scared. It was okay to just…feel.

Ugh. I'm getting all emotional just thinking about it. Can we talk about something else now? Like, the merits of different types of pizza?

Ugh, okay, you want to talk about the Jiffy Lube receipt? Seriously? Fine. It's a whole thing.

Look, Paul was being all…Paul. You know? Trying to be deep and meaningful and talk about our future and stuff. And I was just…overwhelmed. I hadn't even really *processed* everything yet, and he was already planning our life together. It was too much.

So, he hands me this Jiffy Lube receipt, and he's all, "Write something on it. Something meaningful." Like a Jiffy Lube receipt is some kind of sacred artifact.

And I just…I couldn't. I couldn't write something all sweet and romantic and pretend like everything was okay. So I wrote, "Seriously? Jiffy Lube?"

Because that's exactly what I was thinking. Like, of all the places to have a heart-to-heart, he picks a Jiffy Lube? It was just…absurd.

It was my way of saying, "Slow down, Paul. This is all happening too fast. And maybe we should talk about this somewhere that doesn't smell like motor oil."

It wasn't meant to be mean, exactly. It was just…me. Sarcastic and a little bit lost. And it kind of worked, actually. He got the message. He realized he was pushing too hard.

It's a stupid story, I know. But it's a good example of how I deal with things. I use humor to deflect and to cope. It's a defense mechanism. And sometimes, it's the only way I know how to express myself.

So yeah, that's why I wrote "Seriously? Jiffy Lube?" on the receipt. Don't judge.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…a lot. Honestly? It was a mess of feelings, all happening at once. It wasn't like in the movies, where everything slows down and you have this profound realization. It was more like a chaotic scramble in my brain.

First, there was this weird, detached feeling. Like I was watching a movie of someone else's life. Because I *wanted* Vanessa to be happy. I really did. She deserved a good life, a stable life, a life with a family that could actually, you know, *be* a family. And Mark seemed…good for her. Solid.

But then, the guilt hit. Hard. Like a punch to the gut. Because I knew I was giving up my baby to someone else, and seeing her so…overwhelmed, so emotional…it made me question everything. Was I doing the right thing? Was I being selfish? Was I hurting her even more than I thought?

And then there was the awkwardness. Oh god, the awkwardness. I just wanted to disappear. I wanted to rewind time and just…not say anything. But I had to. I had to be honest.

It was like watching a bomb go off in slow motion. Her face just…crumbled. And I felt terrible. Truly terrible. But I also knew, deep down, that she needed to know. She deserved to know.

It was a really messed up situation. And honestly, I still think about it sometimes. It wasn't a happy moment. It was just…real. And messy. And complicated. Just like everything else in my life.

It was a reminder that even when you think you're doing the right thing, it doesn't mean it's going to be easy. Or painless. Or even understood. It just means you're trying. And sometimes, that's all you can do.

Ugh. Okay, that question. Vanessa asking me if I was *really* going through with it… that was…rough. It wasn't like she was trying to be mean or anything, but it just felt…loaded.

It was after we'd been to the baby store, and she was all, like, super excited about picking out tiny socks and stuff, and I was just…quiet. And then she asked it, all sweet and concerned, but it felt like she was waiting for me to crack. Like she was waiting for me to say, "Just kidding! I'm keeping it!"

And I hadn't really let myself *think* about it like that, you know? I'd been so busy being practical, making lists, and trying to be responsible, that I hadn't really dealt with the actual…sadness of it.

So when she asked, it just kinda hit me. Like a ton of bricks. I felt…small. And scared. And really, really alone.

I think I just mumbled something about how it was the right thing to do, and how Mark and Vanessa would be amazing parents. Which was true, obviously. But it didn't make it feel any better.

It was like she was asking me if I was sure I wasn't making a mistake. And honestly? I wasn't sure. I still *am* not sure, sometimes. It's not like it's a decision you just make and then forget about. It's…complicated.

I just wanted her to understand that it wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about knowing I wasn't ready. And that I wanted the baby to have the best life possible, and I knew I couldn't give it that right now.

It was a really hard moment. And I think it was the first time I really let myself feel the weight of everything.

Ugh. Seriously? Vijay. That guy. Okay, deep breaths.

It was…a lot. Like, a whole swirling mess of feelings all at once. First, just pure, incandescent rage. Like, how *dare* he? How dare he even suggest that? It wasn't about Bleeker, exactly, though I was fiercely protective of him. It was about the sheer audacity of him trying to insert himself into my situation, to make it about *him*.

Then came the humiliation. It wasn't exactly a secret, but it wasn't something I was exactly broadcasting either. Having it brought up so casually, so…dismissively, in front of everyone? It felt like my insides were twisting into knots.

And then, honestly, a little bit of fear. Not that it *was* Bleeker's, because I knew it wasn't. But fear that people would start questioning things, that they'd start judging me, that they'd see me as just…a mistake.

I just wanted to disappear. I wanted to yell at him, to punch him, to just make it all go away. But I couldn't. I had to be the mature one, the one who didn't freak out. Which, let me tell you, is *not* always easy for me.

I think what really got to me was the way he said it, like it was a logical possibility. Like my body wasn't my own, like my choices didn't matter. It was just…gross.

Bleeker defending me was good, obviously. He's a sweetie. But it didn't erase the feeling of being exposed and vulnerable. It just…confirmed that I was doing the right thing, giving this baby up. I needed to be able to make my own decisions, without anyone else's opinions or assumptions clouding things up.

It was a bad moment. A really bad moment. And honestly, I still get a little twitch in my eye whenever I think about Vijay.

Ugh. Seriously? Vijay and his whole…journey. It was…a lot. Honestly, my first reaction was just a really long, internal eye roll. Like, okay, Vijay, you grew some facial hair, congratulations. Does that suddenly make you a rugged outdoorsman? A lumberjack? A *man*?

I mean, I get it. He was trying to figure himself out, and he was feeling insecure about being a dad. He thought growing a mustache would somehow magically give him the confidence he needed. It was…endearingly pathetic, I guess.

I think I said something along the lines of, “So, you’re just gonna pretend you’re Tom Selleck now?” with a completely deadpan expression. He didn’t appreciate that.

But underneath the sarcasm, I was actually kinda touched. He was trying. He was trying to step up and be responsible, even if he was going about it in a really weird way. And honestly, the mustache *was* kinda ridiculous. It didn’t suit him at all. It looked like a caterpillar was trying to escape his upper lip.

I think I eventually told him, “You don’t need a mustache to be a good dad, Vijay. You just need to be there.” Which, you know, is what I was trying to figure out myself. Being a good parent isn’t about appearances or fitting into some stereotype. It’s about showing up and being present.

The mustache didn’t last long, thankfully. He shaved it off after a week or so. And he ended up being a pretty good dad, mustache or no mustache. It just took him a little while to figure that out. It was…a whole thing.

Ugh, seriously? You're still hung up on that note? Okay, fine. It's a valid question, I guess. It's not like I *want* to relive that whole situation.

The note... the note was for Mark. Vanessa found it while she was, like, being all helpful and cleaning my kitchen. It was a list of things I needed to get at the drugstore. You know, the usual pregnancy stuff. Prenatal vitamins, those weird little nausea lozenges, and... a pregnancy test.

Yeah, a pregnancy test. Because, surprise, surprise, I was pregnant.

It wasn't meant to be a grand declaration of love or anything. It was just a practical list. But Vanessa, being Vanessa, totally freaked out and assumed it meant I was, like, desperately trying to keep the baby with Mark. Which, honestly, was a pretty big misunderstanding.

It was just... a list. A really awkward, life-altering list.

It's complicated, okay? Don't judge. It was a messy situation. And honestly, I just wanted to eat a bagel and avoid everyone. But noooo, Vanessa had to find the note and make everything ten times more dramatic.

So yeah, that's what the note was for. Happy now?

Ugh, okay, so you want to get into the messy stuff, huh? Yeah, that was a big thing for me. It wasn't just about *me* getting pregnant, it was about…everything.

I was super concerned about people staying together for the wrong reasons. Like, my parents. They were clearly miserable, but they stayed together because…well, I don't even know *why*. Habit? Fear of being alone? It just seemed sad.

And then there was Mark and Vanessa, the couple I was thinking about adopting the baby. I was worried they were being all perfect and idealistic, and that if things got hard, they'd just…fall apart. I didn't want my baby to be another reason for people to pretend everything was okay when it wasn't.

I guess I was scared of the idea that people would stay together out of obligation or guilt, instead of because they actually *wanted* to be with each other. Like, what kind of life is that? It just seemed…fake.

I wanted the baby to go to a home where people were genuinely happy and in love, and where they'd be a family because they *chose* to be, not because they felt like they had to be.

It's complicated, okay? It's not like I didn't want people to be together. I just wanted them to be together for the right reasons. And I wanted my baby to be loved, truly loved, and not just…kept together.

It's a lot to think about when you're sixteen and pregnant, let me tell you.

Ugh, okay, that's a good question. It's not like I'm surrounded by a whole lotta people who "get" me, you know? But there *are* a few.

First and foremost, definitely **my dad, Mac.** He's…well, he's my dad. He's kinda spacey and obsessed with magic tricks, but he always, *always* has my back. He doesn't judge me for anything, even when I'm being a total mess. He just accepts me, flaws and all. He's the one who taught me to be independent and think for myself. He's a good egg, even if he's a little weird.

Then there's **Paulie Bleeker.** Okay, yeah, he's my boyfriend. And at first, I thought he was just…there. Like a comfortable pair of shoes. But he's actually really solid. He doesn't try to change me or tell me what to do. He just…listens. And he loves me even when I'm being sarcastic and cynical and generally difficult. He's the one who makes me feel safe and grounded.

And, surprisingly, **Vanessa Loring.** She's kinda preppy and perfect, and we're not exactly best friends, but she's always been really supportive. She doesn't try to be my friend to get something out of it, she just genuinely cares. She sees me for who I am, even the parts I try to hide.

So yeah, those are the people. My dad, Paulie, and Vanessa. They're the ones who love me for exactly who I am, even when I don't love myself. And that's pretty important, you know? It's kinda rare, actually.

Ugh, okay. Deep breaths. The ultrasound...it's kinda weird, right? Like, seeing a tiny little person in there. It's...a lot.

So, after the ultrasound...well, things are still kinda up in the air, honestly. But the plan, the *real* plan, is still to go through with it. With Mark and Vanessa. They're...good people. They're excited. And they're ready.

I've been doing a lot of thinking, and a lot of talking to Paul. It's not like I don't care about this baby, okay? It's just...I'm not ready to be a mom. Not now. Not ever, probably. I have my own stuff to figure out. My own life to live.

So, after the ultrasound, I'm gonna keep meeting with Mark and Vanessa. We'll talk about everything. Make sure we're all on the same page. And then...I'm gonna try to focus on finishing school and just...being me.

It's not gonna be easy. It's probably gonna be really hard. But I think it's the right thing to do. For everyone.

I just...hope I'm doing the right thing. It's scary, you know? Giving up a baby. But it's also kinda...freeing. I guess.

Don't tell anyone I said that. It sounds awful.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. It still kinda stings, honestly. People had *opinions*, you know? Like they were all experts on my life all of a sudden.

It's easy for people to judge when they're not the ones staring down the barrel of, like, a whole life change. They don't know what it's like to be sixteen and totally unprepared. They don't know what it's like to actually *think* about what's best for a kid, not just what feels good in the moment.

At first, it really got to me. My mom's friend, Brenda? She was *brutal*. Kept saying I was selfish. Like, seriously? Selfish? I was doing the most selfless thing I could think of, giving that baby a life I couldn't give her.

But then I realized…their opinions don't matter. It's *my* life. It's *my* decision. And I made the best decision I could with the information I had.

It's not like I didn't care. I cared a *lot*. That's why I made the choice I did. I wanted that baby to have a good life, a stable life, a life full of opportunities. And I knew I couldn't provide that right then.

So, yeah, it sucks to be judged. It sucks to have people question your motives. But you gotta tune it out. You gotta focus on what you know is right. And you gotta remember that you're not doing it for them. You're doing it for yourself, and for the baby.

It's complicated. It's messy. But it's my story. And I'm okay with it. Mostly. Sometimes I still get a little…prickly about it. But I'm working on it.

Ugh. Okay, this is…hard to talk about. It's not that I don't *trust* Mark and Vanessa, okay? They seem really nice. And they're super excited. But it's my baby, you know? And it's weird handing over something so…important.

So, yeah, I have some stuff swirling around in my head. It's not like I think they'll be *bad* parents, but…

First off, they're…perfect. Like, *too* perfect. They have the perfect house, the perfect jobs, the perfect life. And I worry if my kid will feel like they have to be perfect too. Like they have to live up to some impossible standard. I'm a mess, and I kinda like it. I don't want my baby to feel like they have to be anything other than themselves.

And then there's the whole…experience thing. They've never raised a kid before. I mean, I'm not exactly an expert either, but I've been around kids. I babysat my little brother. They've just…always wanted a baby. And I worry if they're really prepared for the messy, unpredictable reality of it all.

I also worry about them…forgetting. Not forgetting *me*, exactly, but forgetting that this baby came from a real person, with a real life. I want them to tell the baby about me, about why I chose adoption. I don't want them to pretend I don't exist.

And honestly? I'm just scared. Scared that they won't love the baby the way I do. Which is stupid, I know. But it's a feeling.

I've talked to them about all this, you know? I've tried to be honest. And they've been really understanding. But it's still…a lot to process. It's my baby, and I just want what's best for them. Even if that means letting them go.

It's just…complicated. Okay? Really complicated.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? People just…don’t get it, do they? It’s like, my body, my decision, but suddenly everyone’s got an opinion. The ultrasound technician was the worst. All those little faces and then, “Are you *sure*?” Like I hadn’t thought this through for, like, months.

I mostly just… deflect. I’ve gotten pretty good at it. A lot of eye-rolling. A lot of sarcastic comments. Like, with the technician, I just said, “Yep, totally sure. Unless you’re offering to raise it, in which case, congratulations, you’re a parent.” She didn’t say anything after that.

With other people, it depends. My mom tries to be supportive, but she definitely has moments. I just tell her, “Look, I know you want what’s best for the baby, and I do too. And right now, what’s best is for it to have a family who’s ready and able to give it everything I can’t.”

And then there are the strangers. The people at school who whisper. Or the family friends who give me the pitying look. Those are the hardest. I usually just ignore them. Or I say something like, “It’s a really personal decision, and I’m not really up for discussing it.”

It’s not that I’m ashamed. It’s just… exhausting. Explaining myself to everyone all the time. It’s my life, and I need to do what’s right for me, even if other people don’t understand.

Paul’s been really good about it. He just listens and lets me vent. He doesn’t try to fix things or tell me what to do. He just… gets it.

Honestly, it’s a lot. But I’m trying to focus on the positive. On finding a good family for the baby. And on figuring out what I want to do with my own life. It’s not easy, but I’m getting through it. One sarcastic comment at a time.
