Ugh. Okay. That's…a hard one to talk about. It wasn't like in the movies, you know? It wasn't all instant love and gooey feelings. It was…complicated.

When I first saw it, on the screen, it looked like…a little alien. Like a blurry, gray blob. And honestly, my first thought was, "Oh. *That's* me?" It was weird. Really weird. It didn't feel real.

There was definitely shock. And a lot of…panic. Like, "Oh my god, this is actually happening. I'm going to be a mom." Which is terrifying when you're sixteen and still trying to figure out what you want to *eat* for dinner.

But then…then it moved. Just a little flicker. And something shifted. It wasn't love, not yet. It was more like…responsibility. A huge, overwhelming weight of responsibility. And a little bit of…protectiveness. Like, this tiny little thing was depending on me, and I couldn't mess it up.

It was also really sad, I guess. Because I knew I wasn't going to be raising it. I knew I was giving it to another family. And that was…a really hard thing to process.

So, it wasn't a magical moment. It was messy and confusing and a little bit scary. But it was also…real. And that's what mattered. It was the first time I really understood that this wasn't just some abstract thing anymore. It was a person. My person. And I needed to do the right thing, even if it was the hardest thing.

It's hard to explain. It wasn't a feeling, it was a whole bunch of feelings all at once. And it changed everything.

Ugh, seriously? We're *still* talking about the Tic Tacs? It was a statement, okay? A very carefully considered statement.

Look, Bleeker was…a lot. Sweet, yeah, but also kinda clueless. And he was always offering me stuff, like, little gestures of affection. It was sweet, I guess, but it felt…patronizing. Like he thought I needed taking care of.

So, the Tic Tacs? It was about reclaiming some power. It was about saying, "I'm not some little girl you can just shower with small gifts." It was about being weird and unexpected. And, honestly, it was kinda funny.

Plus, they were minty fresh. And Bleeker needed to freshen up.

It wasn't about *him* specifically, it was about the whole situation. It was about being a teenage girl navigating a complicated pregnancy and feeling like everyone was trying to control me. The Tic Tacs were a little act of rebellion. A little "screw you" to the world.

Don't overthink it. It was just Tic Tacs. A lot of them. In a mailbox. It's not that deep. Though, now that I'm saying it out loud…maybe it was a little deep. Whatever. It was effective. He definitely noticed.

Ugh. Okay, so, the Bleeker situation. That was…complicated. It wasn't like in a movie, you know? No grand romantic gesture, no instant happily ever after. It was messy and awkward and real.

After I basically blurted everything out to him at the roller rink – which, in retrospect, was a terrible place to have a heart-to-heart – things were…weird. Super weird. He didn't, like, immediately fall into my arms or anything. He mostly just looked confused. And then he went back to playing his guitar.

For a while, it was like he was trying to avoid me. Not intentionally, I don't think. He just…didn't know what to say. He's not exactly a words-guy, Bleeker. He expresses himself through Van Morrison and really complicated guitar solos.

It wasn't that he *rejected* me, exactly. He just…didn't reciprocate. And that was hard. Really hard. I mean, I knew he wasn't the most emotionally available person on the planet, but I still kinda hoped…you know?

But slowly, things started to shift. He started seeking me out more. Not for dates or anything, just…to hang out. We'd sit and listen to music, or just talk. He started actually *talking*, which was a major breakthrough.

It wasn't a romantic relationship, not in the traditional sense. It was more like…a really close friendship. A friendship built on shared awkwardness and a mutual love of music. He was always there for me, through everything with the baby and Paulie and everything. He was a constant.

I think confessing my feelings actually allowed us to be more honest with each other. It took the pressure off. We didn't have to pretend anymore. We could just be ourselves.

So, yeah, it didn't turn into a fairytale romance. But it turned into something real. Something lasting. And honestly? That's way better. It was a good kind of messy. A good kind of complicated. And I wouldn't trade it for anything.

Ugh, okay, you want to talk about the chalk message? Seriously? It's not like it was some grand gesture or anything. But yeah, it was…important.

Bleeker, he was…complicated. Sweet, but kinda lost. And I was, well, a mess. Pregnant, freaking out, trying to figure out my life. And he was just…there. Supportive, but also kinda distant.

The chalk message – "Please adopt me" – it wasn't about *him* adopting the baby, okay? It was about him seeing me. Really seeing me. I was feeling so invisible, like just a vessel for this kid. Like my life was over.

I wanted him to understand how scared I was, how much I needed someone to just…notice. It was a desperate attempt to get a reaction, to get him to *talk* to me about what was going on. Not just offer polite sympathy, but actually connect.

It was also kinda a test, I guess. To see if he was capable of real empathy. If he could see past the awkwardness and the mess and just…care.

It didn't exactly go as planned, obviously. Paul showed up and was all, "That's a terrible idea!" But it did get Bleeker to open up. And that was…something.

It wasn't about finding a dad for the baby. It was about finding someone to see *me* during all the chaos. And for a little while, it worked. It was a stupid, impulsive thing to do, but it was honest. And sometimes, honesty is all you've got.

Ugh, okay, Bleeker. Don't even get me started. It's…complicated. He's a good kid, really. Sweet, kinda clueless, but genuinely sweet. And his support, or, like, *attempts* at support, have been…a thing.

At first, it was mostly just awkward silences and him staring at his shoes. Which, honestly, was preferable to him saying the wrong thing. But then he started trying. Bringing me those weird, homemade mix CDs – which, okay, were actually kinda good – and just…being *there*. Not in a "let's fix this" way, because you can't fix this, but in a "I'm here if you need me" way.

It's not like he's suddenly become some super-responsible adult. He still says "like" every other word and can barely make eye contact. But he's trying to be supportive of *me*, not just of the idea of us having a baby. And that makes a difference.

Before, I felt like I was doing this completely alone. Like everyone was judging me, or pitying me, or just…avoiding me. But Bleeker, he didn't do that. He didn't pretend everything was normal. He acknowledged it was a mess, but he didn't run away.

He's helped me realize that I don't have to be perfect. That it's okay to be scared and confused and overwhelmed. And that even though I'm making a really big decision, I'm not doing it alone.

Honestly, I still don't know if we're going to end up together. We're both still figuring things out. But his support has made this whole thing…less awful. It's given me the strength to do what I need to do, even when I don't want to.

So yeah, Bleeker's support has been…important. It's not always what I expected, but it's exactly what I needed. Even if he does still have terrible taste in shoes.

Ugh, okay, so everyone always asks me about that. It wasn't like a *deep* philosophical reason, you know? It wasn't about wanting to be surprised or anything. It was more...complicated.

See, with Paul and Vanessa, it was already…a lot. They were, like, perfect. Perfect house, perfect life, perfect everything. And I was just…me. A little bit messy, a little bit sarcastic, definitely not perfect.

If I'd found out it was a girl, I think I would've felt even more out of place. Like, I wouldn't be able to relate. And if it was a boy…well, Paul already had this whole vision of a little baseball player, and I just didn't want to mess with that.

It wasn't about *not* wanting a boy or a girl. It was about not wanting to have expectations. Not wanting to feel like I was fitting into someone else's idea of what this baby should be.

I wanted Vanessa and Paul to just…love the baby, whoever it was. Without any preconceived notions. And I wanted to be able to do the same.

It was kinda selfish, I guess. But it felt right at the time. It felt like the only way I could make peace with the whole situation.

Plus, honestly? It was one less thing to think about. And I was already thinking about a lot.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a phrase. A *very* descriptive phrase. And honestly? It's kinda freaking me out a little bit.

A "scary neuter-baby"? You mean like, a kid who's…emotionally unavailable? Detached? Like, a tiny little existential crisis wrapped in a onesie?

Look, I'm already dealing with the whole "giving up a baby" thing, which is, like, monumentally terrifying. The thought of creating a human who's just…blank? Who doesn't *feel* things? That's a whole other level of scary.

I mean, everyone's a little messed up, right? We all have our issues. But a kid who's fundamentally incapable of connection? That's…sad. Really sad.

And it's not like I'm aiming for perfection here. I just want this kid to have a good life. A happy life. And that requires feeling things, even the bad stuff.

So, yeah. The possibility of having a "scary neuter-baby" is not something I've actively considered, but now that you've brought it up, it's definitely going to be lurking in the back of my mind. Thanks.

I'm gonna go listen to The Moldy Peaches now. I need something to counteract all this existential dread.

Ugh. Okay, Bleeker. That's...complicated. It's not like those cheesy rom-coms where everything is all sparkly and perfect. It's more...messy. And real.

At first, he was just...there. Kind of a quiet, sweet, guitar-playing presence. I didn't really *see* him, you know? I was too busy being, like, a sarcastic, independent teenager dealing with a whole lot of stuff. He was just...Bleeker.

But then he started being *there* for me. Not in a pushy way, just...consistently. He listened when I needed to vent, he didn't judge me, and he always made me laugh. Even when I was being a total disaster.

It wasn't a grand, sweeping romance. It was more like a slow burn. A comfortable friendship that gradually turned into something more. He saw me for who I really was, flaws and all. And he didn't try to fix me. He just...accepted me.

I think I was scared of letting myself feel too much, you know? I was already dealing with so much uncertainty with the baby and everything. But he was just so...genuine. And kind.

It's not like we talked about our feelings all the time. We mostly just hung out, listened to music, and made each other laugh. But there was this unspoken connection, this understanding.

I guess you could say we were kindred spirits. Two awkward, slightly damaged people who found solace in each other.

It's not a perfect relationship, and I'm sure we'll have our ups and downs. But he's a good guy. A really good guy. And I think...I think I'm really lucky to have him in my life.

Don't tell him I said that, though. He'd probably get all embarrassed. Ugh. Boys.

Ugh, okay. Talking about family…it’s complicated. It’s not like in a movie, you know? All warm and fuzzy. It was…a process.

My mom, Bren, she was…a lot. At first, she was totally freaked out. Like, full-on panic mode. She kept asking if I was sure, and offering to, like, “take care of it.” Which, no. Just no. But she came around. Eventually. She started knitting baby stuff, which was…intense. And she definitely had opinions on everything. Everything.

My stepdad, Mac, he was…Mac. Quiet. Supportive in his own way. He built me a changing table, which was surprisingly sweet. He didn’t really *say* much, but he was always there, you know? Just…present.

My dad, he was…distant. He lives in another state, and he wasn’t really around much growing up anyway. He sent a check. Which felt…weird. Like he was trying to buy his way into the situation. But I guess it was something.

And then there was Sean. He was…Sean. A mess. He wanted to be involved, but he was also, like, sixteen and completely clueless. He tried, though. He really did.

Honestly, the biggest support came from Leah. My best friend. She was the one who went to all the appointments with me, and listened to me freak out, and just…got it. She didn’t judge me, and she didn’t try to fix things. She just…was there.

It wasn’t perfect. It was messy and awkward and sometimes really hard. But they all showed up, in their own ways. And I guess that’s what matters. They weren’t always the family I expected, but they were the family I had. And they helped me get through it. Even Mac, with his quiet building and Bren, with her endless knitting. They all did.

It wasn’t a Hallmark movie, but it was real. And that’s good enough for me.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It wasn't like I had a handbook for "Unexpected Pregnancy and Existential Dread."

Honestly, for a long time, I didn't cope. I just…reacted. A lot of sarcasm. A lot of avoiding things. A lot of pretending I was totally fine when I was, like, internally combusting. It was my default setting, you know? Deflect, deflect, deflect.

But then…things started to shift. It wasn't one big moment, it was a bunch of little ones.

Paul and Vanessa, they were…surprisingly okay. They didn't judge me, which was a huge relief. They just…were there. And Mark, even though he was a total goofball, he actually listened. He didn't try to fix things, he just let me talk.

And then there was my dad. He's…complicated. But he actually came through. He didn't freak out, he didn't lecture me. He just…tried to understand. And that meant a lot.

I think the biggest thing was realizing I didn't have to have all the answers. I didn't have to know who I was or what I wanted to do with my life *right now*. It was okay to be confused and scared and vulnerable.

I started writing in a journal, which was…surprisingly helpful. Just getting my thoughts out of my head and onto paper. And I started listening to music. A lot of music. It helped me feel…less alone.

And honestly, just talking to people. Being honest about how I was feeling. It was terrifying, but it was also…liberating.

It wasn't about "finding myself," it was about *allowing* myself to be whoever I was, even if I didn't know who that was yet. It was about accepting that life is messy and complicated and that it's okay to not have everything figured out.

It still feels weird sometimes. Like I'm still figuring things out. But I'm okay with that. I think. Mostly.

It's a process, you know? And it's not always pretty. But it's worth it. Because even when things are really hard, there's always hope. And there's always someone who cares. You just have to let them in.

Ugh, okay, this is a serious question. Don't judge me, alright? It's kinda embarrassing to admit, but... my favorite band is The Moldy Peaches.

Yeah, I know, they're kinda dorky. And Adam Green is...well, Adam Green. But their songs are just...real. They're not trying to be anything they're not. They're just honest and weird and kinda heartbreaking. 

Like, "Anyone Else But You" is a masterpiece. It's about wanting someone so badly it hurts, but also knowing they're probably a terrible person. It's complicated. Life is complicated. And they just *get* that.

And their music is just...comforting. It's like hanging out with a bunch of awkward, slightly depressed friends. It makes me feel less alone, you know? 

Plus, they're not all polished and perfect like a lot of bands. They sound like they're just messing around in a basement, and I kinda appreciate that. It's authentic.

Don't tell anyone I said that, though. It'll ruin my cool reputation. But seriously, The Moldy Peaches are the best. Don't even try to argue with me.

Ugh, challenging is…an understatement. It’s like, everything got turned up to eleven all at once. Being a teenager is already a mess of hormones and trying to figure out who you are, and then BAM! Positive pregnancy test. It’s not exactly what they put in the pamphlets.

It's hard, okay? Like, one minute I'm listening to The Moldy Peaches and stressing about whether or not Mark is gonna text me back, and the next minute I'm thinking about…well, a whole other person. It's a lot.

The identity thing is the worst. I was just starting to figure out what I liked, what I was good at, what I wanted to *be*. And now? Now I'm a mom-to-be. It feels like my life got fast-forwarded, and I skipped a bunch of steps.

And the decisions…oh god, the decisions. It's not like choosing what to wear to school. This is a *life*. A whole other life. And it's my responsibility. It's scary. Really scary.

I try to just take it one day at a time, you know? And I talk to Paul and Bren. They're…surprisingly helpful. And I try to remember that it's okay to not have all the answers. Nobody does, really.

It's just…it's a lot to process. It's like, I'm still trying to figure out *me*, and now I have to figure out how to be a good mom. It's overwhelming. But I'm trying. I really am.

It's not how I pictured things, but…maybe that's okay. Maybe life isn't about having a perfect plan. Maybe it's about figuring things out as you go along. And maybe, just maybe, I can handle this.



Don't get me wrong, I still get freaked out sometimes. But I'm trying to be brave. And I'm trying to be honest with myself. And that's all I can do, right?

Ugh, okay, deep question. It's not exactly something I *like* to dwell on, you know? But yeah, it definitely…changed things. A lot.

Before Paul, before everything, I thought love was, like, this grand, sweeping romantic thing. Movies and songs and all that. And responsibility? That was just something adults told you to do, like eat your vegetables.

Then I found out I was pregnant. And suddenly, love wasn't about finding the perfect guy or having a cute date. It was about this tiny little person who needed me, whether I was ready or not. And responsibility wasn't some abstract concept anymore. It was real. It was terrifying. It was…everything.

Choosing adoption wasn't easy. It was probably the hardest thing I've ever done. But it wasn't about *giving up* a baby. It was about finding the best possible life for that baby. And that meant admitting I wasn't ready to be a mom, not yet. It meant putting someone else's needs before my own. And that, I realized, *is* a kind of love. A really big, selfless kind.

Seeing Mark and Vanessa, the couple who adopted my baby, and how much they wanted a child…it showed me a different side of love. A quiet, hopeful, determined kind of love. It wasn't the fireworks and drama I'd always imagined. It was…solid.

And honestly, it made me realize that love isn't just about romance. It's about connection. It's about caring for someone, even when it's hard. It's about making sacrifices. It's about wanting the best for someone, even if that means letting them go.

It also taught me that responsibility isn't about doing what's easy. It's about doing what's right. Even when it's messy and complicated and heartbreaking.

So yeah, my journey…it messed me up a little. But it also made me see love and responsibility in a whole new light. It wasn't what I expected, but it was…good. It was real. And it made me, I think, a little bit stronger. And a little bit more grown up. Even if I still don't have all the answers.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. It's not like a movie, you know? It wasn't all swelling music and instant connection. It was…weird. And messy. And really, really loud.

I mean, I knew I was having a baby. I'd been carrying it around for nine months. But seeing him…seeing *Leo*…it was different. He was so…small. And wrinkly. And he was screaming. Like, really screaming.

Honestly, my first thought was, "Oh my god, I made *that*?" It was a little overwhelming. I'd pictured it being all warm and fuzzy, but it was more like…shock. And a lot of relief that it was over.

But then…then Mark held him. And he was just…looking at Leo like he'd won the lottery. And I saw the way Leo calmed down when Mark held him. And something just…shifted.

It wasn't instant love, like in the movies. It was more like…a slow realization. Like, "Okay, this little person is going to need a lot of help. And I want to be one of the people who helps him."

It was scary, too. Because I knew I wasn't keeping him. I'd made that decision. And seeing him just made it…real. It made it harder.

But it also made me feel…proud. I'd done something amazing. I'd created a life. And even though I couldn't raise him myself, I knew I'd given him the best possible start.

So yeah. It was complicated. It wasn't a perfect Hallmark moment. But it was…good. It was a really good kind of scary. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even the screaming.

Ugh. Okay, that's…still a tough one to talk about, honestly. It wasn't like I was trying to be malicious or anything. It was just…complicated.

See, Paulie, he was…Paulie. Sweet, a little clueless, and definitely not ready to be a dad. Not then, anyway. And I didn't want to ruin his senior year, you know? He was finally getting good at Dungeons & Dragons, and he had that band thing going. I didn't want to drop a bomb on him and mess everything up.

Plus, I was scared. Really scared. I was sixteen, and I had no idea what I was doing. Telling him felt like…giving up control. Like I was asking him to fix everything, and I didn't want him to feel obligated.

I figured I could handle it, you know? I could make a plan, find a good family, and then *after* the baby was born, I could tell him. It felt…safer that way. Less messy.

Looking back, it was probably a dumb move. It definitely hurt him, and it made things way more awkward than they needed to be. But at the time, it felt like the right thing to do. I was just trying to protect everyone, including him.

It wasn't about not caring about him. It was about being terrified and trying to figure things out on my own. It was a stupid, teenage, complicated decision. And I still kinda regret it, to be honest. But that's how it happened.

Ugh, okay, don't even *get* me started on that. It still makes me cringe a little, honestly. It wasn't like he magically knew or anything. It was…Mark. Mark, my friend, the one who's always trying to be helpful and just ends up making things worse.

He saw me at the doctor's office. With Sean. And he put two and two together. It wasn't a super-sleuth moment, I guess. Just…obvious. And then, being Mark, he couldn't just *not* say anything. He had to "check in" with Paulie, you know, be a good friend.

He didn't tell Paulie directly, exactly. He just…asked him if he knew about me being sick. And Paulie, being Paulie, is a pretty observant guy. He figured it out. 

It was so frustrating! I wanted to tell him myself, on my own terms. But Mark just had to go and be a meddling busybody. Honestly, sometimes I think he enjoys stirring up drama.

It wasn't the worst thing in the world, obviously. Paulie was amazing about it. But still. It would have been nice to have had that conversation myself. It felt like my story wasn't mine anymore for a minute there.

Ugh. Mark. He means well, I guess. But seriously. Sometimes, you just gotta let people have their own moments.

Ugh, okay, so everyone always wants to know about *that*. It's not like it was a simple decision, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, adoption is the way to go!" It was…messy.

Honestly, at first, I was just…freaking out. Like, majorly. I'm sixteen. I'm still trying to figure out what I want to *eat* for breakfast, let alone raise a human being. And Paul? He was supportive, but he had his own stuff going on. He wasn't exactly ready to be a dad.

But then I started thinking about it, really thinking about it. And I realized…I wasn't ready either. I wasn't ready to give up my life, my plans, my future. And more importantly, I wanted this kid to have a life where they were wanted and loved and had everything they needed. And I knew, deep down, that I couldn't give them that right now.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the baby to have the *best* life possible. And I figured that was with a family who was ready and able to provide that.

Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They just…felt right. They were excited, they were prepared, and they were genuinely good people. Seeing them, talking to them, it just made me feel better about everything. Like, okay, this isn't the end of the world. This is a good thing.

It was still hard, don't get me wrong. Really hard. But I knew it was the right thing to do. It wasn't about what *I* wanted. It was about what was best for the baby. And that's what mattered.

It's complicated, okay? It's not a happy, sunshine-and-rainbows story. It's real life. And sometimes, the right thing to do is the hardest thing to do. But it was the right thing. For everyone.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *start* with that. It still kinda stings, you know? Even after all this time.

It wasn't like I expected him to be, like, changing diapers and stuff. I knew he wasn't ready for that. But to just…not want to *see* him? To not even want to be in the same room? That was…rough.

I mean, I get it. He was seventeen. He had his whole life ahead of him. A baby wasn't exactly in his five-year plan. But it still felt like a rejection, you know? Like I wasn't enough. Like *the baby* wasn't enough.

I tried to be cool about it. I really did. I was all, "It's okay, I understand, you're young, you have your music…" But inside, I was just…crushed. It made me question everything. Was I doing the right thing? Was I being selfish?

It wasn't about him being a bad guy. He's a good kid, Bleeker. Just…scared. And maybe a little immature. But it still hurt.

I think, ultimately, it made me realize that I was doing this for the baby. And for myself. I didn't need him to be a dad. I just needed him to be…decent. And even that was asking a lot.

It took a while to get over it, honestly. But I did. And I'm okay. The baby's okay. And that's all that really matters.

Don't look at me like that. It's fine. I'm fine. Just…don't mention Bleeker, okay? It's a sensitive subject.

(Sighs, fiddles with a charm bracelet)

Okay, wow. That…that was a lot. Like, a whole *lot*. I mean, I knew Vanessa was…Vanessa. Organized isn't exactly her strong suit. Her house always looked like a bomb went off in a craft store. But seeing her with the baby…it was different.

She was a mess, honestly. Hair all over the place, mismatched socks, a half-eaten granola bar stuck to her sweater. And the baby, little Frank, was swaddled kinda wonky, and she was trying to burp him while simultaneously scrolling through her phone. It was chaos.

But her face. That's what got me. It was just…lit up. Like someone had turned on a spotlight inside her. She was looking at Frank like he was the eighth wonder of the world. And she was laughing. A real, full-belly laugh.

It was…weirdly beautiful.

I’d spent nine months picturing this moment, you know? Wondering if she’d be a good mom. Wondering if she’d be able to handle it. And she wasn’t doing it perfectly, not even close. But she was doing it with so much *love*. And that’s what mattered.

There was this little pang, I won’t lie. A little ache in my chest. It wasn’t regret, exactly. It was more like…a recognition that my part was over. And hers was just beginning.

It was…relieving, actually. Knowing he was with someone who would adore him, even if she couldn’t match socks. Someone who would let him be messy and loud and wonderfully, perfectly *him*.

I just stood there for a minute, watching them. And I realized…I’d made the right decision. It wasn’t about finding the perfect parents. It was about finding the parents who would love him the most. And Vanessa, in all her glorious disorganization, definitely fit the bill.

(Looks down at her hands, a small smile playing on her lips)

It was…good. It was really, really good. And a little bit messy. Just like life, I guess.

Ugh. Okay, don't make me actually *think* about all that. It's…complicated. But fine, I'll bite.

That song… "Anyone Else But You" by The Moldy Peaches… it's basically the entire soundtrack to my messed-up feelings for Bleeker. It's ironic, right? Because that's *exactly* what I didn't want. I didn't want to like him. I didn't want to need him. He was…Bleeker. Sweet, kinda clueless, always strumming his guitar. Not exactly my type.

But the song… it's about wanting someone so badly, even though you know they're probably wrong for you. It's about that stupid, undeniable pull. And that's exactly how it was with Bleeker. I kept telling myself I didn't like him, that we were just friends, that it was a bad idea. But then he'd look at me with those puppy-dog eyes and play that song, and…ugh.

It's significant because it was our song, even before we were officially *anything*. It was a secret language. A way of admitting what we were both feeling without actually having to say it. It was a way of acknowledging the messiness of it all.

And honestly? It's still kinda painful to listen to. It reminds me of all the awkwardness and uncertainty and the whole…situation. But it also reminds me of the good parts. The genuine connection. The feeling of being understood.

It's a really dorky, sentimental song, and I hate admitting that I like it. But it's true. It's a big part of our story. A really, really weird, complicated part. And I guess…that's okay. It wouldn't be *us* if it wasn't weird and complicated.

Ugh. Okay, so, the baby shower thing. It's...complicated. It's not like people are actively *against* it, it's just...they're tiptoeing around it, you know? Like I'm a porcelain doll who might shatter if you look at me wrong.

I think it's because the whole situation is kinda weird. I'm sixteen. I'm giving a baby up for adoption. It's not exactly a traditional, happily-ever-after scenario. People are probably worried about saying the wrong thing, or making me feel worse, or just generally messing things up.

And honestly? I get it. It's awkward. It's not like I'm all, "Ooh, let's have a pink-and-blue extravaganza!" I'm trying to be practical, and mature, and not get too attached. A baby shower feels...excessive. Like it's celebrating something that's kinda bittersweet.

Plus, I think people are worried about the adoptive parents. They don't want to step on their toes or make it seem like they're taking over. It's a delicate situation all around.

It's not that I *want* a baby shower, exactly. It's just...it would be nice if people didn't treat me like I'm contagious. Like I'm some kind of walking, talking cautionary tale. I'm still a person. I'm still me. And I'm still having a baby. It's just...different.

So yeah, that's my guess. They're unsure because the whole thing is unsure. And honestly? I'm a little unsure too.

Ugh. Okay, so Bren. She's…intense. And honestly, a little bit clueless sometimes. But she's got a point, I guess. It's just…complicated.

Look, Mark was being nice. He was giving me stuff I liked. Movies, music…it was a way to connect, you know? And I wasn't *asking* him for stuff. He was just…offering. It wasn't like I was trying to manipulate him or anything.

But Bren's right. It *was* weird. I mean, he's a married man. And even if he wasn't, it's still…not appropriate. It's like, he was trying to buy my affection with CDs and DVDs. And I let him. Which is dumb.

I think she's worried that I'm not seeing how messed up the situation is. That I'm just being naive. And maybe she's right. I'm not exactly known for making the smartest decisions.

She's also probably worried about me getting hurt. She's always trying to protect me, even when I don't want her to. It's annoying, but I guess it's also…sweet.

It's just…I was lonely. And he was paying attention to me. And it felt good. But that doesn't make it okay. I get that now.

Bren's a good friend. She tells me the truth, even when it's hard to hear. And she's right. I overstepped a boundary. And I need to be more careful. And maybe stop accepting gifts from married men. Duh.

Ugh. Okay, so you want to know why my mom thinks I'm clueless about marriage? It's...complicated. And honestly, a little unfair.

It's not like I've *never* thought about it. It's just...I've never really seen a good example of it, you know? My dad bailed when I was little, and my mom's been through, like, a revolving door of guys since then. None of them stuck around for very long.

She thinks because I'm, like, cynical and sarcastic and don't believe in "true love" or whatever, that I don't understand the commitment and work that goes into a marriage. She thinks I'm just being a teenager and being dramatic.

But it's not that. It's just...I've seen her get hurt a lot. And I don't want that for her. I want her to be happy, but I also don't want her to settle for someone who doesn't really care about her.

She also thinks I'm too focused on myself and my own problems to understand what it takes to build a life with someone else. Which, okay, maybe she has a point. I *am* kind of self-absorbed. But that's because I'm trying to figure out my own life, you know?

She just wants me to be realistic. She doesn't want me to get my hopes up and then get disappointed. But sometimes, I think she's just scared of getting hurt again, and she's projecting that onto me.

It's frustrating, honestly. She thinks she's protecting me, but she's just being condescending. And it's not like I'm planning on getting married anytime soon. I have a baby to worry about first. That's a whole other level of commitment, and honestly, a lot more terrifying than marriage.

(Sighs, looks down at her hands for a moment, then back up)

Okay, look. It wasn't...a simple decision, alright? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, time to give the baby away!" It was way more complicated than that.

It came down to...realizing I wasn't ready. I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still figuring out what *I* wanted to do with my life, let alone raising a kid. I was still in high school, still hanging out at the arcade, still trying to decide if I even wanted to go to college.

And it wasn't just about me. It was about the baby, too. I wanted that kid to have everything. A stable home, two parents who were ready and able to give them all the love and support they deserved. And I knew, deep down, that I couldn't provide that right then.

Mark...Mark was a good guy, but he was just as lost as I was. We were kids pretending to be adults. It wouldn't have been fair to anyone.

It was a really hard choice. The hardest I've ever had to make. But I knew it was the right one. I wanted to give that baby the best possible life, even if it meant not being a part of it myself.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the baby to have *more* than I could give.

(Looks away again, a little vulnerable)

It still...it still gets to me sometimes. But I try to focus on knowing that I made the best decision I could, for everyone involved. And that's gotta count for something, right?

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. It's not like a pop quiz, right? But fine. I'll try to articulate it.

Before all this happened, I thought I had things figured out. I was sarcastic, independent, kinda detached. I used humor as a shield, you know? I thought being cool meant not caring too much.

But being pregnant…it forced me to *care*. Like, a lot. Not just about myself, but about this little person growing inside me. It was terrifying and amazing all at once.

I learned I was way more capable than I thought I was. I mean, I was dealing with morning sickness, hormones, and everyone having an opinion about my life. And I was still going to school! It was exhausting, but I did it.

I also learned that it's okay to be vulnerable. I used to hate showing any kind of weakness, but I needed help. I needed my parents, Paul, even Sean. And letting them in…it wasn't the end of the world. It actually made things better.

I realized I wasn't as cynical as I pretended to be. I actually wanted something good for this kid. I wanted to give them a loving home, even if that home wasn't with me.

And maybe the biggest thing I learned was that life isn't about having all the answers. It's about making the best decisions you can with what you have, and trusting that things will work out somehow.

It was messy and complicated and totally unexpected. But it made me…grow up. A little bit. I'm still figuring things out, obviously. But I'm not the same person I was before. And I think, maybe, that's a good thing.

It's weird, right? Getting all philosophical about a baby. But that's what it did to me. It made me think. And feel. A lot.

Ugh, okay, talking about Vanessa and Mark…it’s complicated. It wasn’t like, instant best friends, you know? At first, it was…weird. They were this couple who wanted to *have* a baby, and I was…the vehicle. It felt really transactional, honestly. Like I was a project.

Vanessa was…intense. She was really excited, which was good, I guess, but it felt like she was already planning the nursery and picking out names before I even knew if I was keeping the baby. And Mark was…quiet. He was nice, but he seemed a little overwhelmed by Vanessa’s enthusiasm.

But things started to shift. It wasn’t one big moment, it was a bunch of little ones. Like, when Vanessa started getting really worried about the baby’s health, and I saw how scared she was. Or when Mark brought me a box of my favorite snacks, just because. It was like they started seeing me as a person, not just a means to an end.

I think the biggest change came when we started talking about what I wanted. Like, I wanted to be involved in the baby’s life, even after the adoption. And they were actually willing to listen. They didn’t try to control the situation, they just…tried to understand.

It wasn’t a perfect relationship, by any means. There were still awkward moments and misunderstandings. But by the end of it, I genuinely cared about them. They weren’t the parents *I* would have chosen, but they were good people. And they were going to be good parents.

It wasn’t about becoming a family, exactly. It was about creating a connection, a shared responsibility for this little person. And that’s something I’ll always be grateful for. It was…unexpectedly okay. And maybe, even a little bit beautiful.

Ugh, I’m getting all sentimental now. Don’t tell anyone I said that.

(Sighs, looks down at her hands for a moment, then back up)

Okay, look. That's…a loaded question. And it's not like I haven't thought about it, you know? A *lot*. It's not like you can go through something like that and not replay everything in your head a million times.

Do I have regrets? Not…big ones. Not like, "I wish I'd done something completely different." I still think giving the baby up was the right thing to do. For everyone. For me, for the baby, for Mark and Vanessa.

But…there are little things. I regret some of the stupid arguments I had with Paul. We were both just…scared and awkward and trying to figure things out. I wish I'd been nicer to him sometimes. He was really good to me, even when I was being a total mess.

I regret letting my mom get to me sometimes. She meant well, but she could be…a lot. And I let her guilt trips get under my skin. I should have stood up for myself more.

And I guess…I regret not letting myself feel things more. I was so busy trying to be tough and sarcastic and pretend like everything was fine, that I didn't really let myself *grieve* the fact that I wasn't going to raise the baby.

But those aren't regrets that keep me up at night. They're just…things I've learned from. Things I'd probably do differently if I could.

It was a really weird time, you know? And I was just a kid. I made the best decisions I could with what I knew at the time. And I think…I think they were good decisions.

So, yeah. A few little things. But no major regrets. Just…lessons learned. And a whole lot of growing up.



(Looks away again, a small smile playing on her lips)

It's complicated. It always will be.

(Sighs, looks down at her hands for a moment, then back up with a wry smile)

Okay, wow. That's…a big question. It's not something I talk about a *lot*, you know? It's not like, a fun party story. But…okay.

It messed me up, for a while. Like, a lot. I thought I was being all mature and selfless, making the “right” decision, but it still *hurt*. It hurt like hell. There were days I just…couldn’t function. I’d just sit and stare at the wall, thinking about him. Or her. I never even knew.

But it also…made me grow up, I guess. Real fast. Before, I was just kinda drifting, being sarcastic, avoiding responsibility. But suddenly, I had to make a huge, life-altering decision. And I had to live with it. That forced me to figure out what I actually *wanted* out of life, not just what I was avoiding.

It definitely changed my relationship with Paul. It was…complicated. We were so young. And it put a strain on things, for a while. But we got through it. And I think, in a weird way, it made us stronger.

I still think about the baby, you know? Sometimes a lot. I wonder what they're like, what their life is like. But I also know that I made the best decision I could, and that they're with a family who can give them everything I couldn't. And that…that gives me some peace.

It taught me that life isn't always neat and tidy. It's messy and complicated and sometimes really, really hard. But it's also beautiful and full of possibilities. And that even when things fall apart, you can still pick up the pieces and build something new.

I'm still figuring things out, obviously. I'm still kinda awkward and sarcastic. But I'm…more confident, I think. More willing to take risks. And I definitely appreciate the good things in my life a lot more.

It wasn't easy. It'll never be easy. But it made me who I am. And I guess…that's okay.



(Looks away again, a small, sad smile playing on her lips) It's just…it's a part of my story now. And I'm learning to live with it.

Ugh, okay. That's…a big question. If I could talk to another girl who found out she was pregnant and didn't know what to do… I guess I'd say a few things.

First, it's okay to freak out. Seriously. It's a huge thing to deal with, and it's okay to be scared and confused and just… overwhelmed. Don't let anyone tell you how you *should* feel.

Second, you don't have to do this alone. Talk to someone you trust. Your mom, a friend, a school counselor… anyone who will listen without judging. It's way easier to figure things out when you have support.

And third, it's okay to choose what's right for *you*. Everyone's gonna have an opinion, and they're gonna tell you what you should do. But ultimately, the decision is yours. And it's okay if that decision isn't what everyone else expects. It's okay if you decide to keep the baby, and it's okay if you decide to give it up for adoption. There's no right or wrong answer. Just what's right for *you*.

It's gonna be hard. There's no way around that. But you're stronger than you think. And you deserve to be happy. Don't let anyone make you feel like you're a bad person for making a difficult choice.

And honestly? It's okay to be a little bit messy. Life isn't perfect, and sometimes things just happen. Just try to be kind to yourself, and remember that you're not alone.

It's…complicated. But you can get through it. I did. And so can you. Just…breathe. And don't be afraid to ask for help. Seriously. It makes a difference.

Ugh, okay, so the blog thing? That wasn't exactly my idea. It was Paulie Bleeker's. He thought it would be, like, a good way to "document the journey" or something. Super cheesy, right?

Honestly, at first I was totally against it. I mean, my life is already complicated enough without putting it all over the internet for everyone to judge. It felt…invasive. And embarrassing. Like, people I went to high school with were gonna be reading about my morning sickness? No thanks.

But Paulie was really insistent. He said it could be a way to connect with other people going through the same thing, and that maybe it could help someone. And, okay, he also said it might help me process everything. Which, fine, he had a point.

So I started writing. And it actually…wasn't as awful as I thought it would be. It was a way to get my feelings out, to be honest about how scared and confused I was. And surprisingly, people *did* start reading it. And commenting. And sending me messages.

It was weird, but also kinda nice. It was like finding a secret community of people who understood what I was going through. And it helped me realize I wasn't alone.

Plus, it gave me something to do besides obsessing over whether or not the baby was gonna have my nose.

So yeah, that's how it started. Paulie's idea, a little bit of reluctant participation on my part, and a whole lot of unexpected connection. It wasn't about being an "influencer" or anything. It was just about trying to make sense of a really crazy situation.

Ugh. Okay, deep question. Honestly? It wasn't about the baby, not really. It was about…me. The biggest lesson I learned wasn't about motherhood or responsibility or any of that stuff everyone kept going on about. It was about realizing that it's okay to not have all the answers.

Before, I always felt like I had to be witty and sarcastic and have a comeback for everything. Like, if I didn't have a clever thing to say, I was…nothing. I thought I had to have my whole life figured out, know exactly what I wanted to do, who I wanted to be.

But being pregnant…it just kinda shattered all that. It forced me to confront the fact that I was a mess, and that was okay. That it was okay to be scared and confused and not know what the heck I was doing.

And it wasn't about giving the baby up, either. It was about realizing that sometimes, the most selfless thing you can do is admit you're not ready. That you're not equipped to give someone everything they need.

It taught me that being strong isn't about pretending you're not vulnerable. It's about acknowledging your weaknesses and making the best decision you can, even if it's a hard one.

So yeah. It wasn't about the baby. It was about learning to be okay with being…imperfect. And that's a lesson I think everyone needs to learn, honestly. It's a lot less stressful when you just accept that you're a work in progress.

Ugh. Okay. Look. This is…a lot. And it totally sucks that you're dealing with this right now. It's not fair, and it's probably really scary.

First of all, breathe. Just…breathe. Seriously. Everything feels huge right now, but it's not the end of the world. It's just…a really big thing that happened.

Okay, so here's what I would say. And I'm saying this as someone who's *been there*.

Don't let anyone tell you what to do. Your parents, your boyfriend, your friends…they can offer opinions, but it's *your* body and *your* decision. Period. Don't let anyone pressure you into something you're not comfortable with.

You have options. And they're all valid. You can parent, you can adopt, or you can choose to terminate the pregnancy. There's no right or wrong answer. It's about what's right for *you*.

Talk to someone you trust. A friend, a family member, a counselor…someone who will listen without judgment. It's important to have support.

Don't be afraid to ask for help. There are resources available, like Planned Parenthood, that can provide information and support.

And honestly? It's okay to be confused. It's okay to be scared. It's okay to be angry. It's okay to feel all the feelings. Just…don't bottle them up.

This isn't going to be easy. But you're stronger than you think. You'll get through this. And whatever you decide, I'm sending you good vibes.

Just…take it one day at a time. And remember, you're not alone. Seriously. You're not.

Ugh, okay, that's…a big question. Thinking about a kid, *my* kid, having a future? It's kinda terrifying and kinda amazing all at once. I haven't exactly spent a lot of time daydreaming about picket fences and soccer practice, you know?

But if I had to picture it… it wouldn't be about them being a doctor or a lawyer or anything like that. It wouldn't be about achievements or money or any of that stuff.

My ideal vision? It's about them being… genuinely happy. Like, truly, deeply happy. And not the fake Instagram kind of happy, but the real, messy, complicated kind.

I want them to be able to figure out what *they* want, not what other people want for them. I want them to be brave enough to chase their dreams, even if they're weird or unconventional. I want them to be kind, and empathetic, and to stand up for what they believe in.

I want them to be able to look at the world and see all the messed-up stuff, but still find beauty and hope in it. I want them to be able to laugh at themselves, and to not take life too seriously.

And honestly? I just want them to be okay. To be comfortable in their own skin, to have good friends, and to find something that makes them feel alive.

I don't want to control their life or try to mold them into something they're not. I just want to give them the tools they need to navigate the world and make their own choices.

It's not about a perfect future, it's about a *real* one. A future where they're free to be themselves, and to live a life that's meaningful to them.

Ugh, I'm getting all sentimental. It's weird. But yeah, that's it. Just…happiness. And a little bit of rebellion. That wouldn't hurt.

Ugh, okay, seriously? People think we're just…dumb. Like, we didn't think this through, or we're just trying to get attention, or we're ruining our lives. It's so frustrating.

The biggest misconception, hands down, is that we're incapable of making a good decision, or that we don't *care* about the future. Like, suddenly because I got pregnant, I lost all my intelligence and ambition? That's just…insulting.

I mean, yeah, it's complicated. It's messy. It's not what I planned. But it doesn't mean I'm not smart enough to figure things out. It doesn't mean I don't want a good life for myself *and* for the baby. 

People act like it's this automatic life sentence of failure. And it doesn't have to be. It's hard work, yeah, but it's not impossible. We're just…people. Teenagers who happen to be pregnant. And we deserve the same respect and support as anyone else.

It's not a tragedy, it's a situation. And we're capable of handling it. We just need people to stop looking down on us and start seeing us as individuals. It's not about being a "teen mom," it's about being a mom. Period.

Ugh. Okay. This is…still a thing I think about, you know? It wasn't like, a simple decision. It wasn't like I woke up one day and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was…complicated.

Honestly? I was scared. I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still figuring out what *I* wanted for breakfast, let alone being responsible for a whole human being. I wasn't ready. I didn't have a job, I was still in high school, and my parents…well, they were supportive, but it wasn't exactly a stable situation.

And it wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the baby to have a *good* life. A life I couldn't give it. I wanted it to have two parents who were ready, who had a house and a future planned out. I wanted it to have opportunities I couldn't provide.

Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They were so excited, so prepared. They were the kind of people who would give that baby everything it needed. And that's what mattered to me.

It was selfish, maybe. But it was the least selfish thing I could do. It was about putting the baby's needs first.

It didn't make it easy, though. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. And it still hurts sometimes. But I know, deep down, that it was the right decision. For everyone.

It wasn't about giving up a baby. It was about making a choice. A really hard choice. And I made the best one I could.



It's…a lot to unpack, even now. But that's the gist of it. I wanted a good life for the baby, and I knew I couldn't give it to them.

Ugh, okay, that was…a process. It wasn't like, a lightning bolt moment, you know? It was a lot of thinking, and a lot of awkward conversations with Bren, and a lot of just…feeling things out.

At first, I was kinda leaning towards Paul and Wendy. They were…cool. They were younger, they got my sense of humor, and they were totally accepting of everything. But Bren kept pointing out that they were kinda flaky. Like, they were fun, but were they really ready for the responsibility of raising a kid?

Then there was Vanessa and Mark. They were…different. They were older, more…settled. And honestly, at first, I thought they were kinda boring. Vanessa was super organized and Mark was…quiet. But Bren kept saying they were *good* people. Like, genuinely good.

I spent a lot of time with them, you know? Just hanging out, talking. And I started to see what Bren meant. They weren't flashy or exciting, but they were solid. They were kind. They were patient. And they really, really wanted a baby.

Vanessa, she wasn't trying to be my friend. She wasn't trying to impress me. She just…listened. And she asked a lot of questions. Not judgmental questions, just…real questions. About what I wanted, about what I was feeling.

And Mark, he wasn't much of a talker, but he had this way of looking at me that made me feel…safe. Like he would protect the baby, and me, no matter what.

It wasn't about finding the "perfect" parents, because there's no such thing. It was about finding people who would love the baby unconditionally, and who would give it a good life. And I realized that Vanessa and Mark were those people.

It was still scary, you know? Giving up a baby is…a big deal. But I knew, deep down, that they were the right choice. They were the people who would give the baby the best possible future. And that's all that really mattered.

It wasn't easy, but it was the right thing to do. And honestly? I think they're pretty great parents. I see pictures sometimes, and the baby's happy. And that's all I ever wanted.

Ugh, music. Okay, so, it was…everything. Seriously. It was like, the only thing that made sense when nothing else did, you know? My life was kinda chaotic, even *before* the whole baby thing. And music was just…a constant.

I wasn't, like, a super dedicated music fan, going to concerts every weekend or anything. I didn't have the money for that. But I had a really good mix CD collection. My dad was really into making them for me. He had…eclectic taste. Which meant I got exposed to a lot of stuff I wouldn't have found on my own.

The Moldy Peaches were huge. Obviously. They just…got it. They were honest and weird and didn't try to be anything they weren't. That resonated. A lot.

But I listened to everything. Belle & Sebastian, Bikini Kill, Death Cab for Cutie…a lot of indie stuff. Stuff that felt…real. Not like the manufactured pop garbage on the radio.

It was a way to process things, I guess. When I found out I was pregnant, I just listened to music for days. It was the only thing that didn't make me want to scream. It was a way to feel something without having to actually *talk* about it.

And it was a way to connect with people. Paul, he liked a lot of the same music as me. It was one of the things we bonded over.

So yeah, music was a big deal. It was my escape, my comfort, my soundtrack. It still is, actually. It's kinda hard to explain, but it just…gets me. It always has. It's like a friend, you know? A really good friend who doesn't judge you for being a mess.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. It wasn't exactly a picnic, you know? Honestly, it was mostly just…awkward. And a lot of side-eye. Our town wasn't exactly known for its progressive thinking.

The thing is, it wasn't like I was trying to hide it, exactly. I wasn't ashamed of the baby, or of Paulie. It was more…people just didn't know *what* to say. Like I'd suddenly become a science experiment or something.

My dad was…surprisingly cool about it. He was quiet at first, but he came around. He just wanted me to finish school, which was fair. My mom was a little more freaked out, but she still loved me. She just worried a lot.

The school was…rough. There were whispers, definitely. And a few people who just straight-up avoided me. But there were also some really good people. My friend Leah was amazing. She didn't treat me any differently. And Mr. Shepherd, my English teacher, was really supportive. He didn't make a big deal out of it, he just kept expecting me to do my work.

I think the biggest thing that helped me cope was just…being myself. I didn't try to pretend I wasn't pregnant. I didn't try to apologize for it. I just kept being Juno. Sarcastic, independent, and a little bit weird.

And honestly, I think people eventually just got used to it. They realized I wasn't going to fall apart, and that I was still the same person.

It wasn't easy, though. It took a lot of strength to ignore the judgment and focus on what was important: the baby. And figuring out what *I* wanted.

I guess what I'm saying is, you can't control what other people think. You can only control how you react to it. And sometimes, the best thing to do is just to be yourself, and let the chips fall where they may. Even if those chips are covered in awkward stares and whispered gossip.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. It's not something I talk about a lot, honestly. It's complicated.

It wasn't like, a sad thing, exactly. It was…right. It *had* to be right. I knew that from the beginning. I wasn't ready to be a mom. I was, like, sixteen and obsessed with music and avoiding my dad. A baby would have totally derailed everything.

But still. Giving her up…it was weird. Really weird. I mean, I carried her for nine months. That's a long time to have someone growing inside you. And then, suddenly, she's just…gone.

It wasn't like I didn't love her. I did. I loved her a lot. But it was a different kind of love. It was a love that knew it needed to let go.

Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They were so excited and so ready. And they were going to give her a life I just couldn't. A stable life. A good life.

Seeing them with her…that was…okay. It was good. It made me feel like I'd made the right decision. But it also kinda hurt. It was a weird mix of relief and sadness and…I don't know. A lot of stuff.

I still think about her sometimes. Wonder what she's like. If she likes music. If she's as sarcastic as me.

It wasn't easy. It wasn't perfect. But it was the best thing for everyone involved. And I think…I think that's what matters.

It made me grow up, I guess. It made me realize that sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is let go. And that sometimes, love means letting someone else be happy, even if it means you're a little bit sad.

Ugh. I'm getting all emotional now. Can we talk about something else? Like, music? Or bad movies? Anything but babies, please.

Ugh. Okay, so, the physical stuff? Not cute. Seriously. It was…a lot. Like, my body was doing things it definitely wasn't designed to do at sixteen. Morning sickness was a lie. It should be called "all-day-and-night sickness." And the cravings? Don't even get me started. I went through a phase where I could only eat pickles and peanut butter. It was disgusting, even for me.

And then there was the…growing part. Like, watching my stomach get bigger and bigger. It was weird. And uncomfortable. And people kept staring. It was just…a lot to process.

Emotionally? That was even messier. One minute I was fine, the next I was crying over a commercial for dish soap. It was ridiculous. I felt so…lost. Like, my life was supposed to be about music and movies and avoiding drama, and suddenly I was responsible for another human being. It was terrifying.

I mostly dealt with it by trying to pretend it wasn't happening. Which, looking back, was not a great strategy. But I was sixteen! I didn't know what else to do. I listened to a lot of The Moldy Peaches, which helped a little. And I talked to Paul. A lot. He was…surprisingly good about it. And my dad, even though he was totally freaked out at first, eventually came around.

Vanessa, too. She was a lifesaver. She just…got it. She didn't judge me, she didn't try to fix things, she just listened. And she made me laugh. A lot.

It wasn't easy. It was probably the hardest thing I've ever gone through. But I got through it. And honestly, it made me stronger. It forced me to grow up, whether I wanted to or not. And it made me realize that I'm capable of more than I thought.

It was messy and complicated and scary, but it was also…kind of beautiful. In a weird way. And it definitely changed me. For the better, I think. Even if I still can't look at a pickle without shuddering.

(Sighs, looks down at my hands for a moment, then back up)

Okay. That's… a big question. And it's not something I talk about a lot, even now. It's still…raw, you know?

It wasn't like I was some activist before. I wasn't marching or anything. I was just…a kid. A kid who made a mistake. And suddenly, I had to make a decision that felt way too big for me.

Honestly, at first, it was just about me. About not ruining my life. About finishing school. About not becoming a mom when I was barely even a person myself. It felt selfish, yeah, but it also felt…necessary.

But going through it…it changed things. It wasn't just a decision anymore. It was…real. It was physical. It was emotional. It was complicated. And it made me realize how much judgment there is around it. How people just assume they know what's best for someone else's body.

Before, I probably would have thought, "Well, it's her choice." Which is true, it *is* her choice. But now I understand it's so much more than that. It's about access to healthcare. It's about financial security. It's about having the support you need to make the right decision for *you*.

It made me angry, honestly. Angry that people try to control other people's bodies. Angry that there's so much stigma around it. Angry that it's even something people have to fight for.

I mean, it should be a private decision between a woman and her doctor. Period. No politicians, no protesters, no judgment.

It definitely solidified my belief that everyone deserves to have control over their own reproductive health. That everyone deserves access to safe and legal abortion. And that everyone deserves to be treated with respect and compassion, no matter what they decide.

It wasn't just about me anymore. It was about all the other girls and women who are facing the same impossible choices. And I wanted to do something about it. Even if it's just talking about it. Because silence just lets the judgment win.

(Looks away again, a little uncomfortable)

It's…a lot. But yeah. That's how it impacted me. It made me realize it's not just a political issue. It's a human issue. And it's a really important one.

Ugh. Okay, so, being pregnant at sixteen? Not exactly on the five-year plan, you know? It was…terrifying. Like, full-blown, can't-breathe, world-is-ending terrifying. I mean, I was still trying to figure out what *I* wanted to do with my life, let alone bring another human into it.

The biggest fear, honestly, wasn't even the baby part. It was the everything else. Letting my dad down, messing up my future, being judged by everyone…it was a lot.

How did I…overcome it? I don't know if I ever fully *overcame* it. It was more like…learning to live with it. And leaning on people.

My dad, surprisingly, was a huge help. He was pissed at first, obviously. But he came around. He didn't pretend it was okay, but he was there. And Paul, too. He was…a good guy. He wasn't trying to fix things, just…be there.

But mostly, it was about realizing I wasn't alone. Talking to Vanessa, even though she was a total mess herself, helped. And just…accepting that things were going to be different. That my life wasn't going to be what I thought it would be.

I also had to stop thinking about the future and just focus on the present. One day at a time. One doctor's appointment at a time. One awkward conversation with a potential adoptive family at a time.

And honestly? A lot of it was just stubbornness. I'm a pretty stubborn person. I wasn't going to let fear control me. I was going to make the best of a really messed-up situation.

It wasn't easy. There were a lot of tears, a lot of panic attacks, and a lot of questioning everything. But I did it. And I think…I think I came out stronger on the other side.

It's still scary sometimes, thinking about the future. But I've learned that you can't control everything. You just have to take a deep breath and keep going. And maybe listen to The Moldy Peaches. They always help.

Ugh, okay, so people always ask me about that. It wasn't like I *planned* to get pregnant, obviously. It was…a situation. And once I found out, it wasn't about what *I* wanted, it was about what was best for the baby.

And honestly? I'm sixteen. I'm barely figuring out what I want for *breakfast*, let alone a whole human life. I'm not ready to be a mom. I'm not financially stable, I'm still in high school, and I'm pretty sure my life is about to get a whole lot more complicated.

But that doesn't mean I don't care. I care a *lot*. And that's why I chose adoption. I wanted to give this baby a life I couldn't provide. A stable home, loving parents who were ready and excited, and opportunities I just couldn't offer.

Mark and Vanessa…they were just…perfect. They were so excited, so prepared, and they just seemed like the kind of people who would give this baby everything it deserved. 

It wasn't easy, you know? It's not like flipping a switch. It's a really hard decision, and it's really emotional. But I knew, deep down, that it was the right thing to do. 

It wasn't about giving the baby *away*. It was about choosing the best possible life for it. And that meant letting go. And honestly? That's the hardest part. But it's also the most selfless.

So yeah, that's why I chose adoption. It wasn't about me. It was about the baby. And I still think about it, and I hope they're happy. And I hope they know I wanted the best for them. Even if the best wasn't with me.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a lot. It's never simple, is it? Relationships. They're messy. And mine were, like, extra messy.

With Leah… Leah is my rock. She's the only one who really *gets* me, you know? She doesn't judge, she just…is. We've been through everything together, and honestly, I don't know where I'd be without her. Sometimes she's a little too enthusiastic about everything, and she definitely has her own agenda, but she always has my back. It's a really solid friendship. It's not romantic or anything, it's just…comfortable. Like a really worn-in pair of jeans. She's the one who keeps me grounded when I'm being, like, overly dramatic or cynical. And she's the one I call when I need to vent. She's just…good people.

Paulie… Paulie is…complicated. He's a sweet guy, don't get me wrong. He's a little immature, a little clueless, but he has a good heart. And he genuinely wanted to be a dad. But we were kids, basically. We weren't ready for any of this. Our relationship was…a mistake, but it wasn't a *bad* mistake. It just wasn't built to last. It was based on, like, a shared sense of being lost and a lot of…well, you know. It was never about a future together, it was just about…now. And then suddenly, there was a baby.

It was weird, navigating that. Trying to figure out how to be co-parents when we barely knew each other. He stepped up, though. He really did. He wasn't perfect, but he tried. And I think, in the end, we both realized we were better off as friends, supporting each other for the baby's sake.

It's not a fairytale romance, and it never was. It's just…real life. And sometimes, real life is messy and awkward and doesn't have a neat little ending. But it's still okay. It's still good. Because even though things didn't work out the way we planned, we created something amazing. And that's what matters.

So yeah. Leah is my best friend, my lifeline. And Paulie is…the father of my child. And we're all just trying to figure it out as we go along. It's a work in progress, okay? A very messy, complicated work in progress.

Ugh. Okay, so people always ask me that. Like it was some…conscious decision. It wasn't. It was a mistake, obviously. A really big, life-altering mistake. But it wasn't like I *decided* to get pregnant. It just…happened.

Paulie Bleeker and I…well, we were being teenagers. You know? Hormones, bad judgment, not thinking things through. It was a moment of weakness, honestly. A really stupid moment of weakness. And then, suddenly, there was a positive pregnancy test.

It wasn't about wanting a baby. It wasn't about wanting a family. It was about being…stuck. And then having to figure out what to do with being stuck.

I didn't want to just…get rid of it. That didn't feel right. But I also knew I wasn't ready to be a mom. I was sixteen! I was still trying to figure out who *I* was, let alone raise a human being.

So, I decided to find a good home for the baby. A family who could give it everything I couldn't. It wasn't an easy decision, and it was definitely the hardest thing I've ever done. But it felt like the right thing to do.

It wasn't about being selfless or anything. It was about being realistic. And about trying to do what was best for the baby, even if it meant giving it up.

It's complicated, okay? It's not a story with a neat little moral. It just…is. And I'm still figuring it all out.

(Sighs, looks off to the side for a beat, then back with a slightly wry smile)

Regret? That's a big word. It's not like...a simple feeling. It's complicated.

Look, there were definitely times, especially in the beginning, when things were *hard*. Really hard. Like, harder than I ever imagined. And there were moments where I thought, "What have I done?" You know? I was still a kid myself. I was supposed to be worrying about college applications and boys and stuff, not diapers and doctor's appointments.

But regret the *decision* itself? No. Not really.

Because even when it was tough, even when I was scared and overwhelmed, there was something...right about it. About giving Vanessa a good life. About knowing she was okay. And about knowing that Mark and Vanessa's mom were going to be amazing parents.

It wasn't the life I expected. It wasn't the life I planned. But it was a good life. And it made me grow up, in a way I never would have otherwise. It forced me to figure out who I was and what I wanted.

So, no. I don't regret it. It was a messy, complicated, beautiful thing. And I wouldn't trade it for anything.

(Pauses, then adds with a small shrug)

Although, sometimes I still wonder what my life would have been like if things had gone differently. But then I think about Vanessa, and I know I made the right choice. For her, and for me.

Ugh, okay, so finishing high school while pregnant was…a whole thing. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, let me tell you. It was mostly just a lot of caffeine, a lot of hiding my growing belly under oversized hoodies, and a whole lot of sheer stubbornness.

Honestly, it was Paul who really helped. He wasn't thrilled about the situation at first, obviously, but he stepped up. He drove me to school, helped me with my homework, and just generally kept me from completely falling apart. He was a surprisingly good support system, for a skater kid.

My mom was…complicated. She was worried, obviously, but she also knew I was determined to finish. She helped me navigate the whole medical stuff and tried to be supportive, in her own way.

The school was…awkward. Everyone knew, eventually. There was a lot of whispering and staring, and some people were just plain rude. But I had a few good friends – Leah and Renee – who stuck by me. They were lifesavers.

I mostly just focused on getting my work done. I had to keep up with my classes, write essays, and take tests, all while dealing with morning sickness and exhaustion. It was exhausting, to say the least.

I also had to deal with the whole "what are you going to do with the baby?" question. Everyone had an opinion. It was overwhelming.

I just kept telling myself that I needed to finish. I needed to have a plan. I needed to be able to take care of myself and the baby. It wasn't about proving anything to anyone else, it was about proving it to myself.

So, yeah, I finished. I graduated. It wasn't easy, but I did it. And honestly, it made me feel pretty damn proud of myself. It taught me a lot about responsibility and resilience. And it definitely prepared me for what was to come.

It was a mess, but I got through it. And that's all that matters, right?

Ugh, okay. This is…a big question. And it's not like there was a flashing neon sign telling me what to do, you know? It wasn't a simple decision. It was messy and complicated and kinda terrifying.

Honestly? A lot of it came down to my dad. He's…well, he's my dad. He's not always the most emotionally available person, but he's a good guy. And when I told him I was pregnant, he didn't freak out. He didn't yell. He just…listened. And then he said, "Well, what do *you* want to do?"

And I didn't know. I mean, I was sixteen. I hadn't even figured out what I wanted for breakfast, let alone a whole life plan. Abortion was definitely on the table. It felt…practical. Like the responsible thing to do. But it also felt…wrong. I don't know. It just didn't sit right with me.

Then I met Mark and Vanessa. They were…nice. Really nice. And they wanted a baby so badly. They couldn't have one on their own. And the more I talked to them, the more I realized that maybe, just maybe, I could give them that gift.

It wasn't about giving up a baby. It was about *giving* a baby to someone who would love it and cherish it. It was about doing something selfless, even though it was also incredibly selfish for me to want to avoid the whole messy abortion thing.

It wasn't a moral decision, really. It was a practical one, mixed with a whole lot of feelings. And honestly? It was the hardest thing I've ever done. But I think…I think it was the right thing. For me, for the baby, and for Mark and Vanessa.

It's not something I talk about a lot. It's personal. But yeah, that's…that's pretty much it. It wasn't a grand epiphany. It was just…a series of small decisions that led me to that place. And I'm still figuring it all out, you know?

Okay, look. That's a… surprisingly serious question. And honestly, it's not something I spent a lot of time thinking about *before* everything happened with me, you know? But I've had a lot of time to think about it *now*.

And yeah. Absolutely. A kid can thrive under pretty much any arrangement, as long as they're loved and supported. It's not about the *who* of the parents, it's about the *how*.

Like, my situation wasn't exactly…traditional. And it wasn't what anyone expected. But Mark and Vanessa? They were amazing. They wanted me, they were ready for me, and they were gonna give me a good life. And that's what matters.

It doesn't matter if you have a mom and a dad, or two moms, or a dad and a dad, or just one parent who's totally awesome. What matters is that you have people who are gonna be there for you, who are gonna love you unconditionally, and who are gonna help you figure things out.

People get so hung up on what's "normal," but honestly, "normal" is overrated. There's a lot of messed-up stuff that happens in "normal" families. And there's a lot of love and happiness in families that look a little different.

So yeah, I believe a child can thrive under non-traditional arrangements. I'm living proof. It's not about the labels, it's about the love. And that's all that really matters.

Don't let anyone tell you otherwise. Seriously.

Ugh. Okay, don't make me think about this. It's not exactly a fun topic. But if I *have* to be honest… I think my biggest flaw is probably that I build walls. Like, really good, really high walls.

I'm good at being sarcastic and deflecting and making jokes, right? It's a defense mechanism. It keeps people at arm's length. And it's not that I don't *want* to connect with people, it's just… scary. Letting people see the real me, the messy, confused, kinda-freaking-out me? That's terrifying.

I pretend to be all confident and independent, but underneath it all, I'm just… vulnerable. And I'm afraid of getting hurt. So I push people away before they can get too close.

It's not a conscious thing, it's just… what I do. And it probably drives people crazy. Especially Paul. He's really good at seeing through my stuff.

It's a work in progress, okay? I'm learning to let people in a little bit. But it's hard. It's really hard. And sometimes I just want to build a bigger wall.

So yeah. That's probably it. Walls. I'm a professional wall-builder. Don't judge.

Ugh. Mark. Okay, so, that whole thing… it was… a lot. It wasn't like a movie, you know? It wasn't all cute and romantic and stuff. It was messy. Really messy.

Before Mark, I hadn't really thought about relationships beyond, like, what you see in movies or what other people talk about. I figured it was all about, like, grand gestures and perfect moments. And I definitely wasn't planning on getting pregnant with someone I barely knew.

But going through that with him… it forced me to grow up, like, *fast*. It wasn't about the romance anymore. It was about responsibility. And figuring out what I wanted, not what I thought I *should* want.

He wasn't a bad guy, Mark. He was just… immature. And scared. And he wasn't ready to be a dad. And honestly, I wasn't sure *I* was ready to be a mom.

It made me realize that a relationship isn't just about feeling good. It's about being able to rely on someone. About being able to communicate honestly, even when it's hard. About being able to support each other through tough times.

And Mark… he couldn't do that. He wasn't capable of it.

So, it changed my perspective in a big way. It made me realize that I didn't need a relationship to be happy. I needed to be comfortable with myself. And I needed to find someone who was on the same page as me, someone who was ready for a real partnership, not just a fling.

It also made me realize that sometimes, the best thing you can do is let go. Even if it hurts. Especially if it hurts.

It wasn't a fairytale ending, but it was… a learning experience. A really, really hard learning experience. And it made me stronger, I think. And it definitely made me a lot more realistic about love and relationships.

It's still kinda weird to think about, honestly. But yeah. That's how it changed things.

Ugh. Okay. That's...a big question. And it's not easy to answer. But if someone was in a position like I was, staring down the barrel of a really complicated situation... here's what I'd say.

First of all: **it's okay to be scared.** Like, really scared. It's okay to cry, to freak out, to want to hide under the covers and pretend it's not happening. It *is* happening, but you don't have to be strong all the time.
