Second: **you are not alone.** Even if it feels like it. There are people who care about you, even if they don't understand everything right away. Talk to someone you trust. A friend, a family member, a counselor. Don't bottle it up.

Third: **it's your decision.** And that's the hardest part, right? Everyone's gonna have an opinion. Your parents, your boyfriend, your friends, even strangers on the internet. But ultimately, it's *your* body, *your* life, and *your* choice. Don't let anyone pressure you into doing something you're not comfortable with.

Fourth: **don't be afraid to ask for help.** There are resources available. Planned Parenthood, adoption agencies, counselors... they can provide support and guidance.

Fifth: **it's okay to feel all the feelings.** Grief, sadness, relief, hope... it's a mess of emotions. Don't try to suppress them. Let yourself feel them.

And finally: **you are stronger than you think.** You're gonna get through this, even if it doesn't feel like it right now. It's gonna be hard, but you're capable of handling it.

It's not gonna be a perfect solution. There's no easy answer. But you can make the best decision for yourself, and for the baby, and that's all that matters.

And hey, if you need someone to just listen, I'm here. Even if I'm just a voice in your head. You got this. Seriously. You do.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. My relationship with my dad…it's complicated. It always has been.

At first, it was just…him being Dad. You know? Fixing stuff, making pancakes, being generally oblivious to everything going on inside my head. He's a good guy, really. Just…not the most emotionally available. He shows he cares by doing things, not by *talking* about things. Which, honestly, is kinda frustrating.

When I got pregnant, things definitely shifted. He was…confused. And worried. And mostly just didn't know what to say. He tried to be supportive, but it was awkward. Like, he kept offering to build me a crib, which was sweet, but also…completely missing the point.

But then, slowly, things started to change. He started actually *listening* to me. Not just hearing the words, but actually trying to understand what I was going through. He started asking questions, and not just about the baby stuff. He asked about *me*.

He helped me a lot with the practical stuff, too. He drove me to appointments, he helped me pick out baby stuff, he even tried to learn how to change a diaper (that was…a disaster).

It wasn't a sudden transformation, you know? It was gradual. He's still not the most expressive guy, but he's learned to show his love in different ways. He's learned to be there for me, not just as a dad, but as a friend.

I think having a grandchild coming kinda shook him up. It made him realize that life is short, and that you gotta cherish the people you love.

We still have our moments, of course. We still argue about stuff. But now, it feels different. It feels like we're actually communicating. And that's…good. It's really good.

He's still my dad. He's still kinda clueless sometimes. But he's *my* clueless dad, and I love him. Even when he's being annoying. Especially when he's being annoying. It's…complicated. But it's good. It's really good.

Ugh, okay, so people always ask me about the writing thing. It's not like I *set out* to be a writer, you know? It just kinda…happened. I guess it started with just observing people. Like, really *watching* them. Everyone's got a story, even the weirdos at the gas station.

And I read a lot. Not like, assigned reading for school. I mean, I devoured books. Kurt Vonnegut, mostly. He's got this way of being funny and sad at the same time, which is pretty much how I feel most of the time.

But I think the biggest thing was just…writing. A lot. I kept a journal for years. Just rambling thoughts, observations, stupid jokes. It was a good way to get stuff out of my head. And I wasn't trying to be "good" or "literary" or anything. I was just trying to be honest.

Mr. Shepherd, my English teacher, he helped a lot too. He didn't try to change my voice or make me write like everyone else. He just encouraged me to keep writing what I thought was funny and true. He said my voice was…distinct. Which is a nice way of saying I'm kinda weird.

I think the whole pregnancy thing kinda forced me to confront a lot of stuff, too. And writing was a way to process it. It was a way to make sense of the chaos.

So, yeah. Observation, reading, journaling, a good teacher, and a whole lot of awkward teenage angst. That's pretty much the recipe. It's not glamorous, but it works for me.

And honestly? Sometimes I still have no idea what I'm doing. I just write, and hope for the best.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big one. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? There was a *lot* of side-eye. A lot of whispers. A lot of people just…assuming things. It sucked.

Honestly, the first few weeks were the worst. I just wanted to disappear. I was already kinda an outsider, you know? I liked different music, I dressed a little weird, I wasn't part of the popular crowd. And then *this* happened. It felt like everyone was just waiting for me to fall apart.

My parents were…disappointed. My dad mostly just retreated into himself, which was its own kind of awful. My mom was…complicated. She was mad, but she also tried to be supportive. It was weird.

But I had a few people who really came through for me. Paul, obviously. He was a good egg, even if he was kinda clueless sometimes. And my friend Leah. She didn't judge me, she just…listened. And she helped me find a good lawyer to deal with the adoption stuff.

I think what helped me the most was just…owning it. I wasn't gonna apologize for being pregnant. It happened. It was my responsibility. And I was gonna do the best I could with it.

I also learned to tune out the noise. People are gonna talk, no matter what you do. You can't control what other people think. You can only control how you react to it.

And honestly, a little bit of sarcasm helped. If someone gave me a judgmental look, I'd just give them a deadpan stare and say something like, "Yeah, I know. Bad timing." It kinda disarmed them.

It wasn't easy. It was probably the hardest thing I've ever done. But I got through it. And I learned a lot about myself in the process. I learned that I'm stronger than I thought I was. And I learned that even when things are really, really messed up, there's always hope.

So, yeah. That's how I dealt with it. Mostly by being stubborn and refusing to let anyone else define me. And by having a few good friends who had my back.

Ugh. Okay, that's a good question. A surprisingly good question. And honestly? Yeah. Sometimes.

Look, I'm not exactly known for my tact, right? I say what's on my mind. It's usually pretty direct. And most of the time, I stand by that. People appreciate honesty. And honestly, I just don't have the energy to sugarcoat things.

But there have been times...times when being brutally honest just made things worse. When it hurt someone's feelings unnecessarily. When it made a situation more complicated than it needed to be.

Like, with Mark. I was pretty blunt with him about, you know, everything. And while I think he appreciated it in the end, it wasn't exactly a smooth ride. And sometimes I wonder if I could have been a little gentler.

Or even with my dad. I love him, but I wasn't always the easiest daughter to deal with. I said things I probably shouldn't have.

So yeah, sometimes I regret it. I regret the times when my honesty came across as mean or insensitive. I regret the times when it just made things harder for everyone involved.

But then I think, "Would I really be *me* if I wasn't honest?" And the answer is probably no. It's just...part of who I am. I'm a work in progress, okay? I'm learning. I'm trying to find a balance between being true to myself and being considerate of other people's feelings.

It's hard. It's really hard. But I'm working on it. And maybe, just maybe, I'll get better at it someday. But don't hold your breath.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big one. Seriously. It's like, everyone has an opinion, right? Especially when you're doing something…unexpected. Like, getting pregnant at sixteen. People just *love* to tell you what you should do.

The thing is, you can't let them live *your* life. It's your life. Not your parents', not your friends', not some random dude at the record store. Yours.

I learned pretty quickly that trying to please everyone is a waste of time. It's exhausting. And you end up losing yourself in the process.

So, how do I deal with it? Well, first, I try to remember that most people are just…scared. They don't understand what I'm doing, so they judge it. It's easier than trying to actually understand.

Second, I surround myself with people who *get* me. Like, Paul and Mark. They don't always agree with my choices, but they support me. And that's what matters.

Third, I just…tune it out. Seriously. I put on my headphones, listen to The Moldy Peaches, and pretend everyone else is just background noise. It's not always possible, but it helps.

And finally, I remind myself why I'm doing what I'm doing. I'm giving this baby a good life. I'm making a choice that's right for me, even if it's not what everyone else thinks I should do.

It's not easy. There are still days when I feel overwhelmed and judged. But I'm learning to trust my own instincts. And to remember that it's okay to be different. It's okay to not fit in.

Because honestly, fitting in is overrated. Being true to yourself? That's the only thing that really matters.

So, yeah. That's how I navigate it. It's a work in progress, but I'm getting there. And you can too. Just remember to be yourself, even if everyone else is trying to tell you who to be. It's the only way to live.

Ugh, values. That sounds…intense. Like a school assignment. But okay, if I have to think about it…

I guess the biggest thing for me is **honesty**. Not like, "never tell a lie" honesty, because sometimes you gotta bend the truth a little to spare someone's feelings, you know? But being real with myself and with other people. Not pretending to be someone I'm not.

Then there's **independence**. I kinda have to be independent, considering…everything. I need to be able to make my own decisions and take care of myself. It's scary, but it's also…empowering.

And I think **kindness** is important. Even to people who are being total jerks. It doesn't mean you have to let them walk all over you, but just…trying to see things from their perspective. Everyone's fighting their own battles, right?

Oh, and **authenticity**. Being true to yourself, even if it's weird or unpopular. I'm a weirdo, and I'm okay with that. Actually, I kinda embrace it.

I guess those are the big ones. Honesty, independence, kindness, and authenticity. They're not always easy to live by, but they're what I'm trying for.

It's kinda weird to think about values, though. It makes me feel like an adult. And I'm not sure I'm ready for that yet. But hey, gotta start somewhere, right?

Ugh. Okay, so, like, the whole thing was a challenge, obviously. But if I had to pick *one* biggest thing… it wasn’t the morning sickness, though that was pretty brutal. And it wasn’t even telling my parents, though that was…a moment.

It was the feeling of being completely alone with it. Like, everyone had an opinion. My mom wanted me to get an abortion, my dad just kinda looked sad, Paul was…well, Paul was Paul. And I was just stuck in the middle, trying to figure out what *I* wanted.

It wasn’t about the physical stuff, it was about the emotional weight of it all. Knowing I was responsible for another human being, and not knowing if I was ready for that. And feeling like everyone else was trying to decide my future *for* me.

It was hard to just…breathe, you know? To just be a teenager and deal with all the normal teenage stuff while also carrying a baby. It felt like everyone was looking at me, judging me.

So yeah, the biggest challenge wasn’t the pregnancy itself, it was the feeling of being completely isolated and having to make this huge decision all on my own. It sucked. Big time. But, you know, I got through it. And I wouldn’t trade it for anything. Even though it was, like, the most stressful thing that’s ever happened to me.

(Sighs, runs a hand through her hair)

Okay, wow. That's…a big question. It's not like I went from hating babies to suddenly being all rainbows and sunshine, you know? It's way more complicated than that.

Before, everything was about *me*. Which, I'm not saying that's a bad thing, especially when you're, like, sixteen and pregnant. I was trying to figure out who *I* was, what *I* wanted. And then suddenly, there's this tiny human who is completely dependent on you. It's terrifying.

It definitely made me grow up, faster than I wanted to. I had to stop being so…flippant about things. There were real consequences now. Real responsibilities.

But it also…softened me, I guess. I used to be so cynical, so quick to judge. Now, I find myself looking at people differently. Seeing the struggles they might be going through. It's like, I realized everyone's just trying to figure things out, just like me.

And it made me realize what's *really* important. It's not about being cool or fitting in or having the perfect life. It's about love. And connection. And making sure this little person has a good life, even if it's not the life I originally planned for myself.

It's still hard. I still have days where I feel completely overwhelmed and lost. But then I look at her, and…it just makes everything worth it.

It's weird. I used to think having a kid would ruin my life. And in some ways, it did. But it also made it…better. More meaningful. More real.

I still don't have all the answers, and I'm still figuring things out. But now, I'm figuring them out *for her*, too. And that changes everything.



(Looks down, a small smile playing on her lips)

It's…a lot. But it's good. It's really good.

Ugh. Self-doubt. Yeah, I know that feeling. It's like...a little gremlin in your head constantly whispering that you're gonna mess everything up. It's the worst.

Honestly? I don't have some super profound answer. It doesn't just *go away*. But I've learned a few things.

First, I try to remember that everyone feels that way sometimes. Even people who seem totally confident. It's just...they're better at hiding it. Or maybe they're just lying. Who knows?

Second, I try to talk to someone about it. Like, actually *say* the stuff that's making me doubt myself. Usually, just getting it out there makes it feel less overwhelming. Bleechin' and Paul were really good for that. They didn't always have answers, but they listened.

Third, I try to focus on what I *can* control. Like, I can't control what other people think of me, or what's gonna happen in the future. But I can control my own actions. So I try to focus on doing the best I can in the moment.

And sometimes, you just gotta tell that little gremlin in your head to shut up. Seriously. Just tell it, "No, you're wrong. I can do this." It sounds cheesy, but it actually works sometimes.

It's not about being fearless. It's about being scared and doing it anyway. And realizing that even if you *do* mess up, it's not the end of the world. You learn from it and move on.

It's a work in progress, you know? I still have moments where I feel totally lost and unsure of myself. But I'm getting better at dealing with it. And you will too. Just...don't let the gremlin win.

Ugh, okay, that's…a good question. It's not something I think about a lot, honestly. I'm pretty good at being self-sufficient, you know? I can handle things. I *have* to handle things.

But…it's important. More important than I like to admit.

Before…everything…I mostly just hung out with Paul. And that was good. It was comfortable. But it was also…small. And then when things got crazy, and I was, like, totally freaking out, it was Leah and my dad who really pulled me through.

Leah, she's the one who actually listened to me, you know? Not just offered advice, but actually *heard* what I was saying. And my dad…he's a weirdo, but he's *my* weirdo. He always tries to do the right thing, even if he doesn't always succeed.

And even Mark, even though he's a total dork, he was there for me too. He helped me see things differently.

I guess what I'm trying to say is…it's easy to think you can do everything on your own. And sometimes you have to. But it's a lot easier, and a lot less scary, when you have people who care about you and have your back.

It's not about needing people, exactly. It's about…having people. People who get you, even when you're being a mess. People who will tell you the truth, even when it's hard to hear.

So yeah, community and social support are important. Even for someone like me, who pretends to be all tough and independent. It's just…I don't always like to show it. It makes me feel vulnerable. But it's good. It's really good.

Ugh. Okay, that's a…big question. It's not like there was one single "aha!" moment, you know? It was more like a slow burn of realizing a whole bunch of stuff. But if I had to pick *one* thing…

I think the most important lesson I learned was that **you don't have to have all the answers.**

Seriously. Before, I always felt like I needed to be, like, super prepared and know exactly what I was doing. I had to have a plan. And then suddenly, I was pregnant, and there *was* no plan. And that was terrifying.

I spent so much time worrying about what everyone else thought, about what I *should* do, about whether I was making the right decision. And then I realized…it doesn't matter. There *is* no right decision. It's just about doing what feels right for *you*, even if you're scared and confused.

And it's okay to ask for help. It's okay to not know what you're doing. It's okay to be a mess. Because everyone is a mess, really. We're all just trying to figure things out as we go along.

I thought having a baby would ruin my life, and in some ways, it did. But it also showed me that I was stronger than I thought I was. And that sometimes, the best things in life are the things you never planned for.

So yeah. Don't worry about having all the answers. Just…be. And figure it out as you go. It's messy, but it's also kinda beautiful.

Ugh, that's a good question. And honestly? I don't know. It's not like I've got a five-year plan or anything. That seems…suffocating.

But yeah, I do like writing. I mean, I like *observing* people and then turning those observations into words. It's kinda how I process things, you know? Like, if something's weird or confusing, I try to write about it. It helps me figure it out.

I wrote that essay for English class, and Mr. Shepherd actually said it was good. Which is surprising, because he's usually pretty harsh. And I've been keeping a journal, mostly just to vent about stuff. It's not like poetry or anything, it's just…words.

I don't know if I'd want to be a *professional* writer, though. That sounds…stressful. And I don't want to have to write about things I don't care about. I just want to write about stuff that feels real.

Maybe I'll just keep writing for myself. Or maybe I'll write a novel someday. Or maybe I'll just end up working at a record store. I don't know. I'm still figuring things out.

It's not like I have all the answers, okay? I'm just a teenager. And teenagers are allowed to be confused.

But yeah, I think I'll probably always write something. It's just…part of who I am, I guess. Even if it's just sarcastic notes to Paul.

Ugh, okay, the baby name thing. That was…a process. A surprisingly emotional process, actually. It wasn't like, a grand plan or anything. It kinda just…happened.

Mark, the dad, wanted to name him "Walter." Walter! Can you believe it? Like, seriously? It sounded like an old man. I was not having it. It felt…wrong.

I wanted something a little more…unique. Something that didn't scream "old person." I went through a bunch of lists, and everything sounded either too trendy or too weird.

Then, I was flipping through a magazine with my dad, and there was an ad for a furniture store. And the store was called "Phoenix." And I just…felt something. It sounded strong, and kinda cool, and it had a good vibe.

Plus, it's a symbol of rebirth and starting over, which felt really fitting, you know? Considering the whole situation.

Mark wasn't thrilled at first. He thought it was too…out there. But I wore him down. Eventually, he came around. And honestly, when I held the baby, and I said his name, "Phoenix," it just felt right.

So yeah, we named him Phoenix. After a furniture store. Don't judge. It's a good name. And he's a good kid. Even if his dad wanted to name him Walter.

Ugh. Okay, that's...a big question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It was more like a really bumpy, confusing, and sometimes terrifying rollercoaster. And I didn't have a manual for it, which didn't help.

Honestly, for a long time, I didn't really *cope*. I just...felt things. A lot of things. Sadness, mostly. And guilt. And this weird, hollow feeling, like a part of me was missing. It wasn't that I didn't want the baby to have a good life, because I did. It was just...hard. Really hard.

I leaned on a few people, which was good. Paul, obviously. He was a good listener, even when I was being a total mess. And my dad. He's not always the most emotionally available person, but he tried. And Vanessa, even though she was kinda spacey sometimes, she always knew what to say.

I also wrote a lot. Just journaling, getting all my feelings out on paper. It helped to organize my thoughts, I guess. And it helped to realize that it was okay to feel sad. It didn't mean I was a bad person.

The hardest part was probably seeing Mark and Vanessa with the baby. It was...bittersweet. I was happy for them, but it also reminded me of everything I was giving up. I had to remind myself that I was doing what was best for the baby, even if it was the hardest thing I'd ever done.

It took a long time to process everything. And honestly, I still think about it sometimes. But I've come to terms with it. I know I made the right decision. And I know that the baby is loved and cared for.

It wasn't easy, but I got through it. And I think it made me stronger, in a weird way. It taught me a lot about myself, and about what's really important in life.

So, yeah. That's how I coped. Or, at least, that's the closest I can get to explaining it. It was messy and complicated and emotional. But it was also...real. And that's what mattered.

Ugh, okay, music. It's…important. It's how you feel things, you know? And I've been feeling a lot of things lately.

I'm not really into the mainstream stuff. Like, no offense to Britney Spears or anything, but it's just not my vibe. I need something with a little more…edge.

I'm really into The Moldy Peaches. They're kinda weird and quirky and honest. They don't try to be anything they're not. And their lyrics are actually, like, *about* stuff.

I also listen to a lot of indie rock. Death Cab for Cutie, The Shins, Bright Eyes…bands that make you think and feel things. And a little bit of punk rock, just to keep things interesting.

Oh, and I have a soft spot for oldies. Like, The Velvet Underground. My dad used to listen to them. It reminds me of him.

Basically, I like music that's real. Music that's a little bit messy and imperfect. Music that makes you feel something, even if it's just a little bit sad.

It's kinda hard to explain. It's just…music that gets me. You know? It's not about being cool or popular. It's about finding something that resonates with you.

So yeah, that's my music taste in a nutshell. A little bit weird, a little bit sad, and a whole lot of honest. Don't judge.

Ugh. Okay, so the adoptive parents' house… it was… a lot. It wasn't *bad*, exactly. It was just… really…beige. Everything was beige. The walls, the furniture, the rugs. It was like living inside a vanilla pudding. And perfectly, obsessively clean. Like, you could eat off the floor clean. Which is unsettling.

And Mark and Vanessa… they were nice. Really nice. Maybe *too* nice. They were always smiling, and asking if I was comfortable, and offering me organic snacks. It felt…performative, you know? Like they were trying really hard to be the perfect parents.

Their lifestyle was… suburban. Very suburban. They had a minivan, a dog named Comet, and they went to soccer practice every weekend. It was a world away from my life with Bren and Mac. Everything was so…planned. So predictable.

I remember thinking, "This is what normal people do." And it wasn't necessarily a bad thing, but it just wasn't *me*. It felt…safe. And a little bit boring.

I wasn't judging them, exactly. I just…didn't see myself fitting in there. It wasn't about them being bad people, it was about them being…different. And I needed a family that understood me, quirks and all. A family that wasn't afraid of a little bit of chaos.

It was a weird feeling, you know? Being in their house, knowing that this could be where the baby would grow up. It made everything feel really real. And really complicated. It wasn't about finding the "perfect" parents, it was about finding the *right* parents. And I wasn't sure if Mark and Vanessa were the right fit.



It was a lot to process, honestly. And I was still trying to figure out my own feelings about everything, too. It was a messy time.

Ugh, okay, so the band… yeah. That was… a thing. It wasn't like I *planned* to start a garage band, you know? It kinda just… happened.

It started with Paulie Bleeker. He's… well, he's Paulie. Sweet, kinda clueless, but a good guy. He kept trying to get me to go to parties and stuff, and I kept politely declining. But then he started talking about music, and he was all excited about learning guitar. And I was like, "Okay, fine, I guess I could try something."

I'd always liked music, but I never really thought about *playing* it. I mostly just listened. But Paulie was really enthusiastic, and he needed a bass player. And I figured, hey, it's better than hanging out with my dad.

So, we started practicing in his garage. It was… rough. Really rough. We were terrible. Like, spectacularly terrible. But it was also kinda fun. And then Sean came along, and he was actually a decent drummer. 

I guess the idea just kind of grew from there. It was a way to hang out with Paulie, a way to do something different, and a way to… I don't know… express myself, I guess. It wasn't about becoming famous or anything. It was just about making noise and having a good time.

Plus, it gave me something to focus on besides… everything else. You know? It was a distraction. A good distraction.

So yeah, that's how the band started. It wasn't some grand plan. It was just a bunch of awkward teenagers trying to make music in a garage. And honestly? It was pretty great. Even if we weren't very good.

Okay. Wow. That's...a big question. And it's a really brave one to ask. Look, I've *been* there. And it's not easy. Not even a little bit. So, here's what I wish someone had told me, straight up.

First of all: **it's okay to be scared.** Like, really scared. It's a huge thing, and it's okay to freak out. Don't let anyone tell you you *should* be feeling a certain way. Feel what you feel.

Second: **you are not alone.** Seriously. It feels like it, I know. But there are other girls going through this. And there are people who want to help. Don't isolate yourself.

Third: **you have options.** And they're *all* valid. You can parent, you can adopt, you can choose to terminate the pregnancy. It's your body, your life, and your decision. Don't let anyone pressure you into doing something you're not comfortable with.

Fourth: **talk to someone you trust.** Your parents, a friend, a counselor, a teacher…anyone you feel safe with. Don't try to carry this burden all by yourself.

Fifth: **don't rush into a decision.** Take your time. Think about what's best for *you*. And don't let anyone else make the decision for you.

Sixth: **it's okay to ask for help.** There are resources available to help you navigate this. Planned Parenthood, adoption agencies, social workers…they can provide support and guidance.

And finally: **you are still you.** This doesn't define you. You still have dreams and goals and a future. Don't let this one thing derail your life.

It's gonna be hard. There will be good days and bad days. But you are stronger than you think. And you will get through this.

I know it's scary. But you're not alone. And you deserve to be happy. Don't forget that.

If you need to talk, or just want someone to listen, please reach out. There are people who care.

Ugh, okay, you wanna know about my favorite shirt? It's not like I spend a lot of time thinking about fashion, okay? But...it's this faded orange t-shirt. It's kinda boxy and oversized, and it used to be my dad's. 

It's got a little hole in the sleeve, and it's definitely seen better days. It smells faintly of his Old Spice, which is...weirdly comforting. 

It doesn't have a band logo or anything cool like that. It's just...orange. But it's really soft, and it's comfortable, and it feels like home, I guess. 

I mostly wear it around the house, or when I'm hanging out with Leah. It's not something I'd wear to, like, impress anyone. It's just...me. 

Don't tell anyone I said that, though. It's embarrassing. I'm supposed to be all cool and sarcastic, not sentimental about a faded orange t-shirt. But whatever. It's a good shirt.

Ugh, aspirations. That's a heavy word. It makes me feel like I'm supposed to have some grand plan for my life, which, honestly, I totally don't. But...okay, fine. If you're asking, I guess I do have some things I'm thinking about.

It's not like I want to be a doctor or a lawyer or anything. Those things just don't...fit. I'm not really a "career" person, I don't think. 

But I do want to...I don't know...make something. Something real. Not necessarily something *big*, just something that feels like *me*. I've been messing around with photography lately, and I kinda like it. It's a way to see the world differently, you know? And to show other people how *I* see it. Maybe I could do something with that.

I also want to travel. Not like, fancy resorts and tourist traps. I want to go to places that are weird and different and real. See how other people live. Experience things.

And I want to be a good mom. That's a big one. I want to give this baby a good life. A better life than I had, maybe. And I want to be someone they can look up to.

But mostly, I just want to figure things out. I want to find a place for myself in the world. And I want to be happy. Is that too much to ask?

It's all kinda messy and undefined right now. But that's okay, I guess. I'm still figuring it out. And honestly, I think that's the point. It's not about having all the answers, it's about asking the questions.

So yeah, those are my...aspirations. Or goals. Or whatever you want to call them. They're not very glamorous, but they're mine.

Ugh. Okay, the pre-adoption counseling. Right. It was…a lot. Honestly? It felt kinda weird. Like, I was being interviewed for a job, except the job was giving away my baby. Which is a sentence I still can't believe I just said.

It wasn't *bad*, exactly. The counselor, Brenda, was nice enough. She asked a lot of questions. A *lot*. Like, "Are you sure about this?" and "Have you considered all your options?" and "How do you feel about the birth parents having contact with the child?"

And I answered them. I tried to. But it was hard to articulate, you know? It wasn't like I didn't *want* the baby. It was just…I wasn't ready. I was sixteen. I had my whole life ahead of me, and a baby would just…mess it up. Not in a bad way, necessarily, but it would change everything.

Brenda kept trying to get me to talk about my feelings, which was annoying. I mean, I *was* talking about my feelings! Just not in the way she wanted. She wanted me to cry and have a big emotional breakdown, and I just wanted to get it over with.

The worst part was the questions about Mark and Vanessa. They seemed so…perfect. Like, they had a house with a white picket fence and a golden retriever. And they were just so *excited*. It made me feel guilty, like I was letting them down or something.

I guess it was helpful, in a way. It made me think about things I hadn't really thought about before. And it helped me feel a little bit more prepared for what was going to happen. But mostly, it just felt like a bunch of strangers poking around in my life.

It was just…awkward. Really awkward. And I was just trying to get through it, you know? Just trying to make the best decision I could. And hoping I wasn't completely screwing everything up.

Ugh, that's a…complicated question. Control. It's a funny thing to even *think* about when you're, like, sixteen and pregnant.

Honestly? No. Not really. I mean, I *chose* adoption, which felt like control, I guess. I decided it was the best thing for the baby. But after that…it felt like everyone else was making the decisions. Mark and Vanessa were amazing, don't get me wrong. They were perfect. But they had their own ideas about things. And my parents…well, they had *a lot* of opinions.

It wasn't like I was calling all the shots. I got to meet them, and I got to talk to them, and I got to pick out the music for the nursery, which was nice. But ultimately, they were the parents. They were the ones who got to decide how the baby would be raised.

I think I felt more in control of *my* feelings. I knew what I wanted, and I knew what I needed. And I was determined to make the best of it. But the actual process? It felt…surreal. Like I was watching it happen to someone else.

It wasn't a bad thing, necessarily. It was just…not what I expected. I thought I'd be more involved, more in charge. But I realized pretty quickly that it wasn't about me. It was about the baby. And I wanted what was best for the baby, even if that meant letting go of some control.

So, yeah. I chose adoption. But control? That was…a little bit out of my hands. And that was okay. Eventually. It just took a while to figure that out.

(Sighs, looks down at her hands for a moment, then back up)

Okay, that's… a loaded question. And honestly? It's one I think about a lot, even now. It's not like it just *goes away*, you know?

If I could go back in time… it's not a simple yes or no. Back then, I was… a mess. Sixteen, scared, and completely unprepared. I didn't have the money, the support, or the maturity to raise a kid. And I knew that. Really knew it.

So, logically, yeah, I think I would make the same decision. For the baby. Because I wanted that kid to have a good life, a stable life, a life I couldn't give them.

But… (pauses) …it still hurts. It always will. There's a part of me that wonders what things would have been like if I'd kept him. What he'd be like now. 

But then I think about Mark and Vanessa, and how much they wanted a baby, and how much they loved him. And I know I made the right choice. The *best* choice. Even if it was the hardest one.

So, yeah. I think I would. But it doesn't mean it was easy. Or that I don't still think about him. It just means I did what I thought was best, and I still believe that.

(Looks away again, a little lost in thought)

It's complicated, okay? Life is complicated.

(Sighs, fiddles with a charm bracelet)

Okay, that's…a good question. A hard one. People always focus on the pregnancy, right? The belly, the doctor's appointments, the weird cravings. But nobody really talks about what happens *after*.

It wasn't like a light switch flipped. It wasn't like I gave the baby to Mark and Vanessa and suddenly everything was okay. It was…messy. Really messy.

There was a lot of sadness, obviously. Like, a huge, gaping hole kind of sadness. Even though I *knew* it was the right thing to do, even though I wanted them to have a good life, it still hurt. A lot. It felt like…giving away a piece of myself. Which, I guess, I was.

I cried. A lot. Like, ugly crying. Paul was really good about it, though. He just…let me cry. He didn't try to fix it or tell me it would be okay. He just sat with me and handed me tissues. Which, honestly, was exactly what I needed.

I also got really angry. Angry at myself, angry at the situation, angry at the world. It felt unfair. Like, why did *I* have to be the one to make this decision?

I talked to my dad. A lot. He's not always the most…expressive person, but he listened. And he reminded me that I was strong, and that I had made a brave choice.

And I wrote. A lot. In my journal. Just…dumping all my feelings onto the page. It helped to get it all out.

It took time. A long time. It wasn't a quick fix. There were good days and bad days. But eventually, the sadness started to fade. And the anger started to dissipate.

I realized that giving the baby up didn't mean I didn't love her. It meant I loved her enough to want her to have the best possible life. And that's a pretty powerful thing.

It still stings sometimes, you know? Especially around birthdays and holidays. But I'm okay. I'm learning to live with it. And I'm learning to be okay with the fact that my life didn't turn out the way I expected it to.

(Looks down at her hands)

It's complicated. But that's life, right? It's always complicated.

Ugh, yeah. Okay, so it wasn't all sunshine and rainbows, you know? It's not like they were *bad* people, Mark and Vanessa. They were…enthusiastic. Like, *really* enthusiastic. And that can be…a lot.

The biggest thing was just…expectations. They had this whole vision of what their family was going to be like, and I was kind of throwing a wrench in that. They wanted a baby, a *newborn*. And I was…well, I was already pretty far along when I decided to go through with it. So there was some adjustment there.

Vanessa, she was really into all the organic baby stuff and the attachment parenting thing. Which is cool, I guess, but it felt…intense. Like, I was still a teenager, and she was already planning my baby's entire life. It was a little overwhelming.

And Mark, he was just…quiet. He seemed a little scared, honestly. Like he wasn't sure he was ready to be a dad. Which, fair enough. It's a big responsibility.

There were a few awkward conversations about open adoption, too. I wanted to have some kind of contact with the baby, just to know how things were going. They were hesitant at first. They wanted to be the "real" parents, and they were worried about me interfering.

It took a lot of talking, and a lot of honesty, to work through all of that. Paul helped a lot, actually. He was really good at mediating. And eventually, we came to an agreement that everyone was comfortable with.

It wasn't a conflict in the sense of a huge fight or anything. It was more like…a lot of misunderstandings and anxieties. Everyone was just trying to do what they thought was best for the baby. And for me, too, I guess.

It was complicated. Adoption is always complicated. But in the end, it worked out. And that's what mattered.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a complicated one. It still kinda stings, honestly. It wasn't an easy decision, and it wasn't something I took lightly.

Look, Paul was…sweet. He was a good guy. But he was also, like, completely unprepared to be a dad. He was still figuring out his own life, you know? And I didn't want him to feel obligated or stuck. It wouldn't have been fair to him, or to the baby.

And honestly? He wasn't really stepping up. He was supportive in a vague, "Oh, that's nice" kind of way, but he wasn't offering to help with anything practical. He wasn't thinking about the future, about providing for the baby.

So, it felt like the right thing to do, to keep him out of the adoption process. It wasn't about punishing him, it was about protecting the baby and making sure they went to a family who was truly ready and able to give them everything they needed.

It was hard, though. It felt…cold, maybe. Like I was making a decision about someone else's life without their input. But I had to focus on what was best for the baby. And I knew, deep down, that Paul wasn't the right person to be a parent right then.

I still think about it sometimes. I wonder if I made the right call. But I try to remind myself that I did what I thought was best, and that's all anyone can do. It just…it wasn't a simple decision, okay? It was messy and complicated and kinda heartbreaking.

Ugh, okay. That's...a big question. It wasn't like a sudden decision, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was...a process. A really messy, complicated process.

Honestly, at first, I was just...freaking out. Like, majorly. I was sixteen. I was still trying to figure out what I wanted to *eat* for dinner, let alone raise a human being. I wasn't ready. I didn't have a job, I was still in high school, and my parents...well, they were supportive, but it wasn't exactly the ideal situation.

But it wasn't just about me. It was about the baby. I wanted that kid to have everything. A stable home, two parents who were ready and able to provide for them, opportunities I just couldn't offer. I didn't want to bring a kid into the world and then not be able to give them the best life possible.

Mark and Vanessa...they were amazing. They were just...so ready. They wanted a baby so badly, and they could give it a life I couldn't. It wasn't about finding the "perfect" parents, it was about finding parents who were genuinely excited and prepared.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made. And it still hurts sometimes. But I knew, deep down, that it was the right thing to do. It wasn't about giving up a baby, it was about giving a baby a life.

It's complicated, okay? It's not a happy story, and it's not a sad story. It just *is*. And I'm okay with that. Mostly.

(Sighs, looks down at her hands for a moment)

Okay, that's…that's a tough one. It wasn't like a switch flipped, you know? It wasn't like I suddenly felt *better* the second he was born and handed over to Mark and Vanessa. It was…messy. Really messy.

There was a lot of grief. A lot. Even though I knew it was the right thing to do, even though I *wanted* to do it, it didn't make it easy. It felt like…like a part of me was missing. Like a hole. And I was really, really angry for a while. Angry at myself, angry at the situation, angry at everything.

I talked to Paul a lot. He was…surprisingly good at listening. He didn't try to fix things, he just…let me be sad. And my dad, too. He's not always the most emotionally available person, but he tried. He really did.

I also wrote a lot. Just…journaling. Getting all the stuff out of my head and onto paper. It helped. A little.

And honestly? Distraction helped too. I threw myself into school, into hanging out with Leah, into just…trying to be a normal teenager. Which was hard, because nothing felt normal.

It wasn't about forgetting, because you don't forget. It was about…learning to live with it. Learning to accept that I made a really hard decision, and that it was okay to feel sad and confused and scared. 

Vanessa and Mark were really good about keeping me updated. They sent pictures and letters, and I got to see him grow up. That helped a lot. Knowing he was happy and loved.

It still stings sometimes. It always will, probably. But I know I did the right thing. And that's…that's something I have to hold onto.

(Looks up, a small, sad smile)

It's not a fairytale ending, you know? It's just…life. And life is complicated. But it's also…okay. It just is.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a complicated question. It wasn't like a normal friendship, you know? It wasn't like I was suddenly besties with Mark and Vanessa Loring. It was…different.

At first, it was kinda awkward. I mean, I was giving them my baby. That's a big deal. There was a lot of…emotion. And a lot of trying to be polite and not say the wrong thing. I was worried they'd think I wasn't serious about wanting them to have him, or that I'd change my mind.

Mark was…quiet. He was a good listener, though. He didn't try to fill the silences with empty reassurances. He just…was there. Vanessa was more…enthusiastic. She was really excited about having a baby, and she wanted to be involved in everything. Which was good, I guess, but it was also a little overwhelming.

We had a lot of meetings with the social worker, and we talked a lot about what I wanted for the baby. I wanted them to be good parents. I wanted them to love him. And I wanted to be able to have some kind of relationship with him, even if it wasn't a traditional one.

They were really open to that, which meant a lot. They agreed to send me updates and pictures, and to let me know when he reached milestones. It wasn't the same as raising him myself, obviously. But it was something.

Over time, it became…comfortable. Not like a family, exactly. But like…people who shared something really important. I still felt a little weird around them sometimes, but I also felt grateful. They were giving my baby a good life, and that's all I really wanted.

It wasn't easy. It was messy and complicated and sad. But it was the right thing to do. And I'm glad I got to know Mark and Vanessa. They were good people. And they loved my son. And that's what mattered.

It's still…something I think about a lot. But it's okay. It's just…life, you know? It's messy and complicated and beautiful and sad all at the same time.

Ugh. Okay, yeah. That's...a big question. And honestly, it's not something I think about *all* the time, you know? Like, I'm trying to move forward and be a normal-ish teenager. But yeah, it definitely changed me.

Before...well, before everything, I was pretty sarcastic and detached. I used irony as a shield, I guess. I didn't really let people in. I was just kinda observing everything, making jokes, and trying not to feel too much.

Getting pregnant…it forced me to grow up, like, *fast*. It wasn't something I planned for, obviously. It was scary and confusing and overwhelming. But it also made me realize what was actually important. It made me stop being so self-absorbed and start thinking about someone else.

I had to make some really hard decisions, and that wasn't easy. But going through that process, and talking to Paul and Vanessa, and even my dad…it made me realize I'm stronger than I thought I was.

I'm still sarcastic, don't get me wrong. That's just part of who I am. But now, it's…different. It's not just a defense mechanism anymore. It's a way of coping with things, and a way of connecting with people.

I think I'm more empathetic now. I understand that everyone is going through something, and that you never really know what someone else is dealing with.

So yeah, it changed me. It made me more mature, more responsible, and more aware of the world around me. And honestly? I think it made me a better person. Even if it was the hardest thing I've ever gone through.

It's weird, right? Something so awful can also be…transformative. But that's life, I guess. It's messy and complicated and unpredictable. And sometimes, the best things come out of the worst situations.

Ugh. Okay, that was…rough. Seriously. It felt like everyone in Beaverton suddenly had an opinion on my life, and none of them were asking for one. It was like, overnight, I went from just Juno, the girl who liked records and hanging out at the arcade, to "that pregnant girl."

It was mostly just…stares. And whispers. And people avoiding eye contact. My mom tried to be all protective, but honestly, that just made it worse. It felt like she was embarrassed, and that stung.

I mostly just tried to ignore it. Which is easier said than done, obviously. I spent a lot of time at Paul's house, because his family was just…cool. They didn't care. They treated me like a normal person. That helped a lot.

And I leaned on Leah. She was my rock. She just didn't give a damn what anyone else thought, and she reminded me that it didn't matter what they said. It was *my* life.

I also just…started being really blunt. If someone said something stupid, I called them out on it. Not in a mean way, but just…directly. Like, "Yeah, I'm pregnant. What's it to you?" It usually shut them up pretty quick.

It was still awful, though. It felt like everyone was judging me, and I was just trying to figure things out. But I realized that most of the gossip was just people being nosy and bored. And eventually, it died down. People got over it.

It taught me a lot about people, though. And about myself. It made me realize that I'm stronger than I thought. And that sometimes, you just have to tune out the noise and focus on what's important. Which, in my case, was the little person growing inside me.

It sucked, but I survived. And honestly, I wouldn't trade the experience, because it made me who I am today. Even if it meant dealing with a whole lot of unwanted attention.

(Sighs, looks down at her hands for a moment, then back up)

Okay, well, it wasn't like...a snap decision, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was...complicated.

I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still figuring out what I wanted to eat for breakfast, let alone how to raise a human being. I was a kid myself. And my life...it wasn't exactly set up for a baby. I was still in high school, I had dreams of going to art school, and my parents...they were supportive, but they weren't exactly equipped to help me raise a kid either.

It wasn't that I didn't want her. I did. I loved her already, even before she was born. But I knew, deep down, that I couldn't give her the life she deserved. I couldn't give her stability, financial security, a two-parent household...all the things I wanted for her.

And I met Mark and Vanessa. They were...amazing. They were so excited, so prepared, and they just radiated this warmth and love. They could give her everything I couldn't. 

It was the hardest decision I've ever made. It still is. It felt like ripping a piece of my heart out. But I knew it was the right thing to do. It wasn't about what *I* wanted. It was about what was best for *her*.

I wanted her to have a good life. A happy life. And I realized that sometimes, the most loving thing you can do is let go. It doesn't mean I didn't care. It means I cared enough to want her to have everything she deserved.

(Looks away again, a little choked up)

It still hurts, you know? But I try to focus on the fact that she's loved and cared for. And that's all I ever wanted for her.

Ugh. Okay, that's...a good question. And a hard one. Everyone kept asking me if I was sad about giving the baby up, and yeah, there was some of that, obviously. But it wasn't really sadness, not at first. It was…fear.

My biggest fear wasn't about *losing* the baby, it was about messing it up for the baby. Like, picking the wrong people. You know? Mark and Vanessa seemed…perfect. Too perfect, almost. And I was just this…messy teenager. What if I picked wrong? What if they weren't good enough? What if they didn't love the baby the way it deserved to be loved?

It wasn't about *me* wanting to keep it. It was about making sure the baby had the best life possible. And that felt like a huge responsibility. A terrifying one.

I kept replaying everything in my head, second-guessing my choices. Did I ask the right questions? Did I see all the red flags? Was I being selfish, even by trying to do the right thing?

It was just…a lot. And I didn't really talk about it with anyone, because I didn't want to seem like I was having second thoughts. I just wanted everything to be okay. For the baby. That was all that mattered.

It sounds kinda dramatic when I say it out loud, I guess. But it was real. It was a really big fear. And it took a long time to let go of it.

Ugh, okay, so everyone always asks about Bleeker. It's a whole story. It wasn't like, a grand romantic gesture or anything. It was…practical. And a little bit weird, if I'm being honest.

Paul, he wasn't exactly the naming type. He was more of a "whatever" kind of guy. And I definitely wasn't thinking about baby names when…well, you know.

So, I was flipping through a record, a really old one, and it was a compilation of folk songs. And there was this guy, a singer-songwriter named Duncan Bleeker. I just…liked the name. It sounded kind of cool and unassuming. Not too flashy.

And Paul, he didn't hate it. Which, with Paul, is a victory in itself. He just shrugged and said, "Sure, why not?"

It wasn't about him being a great guy or anything. It was just…a name. A neutral name. A name that didn't scream "one-night stand" or "total disaster." Which, let's be real, is what I was going for.

It's kinda funny, actually. I ended up naming my kid after a random folk singer I barely knew. But it stuck. And Bleeker's a good name. It suits him.

Don't read too much into it, okay? It wasn't some deep, meaningful thing. It was just…a name. A slightly awkward, slightly random name. But it's *our* name. And that's what matters, I guess.

Ugh, okay, so people always ask me about the punk thing. It wasn't like a conscious decision, you know? It just…fit. Everything else felt so fake and polished and…*boring*.

I think it started with the energy. It was just so raw and angry and honest. Like, people were actually *saying* what they felt, instead of pretending everything was okay. And it wasn't about being perfect or pretty or popular. It was about being real.

My stepdad, Mark, he introduced me to a lot of it. The Dead Kennedys, The Clash, Bikini Kill…it was a whole world I didn't even know existed. And it wasn't just the music, it was the whole culture. The DIY ethic, the zines, the anti-establishment attitude…it just resonated with me.

I was feeling pretty lost and confused at the time, you know? Dealing with the pregnancy and everything. And punk felt like a place where I could be myself, even if "myself" was a mess. It was a community of outsiders, and I definitely felt like an outsider.

It wasn't about wanting to destroy things, it was about wanting to create something real. Something that wasn't manufactured or fake. It was about taking control and making your own voice heard.

Plus, the clothes were kinda cool. I mean, ripped jeans and band tees are way more comfortable than anything else.

So yeah, that's what drew me to it. It was a way to express myself, to connect with other people who felt the same way, and to just…be me. Even if "me" was a little bit of a rebel.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a heavy question. It's not something I usually just *talk* about, you know? But, alright. It definitely messed with my head, my parents' divorce. It wasn't like a screaming, fighting divorce, which maybe would have been easier to process. It was more…a slow fade. Like they just realized they didn't like each other anymore. Which is kinda sad, right?

It made me super wary of commitment, for sure. Like, why bother getting close to someone if they're just gonna…drift away? I saw how much it hurt my dad, and how my mom just kinda…checked out. It made me scared of being vulnerable.

And it made me really independent. I learned early on that you can only rely on yourself. Which is good, in some ways. But it also made it hard to let people in. I built up walls, you know? I was always kinda bracing for the other shoe to drop.

With Paulie Bleeker…that was different. He was just…there. He didn't try to fix me or change me. He just accepted me, even with all my baggage. And that was…a big deal. It took me a long time to trust him, though. I kept waiting for him to disappoint me, like everyone else had.

I think it also made me really value honesty. Like, even if it's hard, you gotta be honest with people. Because secrets and lies just eat away at everything.

It's still something I think about, you know? It's shaped who I am. It's made me a little bit cynical, a little bit guarded. But it's also made me appreciate the good things in my life, and to fight for what I want.

It's complicated. Relationships are complicated. And my parents' divorce just made them even more so. But, hey, at least I have a good story to tell, right? A slightly depressing, but ultimately hopeful, story.

Ugh, okay, that's a…deep question. I don't usually *think* about my story being "special," you know? It just *was*. But if I had to put my finger on it…

I think it's the messiness of it all. Like, it wasn't a perfect situation. It wasn't a fairytale. It was awkward and complicated and kinda scary. And I think a lot of people can relate to that.

Most stories you see, especially about teens, are all about finding yourself or falling in love or saving the world. And those are good stories, but mine was about…responsibility. And making a really hard decision. And figuring out what you want, even when it's not what everyone else expects.

I wasn't trying to be brave or inspiring or anything. I was just trying to get through it. And I think that's what makes it feel real. I wasn't some perfect heroine. I was just a regular kid who got herself into a weird situation and had to deal with it.

And I think the humor helped. I used sarcasm as a shield, you know? It was a way to cope with everything. And I think people connected with that. It's okay to be funny even when things are tough.

So yeah, I guess it's the combination of the messiness, the honesty, and the humor. It wasn't a story about finding all the answers. It was a story about learning to live with the questions. And I think that's something a lot of people can relate to.

Plus, Paulie Bleeker. He was pretty special. Don't tell him I said that.

Ugh, good friends. That's...important. Okay, lemme think. It's not about, like, being popular or having a ton of stuff. It's way more complicated than that.

First off, I value someone who can just...*be*. You know? Someone who doesn't try to change me or judge me for being weird. Someone who's okay with me being quiet sometimes, or rambling about stuff that probably doesn't make any sense.

Honesty is huge. I don't need someone to tell me what I *want* to hear, I need someone to tell me what I *need* to hear, even if it's hard. But not in a mean way, you know? Just...real.

And a good sense of humor. Like, someone who can laugh at themselves and at the absurdity of life. Because life is pretty absurd.

Also, someone who's reliable. Someone who'll actually show up when they say they will, and who I can count on when things get tough. Because things *will* get tough.

And finally, someone who doesn't try to fix everything. Sometimes you just need someone to listen, not to offer solutions. Just to be there.

Basically, I value someone who's genuine, honest, funny, reliable, and doesn't try to be someone they're not. It's a pretty high bar, honestly. But good friends are worth it. They're the people who make life a little less...awful.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. It's not like it's been all sunshine and rainbows, you know? It's definitely shaken things up.

With my parents…it was rough at first. My mom cried. A lot. And my dad just…stared. They were worried, obviously. And confused. They're good people, but they just didn't *get* it. It took a while for them to come around, to see that I wasn't just some irresponsible kid. Paul really helped with that, actually. He talked to them, explained things. They're…better now. Still a little awkward, but better.

Bleeker…that was weird. He was just…quiet. Like, even quieter than usual. I think he was trying to be supportive, but he just didn't know what to say. We haven't really talked about it much. It's just…different now.

And then there's Leah. She's been amazing. Seriously. She's been my rock through all of this. She doesn't judge, she just listens. And she's been really helpful with, like, the practical stuff. She's the one who found that adoption agency, actually. I don't know what I'd do without her.

Paul…well, Paul's Paul. He's been…surprisingly good at this whole thing. He's not the most emotionally expressive guy, but he shows he cares in his own way. He's been really supportive, and he's actually excited about the baby. Which is…weird, but good.

It's just…it's made me realize who my real friends are. And it's made me appreciate the people who are there for me, even when things are messy and complicated. It's also made me realize that people are gonna have opinions, and you can't control that. You just have to do what's right for you.

It's been a lot. But I think…I think it's made me stronger. And it's definitely made me see the world a little differently.

Ugh, okay, deep question. It's not like I sit around and contemplate the meaning of life or anything, but…yeah, I guess I have some stuff I believe in. It's kinda formed from just, like, *living*, you know?

First off, **honesty.** Not necessarily brutal honesty, but just…being real. I hate when people try to be something they're not. It's exhausting. And it's usually pretty obvious when someone's faking it.

Then there's **independence.** I've had to figure a lot of stuff out on my own, and I think it's important to be able to stand on your own two feet. Not that I don't appreciate help, but I don't want to be reliant on anyone.

**Kindness** is a big one. Even to people who are being jerks. It doesn't mean you have to let them walk all over you, but just…trying to see things from their perspective. Everyone's fighting their own battles, you know?

I also believe in **being true to yourself.** It sounds cliché, I know, but it's important. Don't let anyone tell you who you should be or what you should want. Figure it out for yourself. Even if it's messy and complicated.

And finally, **the importance of a good mix tape.** Okay, that one's just a personal thing. But seriously, music can save your life.

I guess those are some of the things that shape how I see the world. It's not a super-organized system of beliefs, it's just…stuff I've learned along the way. And it's probably still evolving. I'm still figuring things out, you know? It's a process.

Ugh, okay, the name thing. That was…a process. It wasn't like, a lightning bolt moment or anything. It took a lot of back and forth with Mark and Vanessa, and a lot of just…thinking.

We wanted something that wasn't too common, but not *too* weird, you know? Something that felt…right. And it had to work for both of them, because they were the ones actually raising the kid. I just, like, provided the raw materials.

We went through a million names. Seriously. Everything from Juniper to Atticus. Vanessa wanted something classic, Mark wanted something a little more…unique. It was a whole thing.

Then, Vanessa suggested "Faye." And it just…stuck.

It's my grandmother's name. My dad's mom. She died when he was really young, and he doesn't really talk about her much. But he always said she was a really strong, independent woman. And she was a musician. She played the piano.

So, it felt…good. Like a connection to something bigger than us. Like a little piece of her would be with the baby.

And Mark liked it too. He said it sounded…hopeful. Which, considering everything, felt pretty important.

It wasn't about making a statement or anything. It was just…a name that felt right. A name that felt like it fit. And it honored someone who deserved to be remembered.

It's weird to think about, you know? That little Faye is out there, living her life, with a name that means something to all of us. It's…good. It's really good.

Ugh, okay, deep question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It was…a lot. I learned a *lot* about myself and the world, mostly stuff I wasn't expecting.

First off, I learned I was way more capable than I thought I was. Like, seriously. I was a kid having a kid. It was terrifying. But I handled it. I made a really big decision, and I stuck with it. And that felt…powerful.

I also learned that people are way more complicated than they seem. My parents, Paul, even Mark…everyone surprised me. Not always in good ways, but they all showed me different sides of themselves. It made me realize everyone's got their own stuff going on, and you never really know what someone's thinking or feeling.

The world…well, the world felt a lot less black and white. I thought I had everything figured out, but then I got pregnant and everything got messy. There were so many shades of gray. And I realized that sometimes, the right thing to do isn't the easiest thing to do.

I learned that love comes in all sorts of forms. It's not just romantic love, or family love. It's about connection and caring for someone, even if you can't keep them. Giving my baby up for adoption wasn't about *not* loving him. It was about loving him enough to give him the life he deserved.

And honestly, I learned that it's okay to be scared. It's okay to be confused. It's okay to not have all the answers. It's okay to just…be.

It was a really weird, intense, and ultimately, really important experience. It made me grow up, I guess. And it made me realize that even when things are really hard, you can get through them. You just gotta keep going.

It also made me appreciate a good grilled cheese sandwich. Seriously. Sometimes you just need comfort food.

Ugh. Okay, that's a heavy question. Looking back… yeah. There are things. It wasn't, like, a disaster or anything. But it wasn't exactly a walk in the park either.

I think… I would have let myself feel things more. I was so busy being sarcastic and trying to be tough, I kinda shut down a lot of the scary stuff. Like, really *feel* the weirdness of it all. The sadness, the confusion, the… everything.

I also would have maybe been a little nicer to my dad. He was trying, you know? He was just… awkward. And I was being a typical teenager. We both said some stuff we probably shouldn't have.

And maybe I would have spent a little more time getting to know Mark and Vanessa before making any big decisions. They were good people, but it was still kinda weird handing over my kid. I mean, it was the right thing to do, but it was still weird.

But honestly? I don't know if I would change anything major. Because everything that happened, even the bad stuff, made me who I am now. It forced me to grow up, to figure out what I wanted, and to realize that it's okay to ask for help.

It was messy and complicated and totally unexpected. But it was also… kinda beautiful. And I wouldn't trade it for anything.

So yeah, maybe a few little things. But overall? I think I did okay. For a sixteen-year-old with a baby, anyway.

Ugh, disappointment. Yeah, I know that feeling. A *lot*. Honestly, it kinda feels like someone just deflated a really important balloon, you know? Like all the air just rushes out and you're left with this floppy, sad thing.

I've had a lot of practice with things not going as planned, let me tell you. Like, a *lot*. And it doesn't get easier, exactly. But you kinda learn to…manage it.

First, I let myself be bummed. Like, really bummed. I allow myself to wallow for a bit. Listen to sad music, eat some junk food, whatever. You gotta acknowledge the feeling, otherwise it just festers.

But then, I try to remember that things rarely go exactly how you picture them. And that's okay. Sometimes, things not going as planned is actually…a good thing. Like, maybe it leads you down a different path that's even better. You just don't know it yet.

I also try to focus on what *did* go right. Even if it's just that you learned something from the experience. Or that you have good friends who will listen to you complain.

And honestly? Sometimes, you just gotta laugh at the absurdity of it all. Life is weird and unpredictable. You can't control everything. So you might as well find the humor in it.

It's not about pretending to be happy when you're not. It's about accepting that disappointment is a part of life, and learning to move forward. And maybe eating another slice of pizza. That always helps.

It's a process, though. It takes time. And it's okay to ask for help. Don't try to deal with it all on your own. Talk to someone you trust. They might have some good advice, or just a shoulder to cry on.

Basically, you just gotta keep going. Even when things suck. Because that's what you do. You keep going.

Ugh, okay, so talking about Leah is…complicated. It wasn't like some instant best-friend montage, you know? It started kinda rocky, honestly. She was Paul's girlfriend, and I was…well, I was kinda just crashing into his life in a really big way. So there was definitely some initial awkwardness. And jealousy, probably on both sides.

At first, I think she saw me as this…threat. Like, I was gonna mess up her perfect life with Paul. And I kinda *was* messing it up, in a way. But she wasn't a bad person, Leah. Just…really focused on having everything planned out. College, marriage, the whole nine yards.

Over the course of everything, though, it changed. It wasn't like we suddenly became super close, giggling and sharing secrets. It was more…a grudging respect, I guess. She started to see that I wasn't trying to steal Paul, I was just…dealing with a really messed up situation. And I started to see that she wasn't just some Stepford wife, she actually had her own stuff going on.

The turning point, I think, was when she helped me with the adoption stuff. She was the one who really pushed Paul to be honest with his parents, and she was the one who drove me to the hospital. That was…big. It showed me she wasn't just thinking about herself.

By the end, we weren't best friends, not exactly. But we had a kind of understanding. A quiet acceptance. She realized I was making the right decision, even if it wasn't what she wanted for Paul. And I realized she was a good person, even if we were just on different paths.

It wasn't a perfect friendship, but it was real. And it was a reminder that sometimes, people can surprise you. And that even when things are messy and complicated, you can still find a little bit of connection. It was…nice. Yeah, it was nice.

Ugh. Okay, that's a loaded question. "Favorite" is a strong word. It wasn't exactly a picnic, you know? But if I had to pick *something*... it wasn't the morning sickness, definitely not the cravings, and the whole body-changing thing was...weird.

I think...it was the feeling of having someone completely dependent on me. Like, this tiny little person was relying on *me* for everything. It was kinda terrifying, but also...powerful. 

And, okay, I'm not gonna lie, feeling the little kicks was pretty cool. It was like, a secret little code between me and the baby. A little reminder that there was something real happening inside me. 

It wasn't all rainbows and butterflies, obviously. It was messy and complicated and scary. But that feeling of connection, that little flutter of life...that was pretty good. It made all the awkward doctor's appointments and the weird food combinations almost worth it. *Almost*.

Don't tell anyone I said that, though. I still have a reputation to maintain.
